byāharanto.example_1: anādariyaṃ paṭicca sakabaḷena mukhena byāharanto ekaṃ āpattiṃ āpajjati.
byāharanto.translation_1: When, out of disrespect, one speaks with food in one’s mouth, one commits one kind of offense:

vipattivāro.meaning_2: class of failure; section on failure for each offense
vipattivāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound refers to a specific chapter or section (vāra) dealing with the classes or types (vipatti) of failure or lapses associated with each monastic offense, marking the conclusion of the third such section.
vipattivāro.translation_1: The classes of failure for each offense, the third, are finished.
vipattivāro.translation_2: The classes of failure for each offense, the third, are finished.

saṅgahitavāro.meaning_2: section of classifications; chapter on grouped cases
saṅgahitavāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya text, 'saṅgahitavāro' refers to the fourth chapter or section that deals with the classification and grouping of offenses, marking the completion of that portion.
saṅgahitavāro.translation_1: The classes of offenses in each offense, the fourth, are finished.
saṅgahitavāro.translation_2: The classes of offenses in each offense, the fourth, are finished.

pārājikāpattikkhandhena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the instrumental singular form used in the context to indicate membership in the category of Pārājika offenses, the most severe class in the Vinaya requiring expulsion from the monastic community.
pārājikāpattikkhandhena.example_1: siyā pārājikāpattikkhandhena, siyā thullaccayāpattikkhandhena, siyā dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena …pe….
pārājikāpattikkhandhena.translation_1: they may be in the class of offenses entailing expulsion; they may be in the class of serious offenses; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong conduct. …
pārājikāpattikkhandhena.example_2: siyā pārājikāpattikkhandhena, siyā thullaccayāpattikkhandhena, siyā dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena.
pārājikāpattikkhandhena.translation_2: they may be in the class of offenses entailing expulsion; they may be in the class of serious offenses; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong conduct.

thullaccayāpattikkhandhena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in Vinaya contexts to denote membership in the category of grave transgressions among monastic offenses, as seen in lists classifying potential rule violations.
thullaccayāpattikkhandhena.example_1: siyā pārājikāpattikkhandhena, siyā thullaccayāpattikkhandhena, siyā dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena …pe….
thullaccayāpattikkhandhena.translation_1: they may be in the class of offenses entailing expulsion; they may be in the class of serious offenses; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong conduct. …
thullaccayāpattikkhandhena.example_2: siyā pārājikāpattikkhandhena, siyā thullaccayāpattikkhandhena, siyā dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena.
thullaccayāpattikkhandhena.translation_2: they may be in the class of offenses entailing expulsion; they may be in the class of serious offenses; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong conduct.

dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena.meaning_2: class of offenses of wrong conduct; group of dukkaṭa transgressions
dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This instrumental singular form appears in Vinaya contexts to denote membership in the dukkaṭa category of offenses, the least severe class requiring simple acknowledgment, as seen in the repeated listings of offense classes where it consistently translates to 'in the class of offenses of wrong conduct'.
dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena.example_1: siyā pārājikāpattikkhandhena, siyā thullaccayāpattikkhandhena, siyā dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena …pe….
dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena.translation_1: they may be in the class of offenses entailing expulsion; they may be in the class of serious offenses; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong conduct. …
dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena.translation_2: in the class of offenses of wrong conduct.

samuṭṭhānavāro.meaning_2: chapter on originations; section on causes of offenses
samuṭṭhānavāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In this Vinaya context, 'samuṭṭhānavāra' refers to the fifth chapter concluding the discussion of the originations or causes (samuṭṭhāna) of each monastic offense (āpatti). The repetitive sentences indicate the chapter's conclusion.
samuṭṭhānavāro.translation_1: The originations of each offense, the fifth, are finished.
samuṭṭhānavāro.translation_2: The originations of each offense, the fifth, are finished.

adhikaraṇavāro.meaning_2: legal issue; section on disciplinary proceedings; chapter on legal matters
adhikaraṇavāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya text, adhikaraṇavāro refers to the sixth chapter or section concluding the discussion of legal issues (adhikaraṇa) pertaining to monastic offenses, as indicated by the sentence marking its completion.
adhikaraṇavāro.translation_1: The legal issues to which each offense belongs, the sixth, are finished.
adhikaraṇavāro.translation_2: The legal issues to which each offense belongs, the sixth, are finished.

samathavāro.meaning_2: section on settling; chapter on adjudication of cases
samathavāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'samathavāra' refers to a specific chapter or section dealing with the procedures for settling or adjudicating monastic offenses, as indicated by the concluding phrases marking the completion of the seventh or fifteenth such section.
samathavāro.translation_1: How each offense is settled, the seventh, is finished.
samathavāro.translation_2: How each offense is settled, the seventh, is finished.

samuccayavāro.meaning_2: summary; section (referring to a concluding compilation of previous topics)
samuccayavāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'samuccayavāro' denotes the eighth section of the text, which serves as a summary or compilation of the preceding six sections, as indicated by the English translation. The compound combines 'samuccaya' (collection or summary) with 'vāra' (section or chapter), fitting the structure of a concluding part in Pāḷi commentaries or treatises.
samuccayavāro.translation_1: The summary of the previous six sections, the eighth, is finished.
samuccayavāro.translation_2: The summary of the previous six sections, the eighth, is finished.

sajjhāyamaggena.meaning_2: by the path/method of recitation; through the way of chanting/studying
sajjhāyamaggena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the compound 'sajjhāyamagga', used to indicate the means by which the eight sections were written down, emphasizing oral recitation as the traditional method of textual composition and preservation in Pāḷi literature.
sajjhāyamaggena.translation_1: These eight sections were written down through the method of recitation.

katthapaññatti.meaning_2: designation of place; concept of 'where'; where it is designated or laid down
katthapaññatti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'katthapaññatti kati ca', it functions as a compound noun inquiring about the location or scriptural source where a rule or concept was designated or established, with 'kati ca' asking 'and how many'. This usage aligns with paññatti's sense of 'designation' or 'prescription' in Vinaya contexts, combined with kattha meaning 'where'.
katthapaññatti.translation_1: “Where was it laid down, and how many,

vipattisaṅgahena.meaning_2: by failure and support; by failure and inclusion; by failure and holding together
vipattisaṅgahena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the tatpuruṣa compound vipattisaṅgaha, glossed in context as 'failure, and being found in' or 'failure and support', likely referring to failure combined with being encompassed or maintained in a negative state.

samuṭṭhānādhikaraṇā.meaning_2: originations, legal issues; cases of arising and disciplinary proceedings
samuṭṭhānādhikaraṇā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in the locative plural, functioning adverbially to indicate the basis or context of the discussion, specifically the origins and legal matters in Vinaya procedures.

paṭisevanapaccayā.grammar: ind, adv, in comps, abl sg of paṭisevanapaccaya
paṭisevanapaccayā.meaning_2: dependent on using; due to making use of; as a result of taking; lit. from the condition of using
paṭisevanapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the contextual sentences, this adverbial form indicates the causal condition for committing offenses, specifically the four offenses resulting from sexual intercourse (methunaṃ dhammaṃ paṭisevana), as laid down by the Buddha. It functions to specify the basis or reason for the legal and disciplinary implications in the Vinaya.
paṭisevanapaccayā.example_1: yaṃ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena methunaṃ dhammaṃ paṭisevanapaccayā pārājikaṃ kattha paññattaṃ, kaṃ ārabbha, kismiṃ vatthusmiṃ …pe…
paṭisevanapaccayā.translation_1: “The offense entailing expulsion that is a result of having sexual intercourse was laid down by the Buddha who knows and sees, the Perfected One, the fully Awakened One. Where was it laid down? Whom is it about? What is it about? …
paṭisevanapaccayā.example_2: yaṃ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena methunaṃ dhammaṃ paṭisevanapaccayā pārājikaṃ kattha paññattanti?
paṭisevanapaccayā.translation_2: “The offense entailing expulsion that is a result of having sexual intercourse was laid down by the Buddha who knows and sees, the Perfected One, the fully Awakened One. Where was it laid down?”

voropanapaccayā.meaning_2: as a result of depriving of life; due to taking life
voropanapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial compound used instrumentally in the sense of 'due to' or 'resulting from' the act of depriving (someone) of life, specifically in the context of intentional killing leading to grave monastic offenses (pārājika). It qualifies the offense as arising from the act of homicide.
voropanapaccayā.example_1: sañcicca manussaviggahaṃ jīvitā voropanapaccayā pārājikaṃ kattha paññattanti?
voropanapaccayā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing expulsion that is a result of intentionally killing a human being. Where was it laid down?”
voropanapaccayā.example_2: sañcicca manussaviggahaṃ jīvitā voropanapaccayā kati āpattiyo āpajjati?
voropanapaccayā.translation_2: How many kinds of offenses does one commit as a result of intentionally killing a human being?

ullapanapaccayā.grammar: ind, adv, in comps, abl sg of paccaya
ullapanapaccayā.meaning_2: due to claiming; as a result of false boasting; caused by extolling non-existent qualities
ullapanapaccayā.construction: ud + √lap + ana + a > ullapana + paccay + a > ullapanapaccay + ā
ullapanapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'ullapanapaccayā' refers to the causal condition of falsely claiming superhuman qualities (uttarimanussadhamma), leading to offenses like pārājika. It combines 'ullapana' (boasting or extolling) with 'paccayā' (ablative indicating 'due to' or 'by means of'). The phrase specifies the motivation or basis for the rule's infraction, as seen in questions about where such a rule was laid down and the number of offenses it entails (three in total).
ullapanapaccayā.example_1: asantaṃ abhūtaṃ uttarimanussadhammaṃ ullapanapaccayā pārājikaṃ kattha paññattanti?
ullapanapaccayā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing expulsion that is a result of claiming a non-existent superhuman quality. Where was it laid down?”
ullapanapaccayā.example_2: asantaṃ abhūtaṃ uttarimanussadhammaṃ ullapanapaccayā kati āpattiyo āpajjati?
ullapanapaccayā.translation_2: How many kinds of offenses does one commit as a result of claiming a non-existent superhuman quality?

saṅghādisesakaṇḍādi.meaning_2: chapter on offenses entailing suspension, etc.
saṅghādisesakaṇḍādi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound title for a chapter in the Vinaya Piṭaka, referring to the section beginning with saṅghādisesa offenses (requiring community involvement for resolution) and extending to other categories of rules.
saṅghādisesakaṇḍādi.translation_1: 2. The chapter on offenses entailing suspension, etc.
saṅghādisesakaṇḍādi.translation_2: 2. The chapter on offenses entailing suspension, etc.

upakkamitvāasuciṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form upakkamitvāasuciṃ results from sandhi where the final -ā of the absolutive upakkamitvā combines with initial a- of asuciṃ, causing loss of the intervocalic -v- in pronunciation and orthographic fusion. In context, it describes an action of approaching something impure, likely a physical or ritual uncleanliness.

mocanapaccayā.meaning_2: due to the cause of releasing; on account of emitting
mocanapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'mocanapaccayā' refers to the instrumental condition for the suspension offense involving deliberate emission of semen, functioning adverbially to indicate the causal basis ('by means of' or 'due to') of the act.
mocanapaccayā.example_1: yaṃ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena upakkamitvā asuciṃ mocanapaccayā saṅghādiseso kattha paññatto, kaṃ ārabbha, kismiṃ vatthusmiṃ …pe…
mocanapaccayā.translation_1: “The offense entailing suspension that is a result of emitting semen by means of effort was laid down by the Buddha who knows and sees, the Perfected One, the fully Awakened One. Where was it laid down? Whom is it about? What is it about? …
mocanapaccayā.example_2: yaṃ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena upakkamitvā asuciṃ mocanapaccayā saṅghādiseso kattha paññattoti?
mocanapaccayā.translation_2: “The offense entailing suspension that is a result of emitting semen by means of effort was laid down by the Buddha who knows and sees, the Perfected One, the fully Awakened One. Where was it laid down?”

samāpajjanapaccayā.grammar: ind, adv, in comps, abl sg of samāpajjanapaccaya
samāpajjanapaccayā.meaning_2: dependent on entering upon; due to the condition of entering upon
samāpajjanapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of Vinaya offenses, this adverbial form indicates the conditional basis for incurring saṅghādisesa offenses, such as physical contact (kāyasaṃsagga) or matchmaking (sañcaritta), where 'samāpajjana' refers to entering upon the prohibited act, and 'paccayā' specifies 'due to' or 'as a result of' that condition.
samāpajjanapaccayā.example_1: mātugāmena saddhiṃ kāyasaṃsaggaṃ samāpajjanapaccayā saṅghādiseso kattha paññattoti?
samāpajjanapaccayā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing suspension that is a result of making physical contact with a woman. Where was it laid down?”
samāpajjanapaccayā.translation_2: “There is an offense entailing suspension that is a result of acting as a matchmaker. Where was it laid down?”

obhāsanapaccayā.meaning_2: due to indecent speech; as a result of addressing indecently
obhāsanapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound adverbial form describes the causal condition arising from speaking indecently to a woman, leading to offenses entailing suspension or three kinds of offenses. It combines the neuter noun obhāsana ('shining, illuminating,' here implying indecent addressing) with the ablative adverb paccayā ('dependent on, due to').
obhāsanapaccayā.example_1: mātugāmaṃ duṭṭhullāhi vācāhi obhāsanapaccayā saṅghādiseso kattha paññattoti?
obhāsanapaccayā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing suspension that is a result of speaking indecently to a woman. Where was it laid down?”
obhāsanapaccayā.example_2: mātugāmaṃ duṭṭhullāhi vācāhi obhāsanapaccayā tisso āpattiyo āpajjati—
obhāsanapaccayā.translation_2: As a result of speaking indecently to a woman, one commits three kinds of offenses:

bhāsanapaccayā.meaning_2: due to speech; on account of speaking; as a result of talk
bhāsanapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'bhāsanapaccayā' functions as an adverbial phrase indicating the causal condition ('as a result of') for the offense, specifically 'encouraging [a woman] with praise/speech' to satisfy desires, leading to suspension or three offenses. It combines 'bhāsana' (speech) with 'paccayā' (ablative of condition, meaning 'due to').
bhāsanapaccayā.example_1: mātugāmassa santike attakāmapāricariyāya vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanapaccayā saṅghādiseso kattha paññattoti?
bhāsanapaccayā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing suspension that is a result of encouraging a woman to satisfy one’s own desires. Where was it laid down?”
bhāsanapaccayā.example_2: attakāmapāricariyāya vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanapaccayā tisso āpattiyo āpajjati—
bhāsanapaccayā.translation_2: As a result of encouraging the satisfaction of one’s own desires, one commits three kinds of offenses:

kārāpanapaccayā.meaning_2: result of having something built by means of begging; offense resulting from ordering construction
kārāpanapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound is an ablative form used adverbially to indicate the cause or condition leading to the offense, as seen in the Vinaya contexts where having a hut or large dwelling built through begging results in suspension (saṅghādisesa).
kārāpanapaccayā.example_1: saññācikāya kuṭiṃ kārāpanapaccayā saṅghādiseso kattha paññattoti?
kārāpanapaccayā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing suspension that is a result of having a hut built by means of begging. Where was it laid down?”
kārāpanapaccayā.example_2: mahallakaṃ vihāraṃ kārāpanapaccayā saṅghādiseso kattha paññattoti?
kārāpanapaccayā.translation_2: “There is an offense entailing suspension that is a result of having a large dwelling built. Where was it laid down?”

anuddhaṃsanapaccayā.grammar: ind, adv, in comps, abl sg of anuddhaṃsanapaccaya
anuddhaṃsanapaccayā.meaning_2: dependent on accusing; due to charging; as a result of groundlessly denouncing; as a result of charging using a pretext
anuddhaṃsanapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This instrumental/ablative form functions adverbially in the sentences to indicate the causal basis for the saṅghādisesa offense, specifically 'as a result of' the act of groundless or pretextual accusation of a pārājika offense against a monk. It combines the neuter noun anuddhaṃsana (accusing) with paccaya (condition), forming a compound whose ablative denotes 'from the condition of accusing'.
anuddhaṃsanapaccayā.example_1: bhikkhuṃ amūlakena pārājikena dhammena anuddhaṃsanapaccayā saṅghādiseso kattha paññattoti?
anuddhaṃsanapaccayā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing suspension that is a result of groundlessly charging a monk with an offense entailing expulsion. Where was it laid down?”
anuddhaṃsanapaccayā.example_2: bhikkhuṃ aññabhāgiyassa adhikaraṇassa kiñcidesaṃ lesamattaṃ upādāya pārājikena dhammena anuddhaṃsanapaccayā saṅghādiseso kattha paññattoti?
anuddhaṃsanapaccayā.translation_2: “There is an offense entailing suspension that is a result of charging a monk with an offense entailing expulsion, using an unrelated legal issue as a pretext. Where was it laid down?”

paṭinissajjanapaccayā.meaning_2: due to not giving up; as a result of refusing to let go; on account of not stopping
paṭinissajjanapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this adverbial compound describes the condition under which an offense is committed, specifically when a monk or nun persists in prohibited behavior (e.g., pursuing schism, being difficult to admonish) despite being formally pressed up to three times (yāvatatiyaṃ samanubhāsanāya) to desist. The ablative form paccayā indicates causality, meaning 'because of' or 'on account of' the failure to renounce the action.
paṭinissajjanapaccayā.example_1: saṅghabhedakassa bhikkhuno yāvatatiyaṃ samanubhāsanāya na paṭinissajjanapaccayā saṅghādiseso kattha paññattoti?
paṭinissajjanapaccayā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing suspension that is a result of a monk not stopping with pursuing schism in the Sangha when pressed for the third time. Where was it laid down?”
paṭinissajjanapaccayā.example_2: bhedakānuvattakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ yāvatatiyaṃ samanubhāsanāya na paṭinissajjanapaccayā saṅghādiseso kattha paññattoti?
paṭinissajjanapaccayā.translation_2: “There is an offense entailing suspension that is a result of monks not stopping siding with one who is pursuing schism in the Sangha when pressed for the third time. Where was it laid down?”

bhedakānuvattakānaṃ.meaning_2: (gen pl) of those who side with schismatics; partisans of one pursuing schism in the Sangha
bhedakānuvattakānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in genitive plural, functioning as a bahuvrīhi to modify bhikkhūnaṃ ('of monks who side with schismatics'). In the Vinaya context, it refers to monks who continue to support a schismatic leader, leading to the saṅghādisesa offense if they refuse to desist after three admonitions.
bhedakānuvattakānaṃ.example_1: bhedakānuvattakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ yāvatatiyaṃ samanubhāsanāya na paṭinissajjanapaccayā saṅghādiseso kattha paññattoti?
bhedakānuvattakānaṃ.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing suspension that is a result of monks not stopping siding with one who is pursuing schism in the Sangha when pressed for the third time. Where was it laid down?”
bhedakānuvattakānaṃ.example_2: bhedakānuvattakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ yāvatatiyaṃ samanubhāsanāya na paṭinissajjantānaṃ saṅghādiseso katihi samuṭṭhānehi samuṭṭhāti?
bhedakānuvattakānaṃ.translation_2: There is an offense entailing suspension for monks who do not stop siding with one who is pursuing schism in the Sangha when pressed for the third time. How many originations does it have?

karaṇapaccayā.meaning_2: by reason of action; on account of doing; due to the instrumental cause
karaṇapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya contexts provided, 'karaṇapaccayā' functions as an adverbial compound indicating the causal or instrumental reason behind an offense, emphasizing that the transgression arises 'by reason of the action' or 'due to the doing' of the prohibited act, such as defecating in water out of disrespect or initiating a lawsuit. This usage highlights the instrumental condition (paccaya) tied to the act (karaṇa) as the basis for incurring the āpatti.
karaṇapaccayā.example_1: anādariyaṃ paṭicca udake uccāraṃ vā passāvaṃ vā kheḷaṃ vā karaṇapaccayā dukkaṭaṃ kattha paññattanti?
karaṇapaccayā.translation_1: “There is an offense of wrong conduct that is a result of, out of disrespect, defecating, urinating, or spitting in water. Where was it laid down?”
karaṇapaccayā.example_2: anādariyaṃ paṭicca udake uccāraṃ vā passāvaṃ vā kheḷaṃ vā karaṇapaccayā kati āpattiyo āpajjati?
karaṇapaccayā.translation_2: As a result of, out of disrespect, defecating, urinating, or spitting in water, how many kinds of offenses does one commit?

asucimocanapaccayā.meaning_2: support for emitting impurity; condition for emitting semen
asucimocanapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an ablative form of a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'by the condition of emitting impurity,' specifically referring to semen in the Vinaya context of offenses from intentional emission.
asucimocanapaccayā.translation_1: How many kinds of offenses does one commit as a result of emitting semen by means of effort?
asucimocanapaccayā.translation_2: One commits three kinds of offenses:

ekapiṇḍe.meaning_2: single lump; one bit of food
ekapiṇḍe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ekapiṇḍe is locative singular of the compound ekapiṇḍa, likely meaning 'in one lump' or 'in a single bit of food', combining eka 'one' with piṇḍa 'lump, bit of food'. Without context, the precise usage is inferred from common Vinaya references to alms food.

pācittiyāpattikkhandhena.meaning_1: class of offenses entailing confession; group of transgressions requiring confession
pācittiyāpattikkhandhena.meaning_2: they may be in the class of offenses entailing confession
pācittiyāpattikkhandhena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This instrumental singular form is used in Vinaya contexts to denote inclusion in the pācittiya category of monastic offenses, as seen in the repeated phrases indicating possible classifications of actions or rules.
pācittiyāpattikkhandhena.example_1: siyā pārājikāpattikkhandhena, siyā thullaccayāpattikkhandhena, siyā pācittiyāpattikkhandhena, siyā dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena …pe….
pācittiyāpattikkhandhena.translation_1: they may be in the class of offenses entailing expulsion; they may be in the class of serious offenses; they may be in the class of offenses entailing confession; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong conduct. …
pācittiyāpattikkhandhena.example_2: siyā pārājikāpattikkhandhena, siyā thullaccayāpattikkhandhena, siyā pācittiyāpattikkhandhena, siyā dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena.
pācittiyāpattikkhandhena.translation_2: they may be in the class of offenses entailing expulsion; they may be in the class of serious offenses; they may be in the class of offenses entailing confession; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong conduct.

aṭṭhapaccayavārā.meaning_2: section on the eight (supporting) conditions; chapter dealing with eightfold causal relations
aṭṭhapaccayavārā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'aṭṭhapaccayavārā' refers to the completed sections or chapters in a grammatical or doctrinal text that discuss the eight paccaya (supporting conditions or causal factors), likely from Buddhist philosophy or Pāḷi grammar, where 'vārā' indicates subdivisions or treatises.
aṭṭhapaccayavārā.translation_1: The eight sections on “as a result of” are finished.

soḷasamahāvārā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Mahāvibhaṅga (a section of the Vinaya Piṭaka), soḷasamahāvārā refers to the sixteen major divisions or chapters that have been completed, as indicated by the sentence structure.
soḷasamahāvārā.translation_1: The sixteen great sections in The Great Analysis are finished.

bhikkhuvibhaṅgamahāvāro.meaning_2: great section of the Monks’ Analysis
bhikkhuvibhaṅgamahāvāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound functioning as a title for the major division of the monks' disciplinary rules in the Vinaya Piṭaka, as indicated by the concluding sentence.
bhikkhuvibhaṅgamahāvāro.translation_1: The great section of the Monks’ Analysis is finished.

puthujjanakalyāṇikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'puthujjanakalyāṇikā' describes 'puthujjana' as 'good' or 'virtuous ordinary people', contrasting with 'sekkhā' (trainees). It is a descriptive compound where 'kalyāṇikā' qualifies ordinary persons who are ethically positive but not yet advanced in spiritual training.
puthujjanakalyāṇikā.translation_1: They are the trainees and the good ordinary people.

arahantiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'arahantiyo sikkhitasikkhā' refers to the perfected ones (arahants) who have trained in the training, emphasizing their status as fully enlightened beings free from defilements.

vuṭṭhāpentiyā.meaning_1: raises up; causes to stand up
vuṭṭhāpentiyā.meaning_2: ordains; gives full admission (to a nun)
vuṭṭhāpentiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, vuṭṭhāpentiyā is the instrumental feminine singular of the present participle vuṭṭhāpentī, meaning 'by one who is giving full admission' or 'for giving full admission'. It refers specifically to the act of ordaining a woman into the Bhikkhunī Saṅgha, which is heavily regulated with numerous conditions as seen in the provided sentences.
vuṭṭhāpentiyā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing suspension for giving the full admission to a female criminal. Where was it laid down?”
vuṭṭhāpentiyā.translation_2: “There is an offense entailing confession for giving the full admission to a pregnant woman. Where was it laid down?”

osārentiyā.meaning_2: fulfilling; satisfying; consenting; consenting to; agreeing with
osārentiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'osārentiyā' refers to the act of obtaining or fulfilling the consent of the gaṇa (community), indicating agreement or satisfaction with the community's decision in the formal readmission procedure for the nun.
osārentiyā.example_1: samaggena saṅghena ukkhittaṃ bhikkhuniṃ dhammena vinayena satthusāsanena anapaloketvā kārakasaṅghaṃ anaññāya gaṇassa chandaṃ osārentiyā saṅghādiseso kattha paññattoti?
osārentiyā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing suspension for readmitting a nun who had been ejected by a unanimous Sangha in accordance with the Teaching, the Monastic Law, and the Teacher’s instruction, without first getting permission from the Sangha that did the legal procedure and without the consent of the community. Where was it laid down?”

uyyojentiyā.grammar: fem, abl sg of uyyojentika, from uyyojeti
uyyojentiyā.meaning_2: by (the act of) dismissal; by sending away; by urging on; by instigation
uyyojentiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya contexts, 'uyyojentiyā' functions as an ablative of instrument indicating the manner or means of the offense, specifically through the act of urging or inciting nuns to behave in a certain way, such as accepting food directly or socializing against rules, leading to suspension (saṅghādiseso).
uyyojentiyā.example_1: iṅgha, ayye, yaṃ te eso purisapuggalo deti khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ vā, taṃ tvaṃ sahatthā paṭiggahetvā khāda vā bhuñja vā”ti uyyojentiyā saṅghādiseso kattha paññattoti?
uyyojentiyā.example_2: mā tumhe nānā viharitthā”ti uyyojentiyā yāvatatiyaṃ samanubhāsanāya na paṭinissajjantiyā saṅghādiseso kattha paññattoti?

arabbhāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'kaṃ arabbhāti?', the word arabbhāti functions as an interrogative expression meaning 'Whom is it about?' or 'What is the object of reference?', where 'kaṃ' is the accusative singular of the interrogative pronoun 'ka' (who/what), and arabbhāti indicates the starting point or subject matter.

ussayacori.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'ussayacori' describes a person characterized by litigiousness and thievery, likely a female criminal prone to disputes or lawsuits, as 'ussaya' relates to piling up or accumulation, here implying contentious piling of arguments or claims.
ussayacori.translation_1: “Litigious, a criminal, the next inhabited area,

bhājāpentiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya sentence, 'bhājāpentiyā' is an instrumental singular feminine form of the present participle 'bhājāpetvā' (absolutive), indicating the action of causing the distribution of the robe-cloth after determining it as in-season, which entails the nissaggiya pācittiya offense.
bhājāpentiyā.example_1: akālacīvaraṃ “kālacīvaran”ti adhiṭṭhahitvā bhājāpentiyā nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
bhājāpentiyā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing relinquishment and confession for determining out-of-season robe-cloth as ‘in-season’, and then distributing it. Where was it laid down?”

cetāpesuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'cetāpesuṃ' describes the act of nuns exchanging a designated Sangha requisite for another item, indicating an improper trade or barter of communal property.
cetāpesuṃ.example_1: sambahulā bhikkhuniyo aññadatthikena parikkhārena aññuddisikena saṅghikena aññaṃ cetāpesuṃ, tasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ.
cetāpesuṃ.translation_1: A number of nuns exchanging for something else a requisite belonging to the Sangha that was designated for a specific purpose.
cetāpesuṃ.example_2: sambahulā bhikkhuniyo aññadatthikena parikkhārena aññuddisikena saṅghikena saññācikena aññaṃ cetāpesuṃ, tasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ.
cetāpesuṃ.translation_2: A number of nuns exchanging for something else a requisite belonging to the Sangha that was designated for a specific purpose and was asked for.

aññadatthi.meaning_2: other view; different opinion; specific purpose
aññadatthi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'cetāpetvā aññadatthi', it refers to exchanging or substituting with another view or purpose, suggesting a deliberate shift to a different perspective or intent.
aññadatthi.translation_1: Getting in exchange, a specific purpose,

catukkaṃsaḍḍhateyyakāti.construction: catu + kaṃsa + aḍḍha + teyya + ka + iti
catukkaṃsaḍḍhateyyakāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound phrase used in a commercial or transactional context, likely from Vinaya texts on monastic economy, specifying a payment or value in ancient Indian currency units. 'Kaṃsa' refers to a bronze or copper coin, 'aḍḍha' means half, and 'teyya' means three, so 'aḍḍhateyyaka' denotes two-and-a-half (half plus three). The ending 'ti' quotatively closes the expression.

saṃharāpentiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, saṃharāpentiyā specifically refers to the act of removing hair from the private parts, which entails a pācittiya offense. The form is the instrumental singular feminine of the present participle of the causative saṃharāpeti, indicating the action causing the offense.
saṃharāpentiyā.example_1: sambādhe lomaṃ saṃharāpentiyā pācittiyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
saṃharāpentiyā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing confession for removing hair from the private parts. Where was it laid down?”

saṃharāpesuṃ.meaning_2: removed; caused to remove (hair from private parts)
saṃharāpesuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In this Vinaya context, saṃharati specifically means 'to remove' or 'to pluck' hair, as in depilation of body hair from private areas, which was prohibited for nuns. The form is 3rd plural aorist causative, indicating the action of causing removal.
saṃharāpesuṃ.example_1: chabbaggiyā bhikkhuniyo sambādhe lomaṃ saṃharāpesuṃ, tasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ.
saṃharāpesuṃ.translation_1: The nuns from the group of six removing hair from their private parts.

atirekadvaṅgulapabbaparamaṃ.meaning_2: more than two finger joints; (in context) exceeding the limit of two finger joints when cleaning with water
atirekadvaṅgulapabbaparamaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this adverbial accusative form specifies the prohibited extent of insertion during water-based cleaning, entailing confession if exceeded; it combines 'atireka' (excess) with 'dvaṅgulapabbaparamaṃ' (at most two finger joints).
atirekadvaṅgulapabbaparamaṃ.example_1: atirekadvaṅgulapabbaparamaṃ udakasuddhikaṃ ādiyantiyā pācittiyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
atirekadvaṅgulapabbaparamaṃ.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing confession for cleaning oneself with water by inserting more than two finger joints. Where was it laid down?”
atirekadvaṅgulapabbaparamaṃ.example_2: atirekadvaṅgulapabbaparamaṃ udakasuddhikaṃ ādiyantī dve āpattiyo āpajjati.
atirekadvaṅgulapabbaparamaṃ.translation_2: When cleaning herself with water by inserting more than two finger joints, she commits two kinds of offenses:

upatiṭṭhantiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, upatiṭṭhantiyā is the instrumental singular feminine of the present participle upatiṭṭhantī, referring to a female attendant (likely a nun or laywoman) who is serving or attending to the eating monk with water or a fan, as prohibited in the Vinaya rule.
upatiṭṭhantiyā.example_1: bhikkhussa bhuñjantassa pānīyena vā vidhūpanena vā upatiṭṭhantiyā pācittiyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
upatiṭṭhantiyā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing confession for attending on a monk who is eating with drinking water or a fan. Where was it laid down?”

upatiṭṭhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, upatiṭṭhi refers to the act of a nun attending or standing by to serve a monk who is eating, specifically by providing drinking water (pānīyena) or fanning (vidhūpanena).
upatiṭṭhi.example_1: aññatarā bhikkhunī bhikkhussa bhuñjantassa pānīyena ca vidhūpanena ca upatiṭṭhi, tasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ.
upatiṭṭhi.translation_1: A certain nun attending on a monk who is eating with drinking water or a fan.

ekenekāya.grammar: card, fem instr sg of eka
ekenekāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the provided Vinaya contexts, 'ekenekāya' functions as an adverbial compound meaning 'alone with one (woman)', emphasizing solitary interaction in prohibited situations. The form is a dvandva-like construction where 'ekena' (masc instr sg) refers to the woman and 'ekāya' (fem instr sg) underscores the singularity, though the core sense derives from 'ekāya' as the feminine instrumental.
ekenekāya.example_1: rattandhakāre appadīpe purisena saddhiṃ ekenekāya santiṭṭhantiyā pācittiyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
ekenekāya.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing confession for standing alone with a man in the dark of the night without a lamp. Where was it laid down?”
ekenekāya.example_2: paṭicchanne okāse purisena saddhiṃ ekenekāya santiṭṭhantiyā pācittiyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
ekenekāya.translation_2: “There is an offense entailing confession for standing alone with a man in a concealed place. Where was it laid down?”

santiṭṭhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the contextual sentences, santiṭṭhi functions as a present indicative 3sg form equivalent to santiṭṭhāti, describing a nun standing alone with a man in various locations such as darkness, concealed places, open areas, streets, cul-de-sacs, and intersections, often implying potentially compromising situations in Vinaya contexts.
santiṭṭhi.example_1: aññatarā bhikkhunī rattandhakāre appadīpe purisena saddhiṃ ekenekā santiṭṭhi, tasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ.
santiṭṭhi.translation_1: A certain nun standing alone with a man in the dark of the night without a lamp.
santiṭṭhi.example_2: aññatarā bhikkhunī paṭicchanne okāse purisena saddhiṃ ekenekā santiṭṭhi, tasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ.
santiṭṭhi.translation_2: A certain nun standing alone with a man in a concealed place.

theyyasatthake.meaning_2: group of traveling thieves; caravan of robbers
theyyasatthake.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term refers to a band or caravan of thieves in the context of Vinaya rules prohibiting association with such groups during travel, as indicated by the English gloss.
theyyasatthake.translation_1: … (as in the rule on a group of traveling thieves) …
theyyasatthake.translation_2: … (as in the rule on a group of traveling thieves) …

abhinisīdantiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, abhinisīdantiyā functions as a present participle in the instrumental case (feminine, agreeing with an implied bhikkhunī or the act itself), indicating the action of sitting down without permission, which constitutes the pācittiya offense.
abhinisīdantiyā.example_1: pacchābhattaṃ kulāni upasaṅkamitvā sāmike anāpucchā āsane abhinisīdantiyā pācittiyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
abhinisīdantiyā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing confession for visiting families after the meal and then sitting down on a seat without asking permission of the owners. Where was it laid down?”
abhinisīdantiyā.example_2: vikāle kulāni upasaṅkamitvā sāmike anāpucchā seyyaṃ santharitvā vā santharāpetvā vā abhinisīdantiyā pācittiyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
abhinisīdantiyā.translation_2: “There is an offense entailing confession for visiting families at the wrong time, putting out bedding without asking permission of the owners, or having it put out, and then sitting down. Where was it laid down?”

ujjhāpentiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, ujjhāpentiyā describes the act of complaining or murmuring against another due to misunderstanding (duggahitena) and lack of reflection (dūpadhāritena), leading to a pācittiya offense. The form is feminine instrumental singular, likely agreeing with a feminine noun implied or elided in the phrase.
ujjhāpentiyā.example_1: duggahitena dūpadhāritena paraṃ ujjhāpentiyā pācittiyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
ujjhāpentiyā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing confession for complaining about someone because of a misunderstanding and a lack of proper reflection. Where was it laid down?”

abhisapantiyā.meaning_2: cursing; reviling; referring to something to curse
abhisapantiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'abhisapantiyā' is the instrumental singular feminine of the present participle, referring to the act of cursing by invoking hell (niraya) or the holy life (brahmacariya), which constitutes a pācittiya offense. The word likely derives from abhi + √sap (to curse or revile), distinct from unrelated entries like 'bhisa' or 'panti'.
abhisapantiyā.example_1: attānaṃ vā paraṃ vā nirayena vā brahmacariyena vā abhisapantiyā pācittiyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
abhisapantiyā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing confession for referring to hell or the spiritual life to curse oneself or someone else. Where was it laid down?”

nahānavaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound used as a title for a section in the Vinaya text. The sentence indicates the completion of the third such subchapter, with 'tatiyo' specifying its position.
nahānavaggo.translation_1: The third subchapter on bathing is finished.
nahānavaggo.translation_2: The third subchapter on bathing is finished.

tuvaṭṭesuṃ.meaning_2: to lie down or sleep together (in pairs)
tuvaṭṭesuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form tuvaṭṭesuṃ is 3rd plural imperfect indicative active, describing nuns lying down in pairs on the same bed or under the same cover in the vinaya context, indicating close proximity or shared sleeping arrangements.
tuvaṭṭesuṃ.example_1: sambahulā bhikkhuniyo dve ekamañce tuvaṭṭesuṃ, tasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ.
tuvaṭṭesuṃ.translation_1: A number of nuns lying down in pairs on the same bed.
tuvaṭṭesuṃ.example_2: sambahulā bhikkhuniyo dve ekattharaṇapāvuraṇā tuvaṭṭesuṃ, tasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ.
tuvaṭṭesuṃ.translation_2: A number of nuns lying down in pairs on the same sheet and under the same cover.

nikkaḍḍhantiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, nikkaḍḍhantiyā describes the action of angrily ejecting or throwing out a bhikkhunī from her assigned upassaya (dwelling place), resulting in a pācittiya offense for the one who does so.
nikkaḍḍhantiyā.example_1: bhikkhuniyā upassayaṃ datvā kupitāya anattamanāya nikkaḍḍhantiyā pācittiyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
nikkaḍḍhantiyā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing confession for giving a dwelling place to a nun, and then, in anger, throwing her out. Where was it laid down?”

pariyāpuṇantiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence, it is used in the feminine dative singular form pariyāpuṇantiyā, referring to a nun who is studying forbidden worldly knowledge (tiracchānavijjaṃ), entailing a pācittiya offense.
pariyāpuṇantiyā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing confession for studying worldly subjects. Where was it laid down?”

maccharāyi.meaning_2: kept to herself; was possessive towards
maccharāyi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, maccharāyi describes the action of a nun selfishly keeping a family or household to herself, implying possessiveness or stinginess, typical in Vinaya contexts of monastic misconduct.
maccharāyi.example_1: aññatarā bhikkhunī kulaṃ maccharāyi, tasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ.
maccharāyi.translation_1: A certain nun keeping a family to herself.

ruhitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Form is accusative singular neuter of the past participle, likely functioning adverbially in context as 'having climbed' or 'in a climbed manner'.

bhedāpentiyā.meaning_2: rupturing; causing to break open; causing to split
bhedāpentiyā.construction: √bhid > bhed + ā + pe + ti > bhedāpeti + ya
bhedāpentiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'bhedāpentiyā' is the instrumental singular of the abstract noun derived from the causative verb bhedāpeti ('causes to break'), referring to the act of rupturing or lancing an abscess or wound, which is prohibited without permission.
bhedāpentiyā.example_1: pasākhe jātaṃ gaṇḍaṃ vā rudhitaṃ vā anapaloketvā saṅghaṃ vā gaṇaṃ vā purisena saddhiṃ ekenekāya bhedāpentiyā pācittiyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
bhedāpentiyā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing confession for being alone with a man and having him rupture an abscess or a wound situated on the lower part of one’s body, without getting permission from the Sangha or a group. Where was it laid down?”

anuggaṇhāpentiyā.meaning_2: causing to help; causing to guide; causing to support
anuggaṇhāpentiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'anuggaṇhāpentiyā' refers to the act of causing someone (likely a senior nun) to guide or support the newly admitted disciple over the two-year period. This is part of the prohibition against neglecting guidance after admission, entailing confession if violated. The form is feminine instrumental singular of the present participle of the causative anuggaṇhāpeti, derived from anuggaṇhāti ('to help, guide').
anuggaṇhāpentiyā.example_1: sahajīviniṃ vuṭṭhāpetvā dve vassāni neva anuggaṇhantiyā na anuggaṇhāpentiyā pācittiyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
anuggaṇhāpentiyā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing confession for giving the full admission to a disciple, and then, for the next two years, neither guiding her nor having her guided. Where was it laid down?”

nānubandhantiyā.grammar: prp of nānubandhati, instr sg fem
nānubandhantiyā.meaning_1: not following; not keeping close to; not attending closely
nānubandhantiyā.meaning_2: not following; not keeping close to; not attending closely; not pursuing
nānubandhantiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'nānubandhantiyā' refers to the act of not following or not staying with the mentor (upajjhāya) who granted full ordination (upasampadā), which is specified as entailing confession (pācittiya) if neglected for two years. This usage emphasizes the disciplinary obligation in the Vinaya to maintain close association with one's teacher during the probationary period.
nānubandhantiyā.example_1: vuṭṭhāpitaṃ pavattiniṃ dve vassāni nānubandhantiyā pācittiyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
nānubandhantiyā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing confession for not following the mentor who gave one the full admission for two years. Where was it laid down?”

nānubandhiṃsu.meaning_2: did not follow; did not trail; did not bind after
nānubandhiṃsu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, it describes a number of nuns who, for two years, did not follow or adhere to the guidance of their mentor (pavattinī) who had given them full admission (vuṭṭhāpitaṃ), indicating a breach in the training process in this Vinaya case.
nānubandhiṃsu.example_1: sambahulā bhikkhuniyo vuṭṭhāpitaṃ pavattiniṃ dve vassāni nānubandhiṃsu, tasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ.
nānubandhiṃsu.translation_1: A number of nuns not following the mentor who gave them the full admission for two years.

vūpakāsentiyā.meaning_2: not sending away; not causing to be sent away
vūpakāsentiyā.construction: vi + upa + kāse + ent + i + yā
vūpakāsentiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, vūpakāsentiyā refers to the act of not dismissing or expelling a nun who has been given full ordination, forming part of the offense description for pācittiya.
vūpakāsentiyā.example_1: sahajīviniṃ vuṭṭhāpetvā neva vūpakāsentiyā na vūpakāsāpentiyā pācittiyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
vūpakāsentiyā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing confession for giving the full admission to a disciple, and then neither sending her away nor having her sent away. Where was it laid down?”

vūpakāsāpentiyā.meaning_1: having ... sent away; causing to send away
vūpakāsāpentiyā.meaning_2: causing to send away; having sent away
vūpakāsāpentiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'vūpakāsāpentiyā' is the instrumental singular feminine of the present participle, referring to the act of causing a disciple to be sent away. It parallels 'vūpakāsentiyā', the direct sending away, in the rule about not dismissing a probationer properly, which incurs a pācittiya offense.
vūpakāsāpentiyā.example_1: sahajīviniṃ vuṭṭhāpetvā neva vūpakāsentiyā na vūpakāsāpentiyā pācittiyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
vūpakāsāpentiyā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing confession for giving the full admission to a disciple, and then neither sending her away nor having her sent away. Where was it laid down?”

yāyiṃsu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'yāyiṃsu' describes the action of the group of six nuns traveling in a vehicle (yānena), indicating past movement or journey to the location of the case (tasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ).
yāyiṃsu.example_1: chabbaggiyā bhikkhuniyo yānena yāyiṃsu, tasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ.
yāyiṃsu.translation_1: The nuns from the group of six traveling in a vehicle.

ummaddāpentiyā.meaning_2: causing to be mad; causing to rub or massage
ummaddāpentiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, ummaddāpentiyā refers to a female agent causing madness or performing a rubbing/massaging action, paralleling parimaddāpentiyā which explicitly means 'rubbing oneself'. The term is used in dative case to indicate the agent providing the service, entailing a pācittiya offense for the recipient.
ummaddāpentiyā.example_1: bhikkhuniyā ummaddāpentiyā parimaddāpentiyā pācittiyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
ummaddāpentiyā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing confession for having a nun massage or rub oneself. Where was it laid down?”
ummaddāpentiyā.example_2: sikkhamānāya ummaddāpentiyā parimaddāpentiyā pācittiyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
ummaddāpentiyā.translation_2: “There is an offense entailing confession for having a trainee nun massage or rub oneself. Where was it laid down?”

parimaddāpentiyā.meaning_2: having someone massage or rub oneself
parimaddāpentiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a feminine dative singular form of the present participle of parimaddāpeti (causative of parimaddati), used in the Vinaya context to indicate the agent causing the action of massaging or rubbing, entailing a pācittiya offense for various categories of women performing or receiving such services.
parimaddāpentiyā.example_1: bhikkhuniyā ummaddāpentiyā parimaddāpentiyā pācittiyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
parimaddāpentiyā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing confession for having a nun massage or rub oneself. Where was it laid down?”
parimaddāpentiyā.example_2: sikkhamānāya ummaddāpentiyā parimaddāpentiyā pācittiyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
parimaddāpentiyā.translation_2: “There is an offense entailing confession for having a trainee nun massage or rub oneself. Where was it laid down?”

ummaddāpesuṃ.meaning_2: caused to be excited; made mad; caused to be massaged
ummaddāpesuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'ummaddāpesuṃ' is used with an instrumental agent (e.g., bhikkhuniyā) to mean 'caused [someone] to massage/rub them', indicating the nuns had the agent perform the action of massaging on them. The root 'mad' typically means 'to be drunk, excited, or mad', but here it idiomatically denotes physical massaging or rubbing, as reflected in the English translations.
ummaddāpesuṃ.example_1: sambahulā bhikkhuniyo bhikkhuniyā ummaddāpesuṃ parimaddāpesuṃ, tasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ.
ummaddāpesuṃ.translation_1: A number of nuns having a nun massage and rub them.
ummaddāpesuṃ.example_2: sambahulā bhikkhuniyo sikkhamānāya ummaddāpesuṃ parimaddāpesuṃ, tasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ.
ummaddāpesuṃ.translation_2: A number of nuns having a trainee nun massage and rub them.

parimaddāpesuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the contextual sentences, parimaddāpesuṃ causativally indicates that the subject (nuns) caused another party (e.g., a nun, trainee, novice, or laywoman) to massage and rub them, as reflected in the English translations.
parimaddāpesuṃ.example_1: sambahulā bhikkhuniyo bhikkhuniyā ummaddāpesuṃ parimaddāpesuṃ, tasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ.
parimaddāpesuṃ.translation_1: A number of nuns having a nun massage and rub them.
parimaddāpesuṃ.example_2: sambahulā bhikkhuniyo sikkhamānāya ummaddāpesuṃ parimaddāpesuṃ, tasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ.
parimaddāpesuṃ.translation_2: A number of nuns having a trainee nun massage and rub them.

asaṅkacchikāya.meaning_2: without doubt; without hesitation; without uncertainty
asaṅkacchikāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a bahuvrīhi compound meaning 'one who has no doubt' (a-saṅkā) + 'having eyes' or 'perforated' (acchikā), used in instrumental singular feminine to describe something or someone free from doubt and possessing clear vision or insight.

navavaggakhuddakā.meaning_2: minor rules in nine subchapters; minor section with nine chapters
navavaggakhuddakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound noun refers to the concluding section of a Vinaya text, specifically the Khuddakavaggas or minor rules organized into nine vaggas (chapters or subchapters), as indicated by the sentence 'The section on minor rules in nine subchapters is finished.' The form is nominative plural, agreeing with an implied neuter plural noun like sikkhāpada (training rules).
navavaggakhuddakā.translation_1: The section on minor rules in nine subchapters is finished.

talamaṭṭhañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form talamaṭṭhañca is a sandhi combination of 'tala' (palm) + 'maṭṭha' (cleaned, polished) + 'ca' (and), functioning as an adverbial phrase in the list. In this Vinaya context, 'tala' likely refers to the palm of the hand used for cleaning, and 'maṭṭha' indicates the cleaned or prepared state, with the English translation suggesting a specific application possibly involving intimate cleaning or tools.

bhuñjantāmakadhaññānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in genitive plural form, indicating 'of those who are eating raw grains' or 'of the eating of raw grains', fitting the contextual translation.

duggahi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'duggahi niraye vadhi', duggahi means 'misunderstood' or 'grasped wrongly', leading to the consequence of beating in hell, highlighting the negative outcome of misunderstanding.

naggodakā.meaning_2: water for (washing) the naked; water used when one is unclothed
naggodakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'naggodakā visibbetvā', the term refers to water used in a procedure involving nudity, likely for ablution or purification where the person is naked. 'Visibbetvā' indicates having spread out or unstitched (perhaps robes or cloth), suggesting a monastic context where one undresses and uses this water.

saṅkamanīyaṃ.meaning_2: to be taken on loan; to be borrowed (for five days)
saṅkamanīyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'pañcāhikaṃ saṅkamanīyaṃ' refers to something permissible to borrow or take on loan for a period of five days, likely related to monastic rules on temporary use of items.

vibhaṅgasamaṇaṃ.meaning_2: monastic community; community of ascetics; distribution of monks
vibhaṅgasamaṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'gaṇaṃ vibhaṅgasamaṇaṃ', this compound likely refers to the monastic community or the distribution/allocation of monks within the saṅgha, aligning with 'distribution, monastic' in the English rendering.

ekamañcattharaṇena.meaning_2: with the same bed and with the same sheet
ekamañcattharaṇena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the compound 'ekamañcattharaṇa', used in context to denote sharing the identical bed and sheet, emphasizing equivalence or singularity in monastic living arrangements.
ekamañcattharaṇena.translation_1: With the same bed, and with the same sheet,

saṃsaṭṭhaanto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form saṃsaṭṭhaanto appears to be a sandhi variant or scribal error for saṃsaṭṭhānto, a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as an adverbial preposition meaning 'within' or 'inside', derived from saṃsaṭṭha (mixed with, associated with) and anta (end, inside). In the context of the sentence, it modifies the action of giving or socializing, indicating location or involvement 'within' a group or association.

tirovassaṃ.grammar: ind, adv, acc sg of tirovassa
tirovassaṃ.meaning_2: during the rainy season; in the monsoon
tirovassaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'tirovassaṃ na pakkame', it functions adverbially to specify the time ('during the rainy season') when the subject should not go out, aligning with the English translation 'Outside, rainy season, should she not go.' The form is an accusative adverbial phrase indicating temporal extent.
tirovassaṃ.translation_1: Outside, rainy season, should she not go.

cīvarāvasathaṃ.meaning_2: robe and lodging; robe-cloth and dwelling
cīvarāvasathaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'dade cīvarāvasathaṃ' (Should she give robe, lodging), the compound functions as a neuter accusative singular object, denoting the combined items to be given, specifically robe-cloth and lodging as provisions.

vācaye.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'pariyāpuṇañca vācaye', this is the 3rd person singular imperative form, directing a female subject to teach what has been learned, as indicated by the English translation 'And learning, should she teach'.

ārāmakkosacaṇḍī.meaning_2: furious in abusing a monastery; hostile with insults towards the monastery
ārāmakkosacaṇḍī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound where ārāma (monastery) is qualified by akkosa (abusing) and caṇḍī (fierce, fem form agreeing with an implied feminine noun like bhikkhunī), indicating a person aggressively insulting the monastery, as per the contextual translation.

pavāraṇovādaṃ.meaning_2: invitation to instruction; exhortation inviting correction
pavāraṇovādaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentence, pavāraṇovādaṃ functions as the object of vāse, indicating the act of spending the rains retreat in a manner that invites correction or instruction from the community, likely tied to the post-vassa invitation ceremony where faults are addressed.
pavāraṇovādaṃ.translation_1: Should she spend, inviting correction, instruction,

asammatūnadvādasa.meaning_1: One who has not been approved, less than twelve
asammatūnadvādasa.meaning_2: not approved and less than twelve; unapproved and deficient by twelve
asammatūnadvādasa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive sandhi compound functioning adjectivally, likely modifying a noun like bhikkhu in Vinaya context, referring to a monk who has not received formal approval (asammata) and whose number is short of the required twelve, as in quorum or assembly requirements.
asammatūnadvādasa.translation_1: One who has not been approved, less than twelve;

dvevassaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'dvevassaṃ' refers to a period of two years or two rains retreats, as in the probationary training for ordination. The accusative form is used as the object in the sentence indicating duration.
dvevassaṃ.translation_1: Enough, and if, for two years,
dvevassaṃ.translation_2: Two years’ training, by the Sangha,

pārivāsikānuvassaṃ.meaning_2: annually for the probationer; expired every year
pārivāsikānuvassaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is an accusative adverbial compound functioning as an indeclinable, modifying the probation period in the context of annual expiration or renewal during the rainy season in Vinaya regulations.

chattayānena.meaning_2: sunshade in a vehicle; sunshade on a carriage; parasol on a wagon
chattayānena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form chattayānena is the instrumental singular of the compound chattayāna, denoting 'by/with the sunshade in/on a vehicle'. The English translation interprets it as a sunshade attached to or part of a vehicle, aligning with the contextual uses in Vinaya lists of monastic requisites or ornaments. The base chatta (nt, 'sunshade') combines with yāna (nt, 'vehicle') to form a descriptive tatpuruṣa compound.
chattayānena.translation_1: Sunshade, in a vehicle, hip ornament,

itthālaṅkāravaṇṇake.meaning_2: jewelry with colors; colored feminine ornaments; beauty products for women
itthālaṅkāravaṇṇake.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term appears in locative singular, denoting a category or context of 'jewelry with colors,' likely referring to ornamental items for women that involve coloration, such as painted or dyed accessories, aligning with the English gloss.

piññākabhikkhunī.meaning_2: nun who eats sesame paste; nun (in context of sesame paste)
piññākabhikkhunī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound is a descriptive tatpuruṣa, likely indicating a nun associated with sesame paste, as per the English translation 'Sesame paste, and a nun'. In Vinaya contexts, such compounds often refer to specific cases or offenses involving the mentioned items.

lasuṇandhakārā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'lasuṇandhakārā nhānā', this compound appears to function as a descriptive noun in the ablative or locative case, likely referring to 'garlic in the darkness' or 'dark garlic', possibly in a ritual or prohibitive bathing context. The English translation suggests 'Garlic, the dark, bathing,' indicating a fragmented or list-like structure where the compound modifies the action of bathing.

cittagārakā.meaning_2: gallery; lying down place; mind house
cittagārakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word appears in a list or enumeration context ('tuvaṭṭā cittagārakā'), where 'tuvaṭṭā' means 'lying down' and 'cittagārakā' is glossed as 'gallery'. This suggests a architectural or monastic term for a gallery or raised walkway used for reclining or resting, literally 'small mind-house' as a diminutive compound. The form is likely an indeclinable or special plural indicating types or instances.

madhuñceva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form 'madhuñceva' is a sandhi combination of 'madhu' (honey) + 'ñca' (and, variant of 'ca' before vowel) + 'eva' (and). In the context of the sentence listing substances, it functions as 'and honey' enumerating ghee, oil, and honey together.

dadhiñcāpi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form 'dadhiñcāpi' results from sandhi where the inherent 'i' of 'api' combines with the preceding 'ca' to produce 'ñca', functioning as an emphatic conjunction 'and even' or 'also', listing curd alongside meat and milk in the context of prohibited items.

viññāpetvāna.meaning_2: having informed; having made known; having announced
viññāpetvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'viññāpetvāna bhikkhunī', this absolutive form indicates that the nun has informed or requested something prior to the main action, fitting the English 'A nun asked for—' as an act of making a formal request or announcement.

vuṭṭhāpentī.meaning_2: causes to stand up; gives full admission (to a nun)
vuṭṭhāpentī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, vuṭṭhāpentī specifically refers to the act of a senior nun formally admitting or ordaining a sikkhamāna (trainee) into full upasampadā as a bhikkhunī, often incurring offenses if done improperly due to the candidate's qualifications or circumstances.
vuṭṭhāpentī.translation_1: When giving the full admission to a female criminal, she commits three kinds of offenses:
vuṭṭhāpentī.translation_2: When giving the full admission to a pregnant woman, she commits two kinds of offenses:

osārentī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'osārentī' is a feminine nominative singular present participle referring to the nun who, without proper permission and consent, proceeds to satisfy or fulfill the consent of the group, thereby committing offenses in the readmission procedure.
osārentī.example_1: samaggena saṅghena ukkhittaṃ bhikkhuniṃ dhammena vinayena satthusāsanena anapaloketvā kārakasaṅghaṃ anaññāya gaṇassa chandaṃ osārentī tisso āpattiyo āpajjati.
osārentī.translation_1: When readmitting a nun who had been ejected by a unanimous Sangha in accordance with the Teaching, the Monastic Law, and the Teacher’s instruction, without first getting permission from the Sangha that did the legal procedure and without the consent of the community, she commits three kinds of offenses:

uyyojentī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'uyyojentī' describes a nun actively urging or inciting another nun to engage in inappropriate actions, such as accepting food directly from a man or socializing excessively, leading to offenses. The form is feminine nominative singular present participle, agreeing with the subject (a nun).
uyyojentī.example_1: “kiṃ te, ayye, eso purisapuggalo karissati avassuto vā anavassuto vā, yato tvaṃ anavassutā. iṅgha, ayye, yaṃ te eso purisapuggalo deti khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ vā, taṃ tvaṃ sahatthā paṭiggahetvā khāda vā bhuñja vā”ti uyyojentī tisso āpattiyo āpajjati.
uyyojentī.translation_1: When urging a nun on, saying, “Venerable, what can this man do to you, whether he has lust or not, if you’re without? Go on, venerable, receive it with your own hands and then eat whatever fresh or cooked food he gives you,” she commits three kinds of offenses:
uyyojentī.example_2: “saṃsaṭṭhāva, ayye, tumhe viharatha. mā tumhe nānā viharitthā”ti uyyojentī yāvatatiyaṃ samanubhāsanāya na paṭinissajjantī tisso āpattiyo āpajjati.
uyyojentī.translation_2: When urging the nuns on, saying, “Venerables, you should socialize. Don’t live separately,” and not stopping when pressed for the third time, she commits three kinds of offenses:

bhājāpentī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, bhājāpentī refers to the act of a bhikkhunī distributing (or causing to be distributed) robe-cloth that has been improperly determined as in-season, resulting in two offenses. The form is feminine present participle nominative singular, agreeing with the implied bhikkhunī.
bhājāpentī.example_1: akālacīvaraṃ “kālacīvaran”ti adhiṭṭhahitvā bhājāpentī dve āpattiyo āpajjati.
bhājāpentī.translation_1: When determining out-of-season robe-cloth as “in-season”, and then distributing it, she commits two kinds of offenses:

saṃharāpentī.meaning_1: causing to draw together; causing to fold up; causing to contract
saṃharāpentī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, saṃharāpentī describes the action of a nun contracting or removing hair (lomaṃ) from the private parts (sambādhe), which incurs two offenses. The form is feminine nominative singular present participle, indicating the subject performing the action.
saṃharāpentī.example_1: sambādhe lomaṃ saṃharāpentī dve āpattiyo āpajjati.
saṃharāpentī.translation_1: When removing hair from the private parts, she commits two kinds of offenses:

saṃharāpite.meaning_2: having removed; having put away; having folded up
saṃharāpite.construction: sam + √har > saṃ + hṛ > saṃhar + ā + ite
saṃharāpite.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, saṃharāpite indicates the action of removing or putting away an article (likely clothing or covering), after which the confession offense is committed.
saṃharāpite.translation_1: when she has removed it, she commits an offense entailing confession.

upatiṭṭhantī.meaning_2: attending; standing by; serving; waiting upon
upatiṭṭhantī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'upatiṭṭhantī' refers to a female (nuns or laywomen) attending or serving a monk who is eating, by providing drinking water or fanning, which leads to two offenses under Vinaya rules prohibiting such direct service by women to monks.
upatiṭṭhantī.example_1: bhikkhussa bhuñjantassa pānīyena vā vidhūpanena vā upatiṭṭhantī dve āpattiyo āpajjati.
upatiṭṭhantī.translation_1: When attending on a monk who is eating with drinking water or a fan, she commits two kinds of offenses:

abhinisīdantī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The present participle abhinisīdantī describes the action of sitting down after arranging bedding without permission, completing the second offense in the sequence of actions.
abhinisīdantī.example_1: vikāle kulāni upasaṅkamitvā sāmike anāpucchā seyyaṃ santharitvā vā santharāpetvā vā abhinisīdantī dve āpattiyo āpajjati.
abhinisīdantī.translation_1: When visiting families at the wrong time, putting out bedding without asking permission of the owners, or having it put out, and then sitting down, she commits two kinds of offenses:

ujjhāpentī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, ujjhāpentī describes a female (likely a nun) who is complaining or finding fault with another due to misunderstanding, resulting in two offenses. The form is feminine nominative singular present participle of the causative ujjhāpeti.
ujjhāpentī.example_1: duggahitena dūpadhāritena paraṃ ujjhāpentī dve āpattiyo āpajjati.
ujjhāpentī.translation_1: When complaining about someone because of a misunderstanding and a lack of proper reflection, she commits two kinds of offenses:

abhisapantī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, abhisapantī is the feminine present participle used with a female subject (implied 'she'), meaning 'cursing' or 'uttering a curse'. The sentence describes a bhikkhunī committing offenses by cursing with reference to hell (niraya) or the holy life (brahmacariya), affecting oneself (attānaṃ) or another (paraṃ). The form ends in -antī, indicating feminine nominative singular present participle.
abhisapantī.example_1: attānaṃ vā paraṃ vā nirayena vā brahmacariyena vā abhisapantī dve āpattiyo āpajjati.
abhisapantī.translation_1: When referring to hell or the spiritual life to curse oneself or someone else, she commits two kinds of offenses:

nikkaḍḍhantī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, nikkaḍḍhantī describes the act of angrily expelling a nun from her dwelling place, leading to two offenses. The form is feminine nominative singular present participle, agreeing with bhikkhunī implied as the subject.
nikkaḍḍhantī.example_1: bhikkhuniyā upassayaṃ datvā kupitā anattamanā nikkaḍḍhantī dve āpattiyo āpajjati.
nikkaḍḍhantī.translation_1: When giving a dwelling place to a nun, and then, in anger, throwing her out, she commits two kinds of offenses:

pariyāpuṇantī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, pariyāpuṇantī refers to a female studying worldly knowledge (tiracchānavijjaṃ), resulting in two offenses, indicating a present participle form of the verb used as a gerundial construction.
pariyāpuṇantī.translation_1: When studying worldly subjects, she commits two kinds of offenses:

akkosite.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, akkosite refers to the act of verbal abuse or reviling, which, when completed by a bhikkhuni, entails a pācittiya offense requiring confession.
akkosite.translation_1: when she is finished abusing, she commits an offense entailing confession.

maccharite.meaning_2: stinginess; avarice; greediness in keeping things for oneself
maccharite.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'maccharite' is the locative singular of 'maccharita', indicating the state of being stingy or miserly. The sentence describes a bhikkhunī who, out of this stinginess, keeps an item meant for sharing for herself, resulting in a pācittiya offense requiring confession.
maccharite.translation_1: when she has kept it for herself, she commits an offense entailing confession.

bhedāpentī.meaning_2: having (someone) rupture; causing to break open
bhedāpentī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, bhedāpentī describes a nun causing a man to rupture or break open an abscess or wound on her lower body, implying a medical or invasive act without permission, leading to offenses.
bhedāpentī.example_1: pasākhe jātaṃ gaṇḍaṃ vā rudhitaṃ vā anapaloketvā saṅghaṃ vā gaṇaṃ vā purisena saddhiṃ ekenekā bhedāpentī dve āpattiyo āpajjati.
bhedāpentī.translation_1: When being alone with a man and having him rupture an abscess or a wound situated on the lower part of her body, without getting permission from the Sangha or a group, she commits two kinds of offenses:

nānuggaṇhāpentī.meaning_2: not causing to be guided; not having guided
nānuggaṇhāpentī.construction: na > an + anu + gaṇhā + e + nti
nānuggaṇhāpentī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, this feminine present participle describes the bhikkhunī who, after giving full admission to a disciple, fails to provide guidance or arrange for guidance over the next two years, resulting in an offense. The form incorporates the negative prefix na- and the causative extension -āpe- to indicate causing someone else to perform the action of guiding.
nānuggaṇhāpentī.example_1: sahajīviniṃ vuṭṭhāpetvā dve vassāni neva anuggaṇhantī nānuggaṇhāpentī ekaṃ āpattiṃ āpajjati.
nānuggaṇhāpentī.translation_1: When giving the full admission to a disciple, and then, for the next two years, neither guiding her nor having her guided, she commits one kind of offense:

nānubandhantī.meaning_2: not following; not keeping close to; not attending closely
nānubandhantī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, nānubandhantī refers to a female probationer (pavattinī) not adhering to or staying with her mentor (vuṭṭhāpita) for the required two years after full admission, resulting in an offense (āpatti).
nānubandhantī.example_1: vuṭṭhāpitaṃ pavattiniṃ dve vassāni nānubandhantī ekaṃ āpattiṃ āpajjati.
nānubandhantī.translation_1: When not following the mentor who gave her the full admission for two years, she commits one kind of offense:

vūpakāsentī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, vūpakāsentī refers to the act of sending away a bhikkhunī, likely from the community or seclusion, contrasting with the offense of failing to do so after her upasampadā admission.
vūpakāsentī.example_1: sahajīviniṃ vuṭṭhāpetvā neva vūpakāsentī na vūpakāsāpentī ekaṃ āpattiṃ āpajjati.
vūpakāsentī.translation_1: When giving the full admission to a disciple, and then neither sending her away nor having her sent away, she commits one kind of offense:

vūpakāsāpentī.meaning_2: causing to send away; having sent away
vūpakāsāpentī.construction: vi + upa + kāse + āp + e + ti
vūpakāsāpentī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'vūpakāsāpentī' is the feminine nominative singular present participle, indicating the subject (a female) who causes the sending away of the disciple but fails to do so, contributing to the offense described.
vūpakāsāpentī.example_1: sahajīviniṃ vuṭṭhāpetvā neva vūpakāsentī na vūpakāsāpentī ekaṃ āpattiṃ āpajjati.
vūpakāsāpentī.translation_1: When giving the full admission to a disciple, and then neither sending her away nor having her sent away, she commits one kind of offense:

yāyite.meaning_2: to go; to travel; to proceed
yāyite.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'yāyite' is the locative absolute form, indicating the circumstance 'when (she) is traveling' or 'upon traveling', triggering the pācittiya offense.
yāyite.translation_1: when she has traveled, she commits an offense entailing confession.

ummaddāpentī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, ummaddāpentī means causing someone to perform a rubbing or massaging action on the subject, often implying an intimate or prohibited touch, leading to two offenses as specified.
ummaddāpentī.example_1: bhikkhuniyā ummaddāpentī parimaddāpentī dve āpattiyo āpajjati.
ummaddāpentī.translation_1: When having a nun massage or rub her, she commits two kinds of offenses:
ummaddāpentī.example_2: sikkhamānāya ummaddāpentī parimaddāpentī dve āpattiyo āpajjati.
ummaddāpentī.translation_2: When having a trainee nun massage or rub her, she commits two kinds of offenses:

parimaddāpentī.meaning_2: causing to massage; causing to rub
parimaddāpentī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the feminine nominative singular present participle of the causative parimaddāpeti, meaning 'having [someone] massage or rub [her]'. In the Vinaya context, it describes the action of a bhikkhunī causing another female (nun, trainee, novice, or laywoman) to perform the massage, resulting in two offenses.
parimaddāpentī.example_1: bhikkhuniyā ummaddāpentī parimaddāpentī dve āpattiyo āpajjati.
parimaddāpentī.translation_1: When having a nun massage or rub her, she commits two kinds of offenses:
parimaddāpentī.example_2: sikkhamānāya ummaddāpentī parimaddāpentī dve āpattiyo āpajjati.
parimaddāpentī.translation_2: When having a trainee nun massage or rub her, she commits two kinds of offenses:

ummaddite.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'ummaddite' is the locative singular feminine of the past participle 'ummadditā', indicating a state of being 'when mad' or 'when deranged'. The English translation 'when she has gotten massaged' appears to be a misinterpretation, as 'ummaddita' relates to madness (from ud + mad), not massage (which would derive from √mas or similar). The rule likely prohibits certain actions for a bhikkhuni who is mentally afflicted.
ummaddite.translation_1: when she has gotten massaged, she commits an offense entailing confession.
ummaddite.translation_2: when she has gotten massaged, she commits an offense entailing confession.

saṅgahavāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'saṅgahavāro' refers to the fourth chapter or section of the text, titled 'Classification' or 'Grouping,' which has just been completed. The English translation's 'classes of offenses in each offense' appears to be an interpretive rendering of the structure being classified within this section.
