saṅgahavāro.translation_1: The classes of offenses in each offense, the fourth, are finished.
saṅgahavāro.translation_2: The classes of offenses in each offense, the fourth, are finished.

pāṭidesanīyāpattikkhandhena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This instrumental form is used in the Vinaya context to denote membership in the category of pāṭidesanīya offenses, as in 'they may be in the class of offenses entailing acknowledgment.' It appears in lists classifying potential offenses across various categories.
pāṭidesanīyāpattikkhandhena.translation_1: they may be in the class of offenses entailing acknowledgment; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong conduct. …
pāṭidesanīyāpattikkhandhena.translation_2: they may be in the class of offenses entailing acknowledgment; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong conduct.

sādiyanapaccayā.meaning_1: because of consent; due to consenting
sādiyanapaccayā.meaning_2: consent as a condition; by reason of acceptance
sādiyanapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental adverbial phrase meaning 'by reason of consent' or 'due to consenting,' used in Vinaya contexts to describe the condition leading to offenses involving physical contact (kāyasaṃsagga). It modifies the offenses as their causal basis.
sādiyanapaccayā.example_1: yaṃ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena kāyasaṃsaggaṃ sādiyanapaccayā pārājikaṃ kattha paññattaṃ?
sādiyanapaccayā.translation_1: “The offense entailing expulsion that is a result of consenting to physical contact was laid down by the Buddha who knows and sees, the Perfected One, the fully Awakened One. Where was it laid down?
sādiyanapaccayā.example_2: yaṃ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena kāyasaṃsaggaṃ sādiyanapaccayā pārājikaṃ kattha paññattanti?
sādiyanapaccayā.translation_2: “The offense entailing expulsion that is a result of consenting to physical contact was laid down by the Buddha who knows and sees, the Perfected One, the fully Awakened One. Where was it laid down?”

vajjappaṭicchādanapaccayā.meaning_2: on account of concealing an offense; due to the condition of covering up a fault
vajjappaṭicchādanapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an ablative form used adverbially in instrumental-ablative sense, common in Pāli for expressing cause or reason ('due to' or 'on account of'). In the Vinaya context, it refers to offenses arising from the act of concealing a monk's fault, specifically leading to four types of offenses including a pārājika.
vajjappaṭicchādanapaccayā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing expulsion that is a result of concealing an offense. Where was it laid down?”
vajjappaṭicchādanapaccayā.translation_2: How many kinds of offenses does one commit as a result of concealing an offense?

paripūraṇapaccayā.grammar: ind, adv, in comps, abl sg of paripūraṇapaccaya
paripūraṇapaccayā.meaning_2: dependent on fulfilling; as a result of completing; due to accomplishing
paripūraṇapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'paripūraṇapaccayā' functions adverbially to indicate that the offenses (pārājika and others) arise as a direct result of fulfilling the eight parts (aṭṭhamaṃ vatthuṃ) of the case, emphasizing the complete set of conditions required for the rule's application.
paripūraṇapaccayā.example_1: aṭṭhamaṃ vatthuṃ paripūraṇapaccayā pārājikaṃ kattha paññattanti?
paripūraṇapaccayā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing expulsion that is a result of fulfilling the eight parts. Where was it laid down?”
paripūraṇapaccayā.example_2: aṭṭhamaṃ vatthuṃ paripūraṇapaccayā kati āpattiyo āpajjati?
paripūraṇapaccayā.translation_2: How many kinds of offenses does she commit as a result of fulfilling the eight parts?

vuṭṭhāpanapaccayā.meaning_2: supporting condition of giving higher ordination; requisite of full admission
vuṭṭhāpanapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this instrumental compound specifically refers to the condition arising from ordaining a female criminal (coriṃ), leading to saṅghādisesa offenses and three āpattiyo, as per the sentences. It combines the act of higher ordination with the causal support, emphasizing the prohibitive nature in monastic rules.
vuṭṭhāpanapaccayā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing suspension that is a result of giving the full admission to a female criminal. Where was it laid down?”
vuṭṭhāpanapaccayā.translation_2: As a result of giving the full admission to a female criminal, she commits three kinds of offenses:

gamanapaccayā.grammar: ind, adv, in comps, abl sg of gamanapaccaya
gamanapaccayā.meaning_2: dependent on going; due to walking; caused by journeying
gamanapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given Vinaya context, 'gamanapaccayā' functions adverbially to indicate the condition or reason ('due to') for the offense, specifically the act of walking alone to another village, which results in suspension or three offenses.
gamanapaccayā.example_1: ekā gāmantaraṃ gamanapaccayā saṅghādiseso kattha paññattoti?
gamanapaccayā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing suspension that is a result of walking to the next inhabited area by oneself. Where was it laid down?”
gamanapaccayā.example_2: ekā gāmantaraṃ gamanapaccayā tisso āpattiyo āpajjati.
gamanapaccayā.translation_2: As a result of walking to the next inhabited area by herself, she commits three kinds of offenses:

osāraṇapaccayā.grammar: ind, adv, in comps, abl sg of osāraṇapaccaya
osāraṇapaccayā.meaning_2: as a result of readmission; due to the condition of reinstatement
osāraṇapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this adverbial form indicates the causal condition under which the offense of saṅghādisesa is incurred, specifically through the act of readmitting a suspended nun without proper authorization. It combines 'osāraṇa' (reinstatement) with 'paccayā' (due to condition), emphasizing the procedural violation.
osāraṇapaccayā.example_1: samaggena saṅghena ukkhittaṃ bhikkhuniṃ dhammena vinayena satthusāsanena anapaloketvā kārakasaṅghaṃ anaññāya gaṇassa chandaṃ osāraṇapaccayā saṅghādiseso kattha paññattoti?
osāraṇapaccayā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing suspension that is a result of readmitting a nun who had been ejected by a unanimous Sangha in accordance with the Teaching, the Monastic Law, and the Teacher’s instruction, without first getting permission from the Sangha that did the legal procedure and without the consent of the community. Where was it laid down?”
osāraṇapaccayā.example_2: samaggena saṅghena ukkhittaṃ bhikkhuniṃ dhammena vinayena satthusāsanena anapaloketvā kārakasaṅghaṃ anaññāya gaṇassa chandaṃ osāraṇapaccayā tisso āpattiyo āpajjati.
osāraṇapaccayā.translation_2: As a result of readmitting—without first getting permission from the Sangha that did the legal procedure and without the consent of the community—a nun who had been ejected by a unanimous Sangha in accordance with the Teaching, the Monastic Law, and the Teacher’s instruction, she commits three kinds of offenses:

bhuñjanapaccayā.grammar: ind, adv, in comps, abl sg of bhuñjanapaccaya
bhuñjanapaccayā.meaning_2: as a result of eating; due to eating
bhuñjanapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'bhuñjanapaccayā' functions adverbially to indicate the causal condition or result arising from the act of eating, as seen in phrases describing offenses 'bhuñjanapaccayā' (as a result of eating), linking the consumption of food to the commission of specific pācittiya or saṅghādisesa rules.
bhuñjanapaccayā.example_1: avassutāya bhikkhuniyā avassutassa purisapuggalassa hatthato khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ vā sahatthā paṭiggahetvā bhuñjanapaccayā saṅghādiseso kattha paññattoti?
bhuñjanapaccayā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing suspension that is a result of a lustful nun eating fresh or cooked food after receiving it directly from a lustful man. Where was it laid down?”
bhuñjanapaccayā.example_2: dadhiṃ viññāpetvā bhuñjanapaccayā pāṭidesanīyaṃ kattha paññattanti?
bhuñjanapaccayā.translation_2: “There is an offense entailing acknowledgment that is a result of asking for curd and then eating it. Where was it laid down?”

uyyojanapaccayā.grammar: ind, adv, in comps, abl sg of uyyojanapaccaya
uyyojanapaccayā.meaning_2: dependent on urging; due to persuasion; as a result of incitement
uyyojanapaccayā.construction: ud + yoje + ana + pati > paty > pacc + √i > ay + *a + ā
uyyojanapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this instrumental ablative adverbial phrase specifies the condition under which the saṅghādisesa offense or three āpattiyo are committed, referring to the act of persuading or inciting a nun to accept food from a man, as in the quoted speech.
uyyojanapaccayā.example_1: “kiṃ te, ayye, eso purisapuggalo karissati avassuto vā anavassuto vā, yato tvaṃ anavassutā. iṅgha, ayye, yaṃ te eso purisapuggalo deti khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ vā taṃ tvaṃ sahatthā paṭiggahetvā khāda vā bhuñja vā”ti uyyojanapaccayā saṅghādiseso kattha paññattoti?
uyyojanapaccayā.translation_1: “There is an offense entailing suspension that is a result of urging a nun on, saying, ‘Venerable, what can this man do to you, whether he has lust or not, if you’re without? Go on, venerable, receive it with your own hands and then eat whatever fresh or cooked food he gives you.’ Where was it laid down?”
uyyojanapaccayā.example_2: “kiṃ te, ayye, eso purisapuggalo karissati avassuto vā anavassuto vā, yato tvaṃ anavassutā. iṅgha, ayye, yaṃ te eso purisapuggalo deti khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ vā taṃ tvaṃ sahatthā paṭiggahetvā khāda vā bhuñja vā”ti, uyyojanapaccayā tisso āpattiyo āpajjati.
uyyojanapaccayā.translation_2: As a result of urging a nun on, saying, “Venerable, what can this man do to you, whether he has lust or not, if you’re without? Go on, venerable, receive it with your own hands and then eat whatever fresh or cooked food he gives you,” she commits three kinds of offenses:

tamhe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of the demonstrative pronoun 'ta', used to refer to a group of masculine or neuter entities in context.

bhedakānuvattikā.meaning_2: she who sides with a schismatic; nun who follows a monk pursuing schism
bhedakānuvattikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this feminine form refers to a bhikkhunī who supports a bhedaka (schismatic monk) and refuses to desist after three admonitions, leading to saṅghādisesa offense. The compound combines 'bhedaka' (schism-causer) with 'anuvattikā' (feminine of anuvattaka, meaning follower or sider-with).
bhedakānuvattikā.example_1: bhedakānuvattikā bhikkhunī yāvatatiyaṃ samanubhāsanāya na paṭinissajjati, āpatti saṅghādisesassa;
bhedakānuvattikā.translation_1: when a nun sides with a monk who is pursuing schism and she does not stop when pressed for the third time, she commits an offense entailing suspension;

saṅghādisesāpattikkhandhena.meaning_2: class of offenses entailing suspension; group of transgressions requiring involvement of the community from start to finish
saṅghādisesāpattikkhandhena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This instrumental singular form appears in lists enumerating possible categories of monastic offenses in the Vinaya, indicating that certain actions or items 'may be in the class of offenses entailing suspension,' highlighting its role in classifying disciplinary matters within the saṅgha.
saṅghādisesāpattikkhandhena.example_1: siyā pārājikāpattikkhandhena, siyā saṅghādisesāpattikkhandhena, siyā thullaccayāpattikkhandhena, siyā pācittiyāpattikkhandhena, siyā dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena …pe….
saṅghādisesāpattikkhandhena.translation_1: they may be in the class of offenses entailing expulsion; they may be in the class of offenses entailing suspension; they may be in the class of serious offenses; they may be in the class of offenses entailing confession; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong conduct. …
saṅghādisesāpattikkhandhena.example_2: siyā pārājikāpattikkhandhena, siyā saṅghādisesāpattikkhandhena, siyā thullaccayāpattikkhandhena, siyā pācittiyāpattikkhandhena, siyā dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena.
saṅghādisesāpattikkhandhena.translation_2: they may be in the class of offenses entailing expulsion; they may be in the class of offenses entailing suspension; they may be in the class of serious offenses; they may be in the class of offenses entailing confession; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong conduct.

imassānantaraṃ.meaning_2: immediately after this; straight after that
imassānantaraṃ.construction: ima + ssa + an + anta + ra + aṃ
imassānantaraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This adverbial compound combines the genitive/dative pronoun 'imassa' (of this/to this) with 'anantaraṃ' (immediately after), indicating temporal immediacy following the referenced event or thing. Commonly used in narrative sequences to denote succession without interval.

tesamuddānaṃ.meaning_2: their summary; table of contents for them
tesamuddānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound form where 'tesaṃ' (genitive plural of 'ta', meaning 'of them/their') modifies 'uddānaṃ' (neuter accusative singular, meaning 'summary' or 'table of contents'). In Pāḷi texts, such compounds often refer to the summary or index pertaining to a specific set of items, like chapters or sections.

kativāro.meaning_2: how many times?; how many occasions?; how many instances?
kativāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound kativāro functions as an interrogative pronoun in the masculine nominative singular, questioning the number of occurrences or repetitions, likely derived from the primary sense of vāra as 'occasion' or 'instance'.

paññattivārena.meaning_2: by means of designation; by way of naming; by conceptual attribution
paññattivārena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the tatpuruṣa compound paññattivāra, where paññatti (designation, concept) is qualified by vāra (turn, way). In philosophical contexts, this often refers to 'by way of convention' or 'by mere naming', contrasting with ultimate reality (paramattha). Without the specific sentence, the interpretation is based on common Pāli usage in Abhidhamma and commentarial literature.

aṭṭhavārātiiti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form aṭṭhavārātiiti appears to be a sandhi-affected version of 'aṭṭhavārāti iti', where 'iti' delimits the phrase, common in Pāḷi commentaries for quoting terms. 'Aṭṭhavāra' likely refers to a collection or section of eight items, such as verses or topics in texts like the Aṭṭhakathā.

paccayavārā.meaning_2: section on conditions; section on supporting factors
paccayavārā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'paccayavārā' refers to the eight chapters or sections in a grammatical or doctrinal text that deal with 'paccaya' (conditions or dependencies), concluding the discussion on how elements support or condition each other, as indicated by the translation 'sections on “as a result of”'.
paccayavārā.translation_1: The eight sections on “as a result of” are finished.

mahāvārā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'mahāvārā' refers to the major structural divisions or chapters in the Bhikkhunivibhaṅga, specifically numbering sixteen, as indicated by the completion of the nuns' analysis section in the Vinaya Piṭaka.
mahāvārā.translation_1: The sixteen great sections of the Nuns’ Analysis are finished.

samuṭṭhānasīsasaṅkhepo.meaning_2: summary of the origination of offenses; brief account of the causes of offenses
samuṭṭhānasīsasaṅkhepo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound noun serves as a title or heading for a section concluding the discussion on the causes or origins of monastic offenses in the Vinaya context, where 'sīsa' indicates a heading or lead, and 'saṅkhepa' a summary.
samuṭṭhānasīsasaṅkhepo.translation_1: The origination of offenses is finished.

samuṭṭhānassuddānaṃ.meaning_2: of the summary of the origins
samuṭṭhānassuddānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound formed by samuṭṭhānassa (genitive singular of samuṭṭhāna 'origin') + uddānassa (genitive singular of uddāna 'summary'), with double genitive sandhi resulting in -ssuddānaṃ. Likely a title or heading in a Pāli text, referring to a list or table of contents concerning origins or causes.

dukkhānattā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, dukkhānattā is the ablative form used instrumentally to express the reason or nature 'because of being suffering and nonself'. The English translation condenses the compound as 'suffering, nonself', referring to the first two of the three marks of existence (dukkha, anattā, saṅkhatā).

nibbānañceva.meaning_2: and indeed the description of extinguishment; and indeed nibbāna as a concept
nibbānañceva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form nibbānañceva results from sandhi where the inherent -a of nibbāna contracts with ca to -añca, followed by eva. In the context, it emphasizes nibbāna as a descriptive concept or designation (paññatti), aligning with the English translation 'Indeed the description extinguishment'.

buddhacande.meaning_2: Buddha moon; moon of the Buddha; metaphorical reference to the Buddha's appearance
buddhacande.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'buddhacande anuppanne' refers to the time before the Buddha's arising or manifestation in the world, likened to the moon not having risen, emphasizing the darkness or lack of enlightenment prior to his appearance.
buddhacande.translation_1: When the Buddha moon has not appeared,

buddhādicce.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, buddhādicce refers to the 'Buddha-sun' metaphorically, and the locative case with anuggate indicates 'when it has not yet risen,' symbolizing the time before the Buddha's enlightenment or teaching dawns.
buddhādicce.translation_1: When the Buddha sun has not yet risen;

sabhāgadhammānaṃ.meaning_2: mental states or phenomena that are of the same kind or nature; shared qualities or characteristics
sabhāgadhammānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given context, 'sabhāgadhammānaṃ' (genitive plural) refers to shared or similar mental phenomena, explaining why their specific names become unknown when the distinction is lost.
sabhāgadhammānaṃ.translation_1: Then even the name is not known,

pūrayitvāna.meaning_2: having filled; having completed; having fulfilled
pūrayitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'pūrayitvāna pāramī' means 'having fulfilled the perfections', where 'pūrayitvāna' is a variant of 'pūretvāna' indicating completion of the pāramī (perfections) prior to the main action.

dukkhahāniṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, dukkhahāniṃ functions as the object of the implied verb, describing something that terminates or removes suffering (dukkha), thereby leading to happiness (sukhāvahaṃ). The accusative singular ending -iṃ indicates the direct object in Pāḷi.
dukkhahāniṃ.translation_1: That ends suffering and brings happiness;

suttantamabhidhammañca.meaning_2: the discourses and the higher doctrine; the Suttanta and Abhidhamma
suttantamabhidhammañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Sandhi form combining accusative singular suttantaṃ (nt, discourse) with accusative singular abhidhammaṃ (masc, higher doctrine) and the conjunction ca (and). In context, it refers to the second and third baskets of the Tipiṭaka, following the Vinaya mentioned earlier in the verse.

mahāguṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'vinayañca mahāguṇaṃ', mahāguṇaṃ functions as a predicate nominative agreeing with vinaya, describing the Monastic Law as possessing great quality or virtue.
mahāguṇaṃ.translation_1: And the Monastic Law, of great quality.

vibhaṅgāni.meaning_2: analysis; division; classification; section (of the Sutta Piṭaka)
vibhaṅgāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'ubhato ca vibhaṅgāni', it refers to both Analyses, likely the two Vibhaṅga sections in the Tipiṭaka (Dhammasaṅgaṇī and its counterpart in Abhidhamma), translated as 'both Analyses'.

suttaguṇeneva.meaning_2: with a thread; by means of a string; bound with a cord
suttaguṇeneva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'mālā suttaguṇeneva' meaning 'A garland bound', the compound suttaguṇa refers to a thread or string used for binding the garland, with sutta likely denoting 'thread' (from √siv, lit. thread) and guṇa meaning 'string' or 'cord'. The instrumental case -ena indicates the means of binding.

caññaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form caññaṃ appears to be a sandhi compound or fused form combining 'ca' (and) and 'aññaṃ' (other, accusative singular neuter), possibly referring to an additional or different item in a list or context. Without the full sentence, the exact usage is inferred from dictionary entries as a grammatical or enumerative term.

terasasamuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: origination due to thirteen (causes); arising from thirteen
terasasamuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'terasa' (thirteen) modifies 'samuṭṭhāna' (origination), indicating origin or arising from thirteen elements or causes, common in doctrinal contexts like listing thirteen types of something.

sañcarittānubhāsanañca.meaning_2: matchmaking and pressing; matchmaking and speaking; carrying proposals and talk
sañcarittānubhāsanañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound formed by sañcaritta (matchmaking, lit. 'going between') + anu (prefix indicating following or along) + bhāsana (speech, talk) + ca (and). The English translation 'Matchmaking and pressing' likely interprets anubhāsana as 'pressing' in the sense of persuasive speaking or urging in the context of matchmaking proposals. In Vinaya contexts, this may refer to intermediaries facilitating marriages through discussions or negotiations.

padasodhammo.meaning_2: memorizing the Teaching; (lit.) holding the Teaching word by word
padasodhammo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'padasodhammo' refers to the practice of memorizing the Buddha's Teaching by committing it to memory line by line or word by word, a key method of preserving and internalizing the doctrine in early Buddhist tradition, as contrasted with 'lomāni' (wool), possibly symbolizing material concerns.

theyyadesanacorī.meaning_2: female thief who teaches (or teaches theft)
theyyadesanacorī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound interpreting as 'female thief of teaching' or 'thief who teaches', likely in the context of a criminal woman involved in thieving and instructing others, as per the English translation 'Thieves, teaching, and female criminal'. The compound lists three related vices or categories in the Vinaya context.

terasete.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the phrase 'terasete samuṭṭhāna', 'terasete' functions as a demonstrative ordinal referring to the thirteen modes or originations previously mentioned, equivalent to 'these thirteen' in English.

paṭhamapārājikasamuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: origination of the first päräjika offense; arising of the first expulsion entailing defeat
paṭhamapārājikasamuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, the term refers to the causes or origins related to the first päräjika rule in the Vinaya, with 'niṭṭhitaṃ' indicating the completion of this section.
paṭhamapārājikasamuṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: Originations like the first offense entailing expulsion are finished.

sukkasaṃsaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, sukkasaṃsaggo refers to intimate contact or association involving semen, specifically denoting sexual intercourse as a prohibited act in monastic discipline.

paṭhamikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'paṭhamikā' modifies 'aniyatā', referring to the first of the undetermined offenses (aniyatā-pācittiya), which are ambiguous cases requiring adjudication by the Sangha.

pubbūpaparipācitā.meaning_2: arrived before and prepared; having previously prepared
pubbūpaparipācitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a feminine nominative singular past participle in a compound construction, describing something (likely feminine) that arrived earlier and made preparations, aligning with the contextual translation 'Arrived before, had prepared'.

tepaññāsā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'tepaññāsā ca sekhiyā', it refers to the fifty-three training rules (sekhiyā) in the Pāḷi Vinaya, feminine nominative plural agreeing with sekhiyā.

adhakkhagāmāvassutā.meaning_2: flooded with vulgar lust below the collar-bone
adhakkhagāmāvassutā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form adhakkhagāmāvassutā is a descriptive compound interpreting avassutā as 'flooded with' (lust) that is gāmā (vulgar or village-related), with adhakkha specifying the location below the collar-bone, likely in a context of bodily or metaphorical impurity involving lust.
adhakkhagāmāvassutā.translation_1: Below the collar bone, village, lustful,

dutiyapārājikasamuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: origination of the second defeat offense; arising of the second expulsion transgression
dutiyapārājikasamuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative singular form of the compound noun, used as the object in the sentence indicating completion of the section on the origination of the second Pārājika offense in the Vinaya context.
dutiyapārājikasamuṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: Originations like the second offense entailing expulsion are finished.

viggahuttari.meaning_2: in a superior form; in a higher form
viggahuttari.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'adinnaṃ viggahuttari', it modifies 'adinnaṃ' (not given), indicating the not-giving occurs in a superior or higher form, possibly contrasting with a base or ordinary form in a grammatical or analytical resolution sense.

attakāminaṃ.meaning_2: selfish; desirous of one's own benefit; pursuing personal desires
attakāminaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'duṭṭhullā attakāminaṃ', the word describes someone indecent or coarse in pursuing selfish needs, likely in an accusative sense modifying an implied object. The form attakāminaṃ is accusative singular masculine, with attakāmī as the base adjective meaning one who desires for oneself, combining 'atta' (self) and 'kāmī' (desirous).

omasapesuṇā.meaning_2: falsely; abusively, maliciously; with divisive talebearing
omasapesuṇā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form omasapesuṇā is an adverbial compound derived from omasa (abusive) and pesuṇā (feminine form of pesuṇa, divisive speech), used in the context of the sentence to describe false, abusive, and slanderous speech as a triad of vices.

pathavīkhaṇe.meaning_2: digging of the earth; act of digging the ground
pathavīkhaṇe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya rule, 'pathavīkhaṇe' refers to the act of digging the earth, which is prohibited for monks as a grave offense, likely to prevent harm to living beings in the soil.
pathavīkhaṇe.translation_1: Grave offense, should he dig the earth,

siñcanañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'siñcanañca' refers to the act of sprinkling or pouring, likely in a ritual or purificatory sense, paired with 'throwing out' as actions related to disposal or cleansing.

ūnasaṃvāsanāsanā.meaning_2: expulsion for inadequate participation in formal meetings; lesser ban; suspension from community activities
ūnasaṃvāsanāsanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound noun in the Vinaya context refers to a specific monastic penalty where a monk is partially restricted, such as being barred from full participation in group formalities (saṃvāsa) due to deficiency (ūna), leading to a form of expulsion or removal (nāsana) from communal rights. The English gloss 'Less than, doing formal meetings with, expulsion' captures the tripartite structure, indicating a lighter form of excommunication compared to full asaṃvāsa.
ūnasaṃvāsanāsanā.translation_1: Less than, doing formal meetings with, expulsion;

duggahī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'duggahī nirayena ca' translates as 'because of misunderstanding, and with hell,' indicating that faulty comprehension leads to hellish consequences. The form duggahī is an agent noun (kṛdanta) in -ī, denoting one who grasps wrongly, hence 'misunderstanding' as a process or state.
duggahī.translation_1: Because of misunderstanding, and with hell.

kathināphāsupassayaṃ.meaning_2: dwelling place of ill ease in the robe season
kathināphāsupassayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound interpreting as 'kathina (robe season) + a-phāsu (ill ease) + passaya (dwelling place)', matching the English gloss. The form is accusative singular, likely the object in context describing a place of discomfort during the kathina period.
kathināphāsupassayaṃ.translation_1: Robe season, ill at ease, dwelling place;

akkosacaṇḍī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, this compound adjective describes a person characterized by verbal abuse and fierce temperament, as indicated by the English glosses 'abuse, furious'.

gihīgatā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya, 'gihīgatā' refers to girls who have entered the state of being householders, i.e., married into lay life, as opposed to those who remain unmarried or enter monastic life.

ūnadvādasasammatā.meaning_2: less than twelve; without approval; not approved as having twelve
ūnadvādasasammatā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound ūnadvādasasammatā functions as an adjective describing a group or assembly that is deficient in the required number of twelve members and thus lacks the approval or authorization for validity, as per the contextual translation 'Less than twelve, without approval.' This likely refers to quorum requirements in monastic proceedings.

anuvassā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'chandā anuvassā ca dve', anuvassā functions adverbially to indicate recurrence, modifying the numeral 'dve' (two), meaning two instances every year, likely referring to annual observances or duties in a monastic context.

sattatime.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'sattatime' refers to the locative case indicating the group or set of seventy training rules (sikkhāpadāni), as in 'among the seventy training rules' or 'the seventy training rules'.

kāyacittena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in contexts indicating origin or means, as in 'from body and mind' or 'produced from body and mind', contrasting with speech (vācā/vācato).
kāyacittena.translation_1: From body and mind, not from speech,
kāyacittena.translation_2: Or from body and mind, not from speech;

vācācittaṃ.meaning_2: speech and mind; from speech and mind
vācācittaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'vācācittaṃ na kāyikaṃ' contrasts mental and verbal actions with physical ones, indicating something arising from speech and mind rather than body.
vācācittaṃ.translation_1: Or from speech and mind, not from body;

sañcarittasamuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, it refers to the origins or cases arising from the offense of sañcaritta (matchmaking or carrying proposals), marking the completion of their discussion in a Vinaya text.
sañcarittasamuṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: Originations like the offense for matchmaking are finished.

viññattuttari.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, viññattuttari functions adverbially, modifying the infinitive abhihaṭṭhuṃ 'to take', indicating the manner of taking as 'asking for more than (what was offered)'. It combines the abstract noun viññatti 'request, solicitation' with the adverb uttari 'more than, further', forming a descriptive adverbial phrase common in Pāḷi to express excess in requests.
viññattuttari.translation_1: Asking, invites to take more than,

ūnabandhanavassikā.meaning_2: newly ordained with fewer than five mends; having less than five repairs, rainy season
ūnabandhanavassikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In Vinaya context, this term designates a monk who has been ordained for less than five rainy seasons (vassa), where 'bandhana' refers to mends or repairs to robes, indicating insufficient experience or qualifications for certain monastic roles.
ūnabandhanavassikā.translation_1: Fewer than five mends, rainy season,

dvāradānasibbāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a neuter plural compound noun listing three categories in the Vinaya context: doors (dvāra), gifts or acts of giving (dāna), and sewing or tailoring (sibbāni, from sīvati 'to sew'). The English translation reflects these as separate items connected by 'and'.

dvāradānasibbinī.meaning_2: having sutures that are a gift of the door; suture of the gateway of giving
dvāradānasibbinī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound interpreting 'dvāra' as the door or entrance, 'dāna' as the act of giving, and 'sibbinī' as sutures, possibly metaphorical in a doctrinal or anatomical context referring to cranial sutures or conceptual 'stitches' at the gateway of generosity.

pūvapaccayajoti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound listing three items: pūva (a type of cake or pastry), paccaya (requisite or supporting condition), and joti (fire), as indicated by the English translation 'Cookie, requisite, and fire.' The form ends in -joti, suggesting a masculine interpretation of joti in this context, and the entire expression functions as a nominal list in the sentence.

nisīdanakaṇḍu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a dvandva compound connecting 'nisīdana' (sitting mat) and 'kaṇḍu' (itch), listed as one of three items in the Pāḷi sentence alongside 'tūlaṃ' (cotton down), likely enumerating monastic requisites or prohibitions in a Vinaya context.
nisīdanakaṇḍu.translation_1: Cotton down, sitting mat, and itch;

puggalalahukā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'puggalalahukā garu', this compound functions as a masculine nominative singular adjective or noun, paired with 'garu' (heavy) to contrast lightness and heaviness in relation to an individual or person, likely in a doctrinal or metaphorical sense such as light vs. heavy karma or burden.

samapaññāsime.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'samapaññāsime' modifies 'dhammā' to specify 'these exactly fifty rules', combining 'sama' (altogether, exactly) with 'paññāsa' (fifty) and 'ime' (these), functioning as a demonstrative pronoun in the locative plural to indicate the precise set of fifty dhammā.

vācācittā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular feminine form used in the compound to indicate 'from speech and mind' in contrast to 'from body', as seen in the sentences where it modifies the action or origin.
vācācittā.translation_1: From body, not from speech or mind;
vācācittā.translation_2: From speech and mind, not from body;

kāyamanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, kāyamanā is part of the negation na kāyamanā, contrasting with vācato, indicating something arising or originating from speech rather than from the physical body (kāya) or mind (manas). It functions as a descriptive compound emphasizing the bodily or material aspect.
kāyamanā.translation_1: From speech, not from body or mind;

kāyavācā.meaning_2: of body and speech; pertaining to body and speech
kāyavācā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'kāyavācā na ca cittā', the compound adjective kāyavācā modifies an implied noun (likely karmic actions or precepts), indicating they pertain to or originate from the body and speech but exclude the mind, as in physical and verbal actions versus mental ones.
kāyavācā.translation_1: From body and speech, not from mind;
kāyavācā.translation_2: Are from body and speech, not from mind,

kāyacittā.meaning_2: from body and mind; originating from physical and mental aspects
kāyacittā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form used in the sentence to indicate origin or source from both body (physical processes) and mind (thoughts or intentions), contrasting with speech (vācikā). This compound appears in contexts discussing sources of karma or actions in Buddhist texts.
kāyacittā.translation_1: From body and mind, not from speech;

vācikā.meaning_2: of speech; verbal; relating to speech
vācikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'kāyacittā na vācikā', the instrumental form 'vācikā' indicates 'from speech' or 'of speech', contrasting with actions or states originating from body (kāya) and mind (citta). This usage is common in Pāli to denote categories of karma or volition.
vācikā.translation_1: From body and mind, not from speech;

chasamuṭṭhānikā.meaning_2: having six originations; originating from six bases
chasamuṭṭhānikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form chasamuṭṭhānikā is feminine nominative plural, agreeing with an implied feminine noun like dhātuyo ('faculties') or similar. In the context, it describes entities that have six points of origination or arising, likely referring to six bases or causes in doctrinal enumeration.

samanubhāsanāsamuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: origination due to admonishing; arising from stern advising; offense originating from pressing discussion
samanubhāsanāsamuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where samanubhāsanā (admonishing) is the basis for the origination (samuṭṭhāna) in Vinaya context, referring to offenses or cases arising from such actions, as indicated by the sentence concluding their discussion.
samanubhāsanāsamuṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: Originations like the offense on pressing are finished.

bhedānuvattadubbaca.meaning_2: difficult to correct those who side with schism
bhedānuvattadubbaca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound functioning as a masculine noun in the context of Vinaya monastic rules, referring to a person who supports schism and is obstinate, hard to admonish or reform through words.
bhedānuvattadubbaca.translation_1: Schism, those who side with, difficult to correct,

dūsaduṭṭhulladiṭṭhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound used as a karmadhāraya in the context, likely modifying a preceding noun. The English translation 'Corrupter, grave, and view' suggests a list-like interpretation of the components, but in Pāḷi compounds, it functions as a single descriptive term for a type of view that is corrupting, not vulgar, and erroneous, often referring to a specific wrong view in doctrinal contexts.

vajjānuvattigahaṇā.meaning_2: taking sides with offenses; holding onto faults; agreeing with or accepting blame
vajjānuvattigahaṇā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as an abstract noun in the instrumental singular, denoting the act of following and grasping faults or offenses, as indicated by the contextual translation 'Offenses, taking sides with, holding'.

paccācikkhanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, paccācikkhanā refers to the formal act of a monk renouncing or rejecting a false confession or charge, effectively readmitting him to the community after denial, as indicated by the sentence 'osāre paccācikkhanā' meaning 'Should readmit, renouncing.'

anvaddhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'anvaddhaṃ saha jīviniṃ dve', anvaddhaṃ functions adverbially to indicate distribution, likely meaning 'every half (month or period)', with 'saha jīviniṃ dve' referring to two disciples together, suggesting a contextual usage related to periodic or alternating assignment.

kāyavācāya.meaning_2: from body and speech; by body and speech
kāyavācāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the compound noun 'kāyavācā' (body and speech), used in the contexts to indicate origin or instrumentality, as in 'produced from body and speech' or 'from body, speech and mind'. The form in sentence 0 includes 'cittato' (from mind), suggesting an extension to all three doors of action.
kāyavācāya.translation_1: Are from body, speech and mind;
kāyavācāya.translation_2: Or it is produced from body and speech,

kathinasamuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_1: origination arising from the kathina ceremony
kathinasamuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: origination like the offense on the robe-making ceremony; cause due to kathina privileges
kathinasamuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound refers to offenses or cases originating from the kathina ceremony or privileges, as indicated by the sentence 'Originations like the offense on the robe-making ceremony are finished.'
kathinasamuṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: Originations like the offense on the robe-making ceremony are finished.

pattabhesajjaṃ.meaning_2: bowl tonics; medicines received in the bowl; first category of monastic requisites
pattabhesajjaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, pattabhesajjaṃ refers to the first type of medicinal requisites allowed for monks, specifically tonics or medicines obtained in the alms bowl, as opposed to other forms like those stored or applied externally.

vosāsāraññakena.meaning_2: with one who gives directions in the wilderness; with a wilderness instructor
vosāsāraññakena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of a tatpuruṣa compound vosāsāraññaka, formed from the present participle vosāsant (giving directions, commanding) and araññaka (belonging to the wilderness, forest-related). In the context, it likely refers to a person or role involving directing in a wilderness setting, aligning with the sentence's translation 'Giving directions, and with wilderness'.

ussayāsannicayañca.meaning_2: litigiousness and collection; contentious accumulation and hoarding
ussayāsannicayañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form appears to be a sandhi compound 'ussayā + sannicaya + ca', where 'ussayā' is the instrumental singular of 'ussaya' (heap), but in context, 'ussaya' likely functions adjectivally as 'litigious' or 'contentious' (possibly from 'ussada' excellent/superior, or a Vinaya-specific sense of 'quarrelsome'). The English translation 'Litigious, and collection' suggests 'ussaya' conveys a sense of dispute or litigation, paired with 'sannicaya' as accumulation or hoard. The 'ā' ending may indicate an adverbial or connective form in the compound.

saṅkamanī.meaning_2: borrowed thing; item on loan; in context of five days, a temporary loan or borrowing for five days
saṅkamanī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'pañcāhikā saṅkamanī' refers to a borrowing or loan item that is to be returned within five days, as indicated by the English translation 'Five days, borrowed'. The term saṅkamanī is a feminine noun denoting something borrowed or taken on loan, derived from the root √saṅkam (to go to, approach) with the suffix -anī forming a noun of instrument or action.

ekūnakā.grammar: adj, in comps, from eka + ūna
ekūnakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'tiṃsa ekūnakā ime' meaning 'these twenty-nine', ekūnakā functions as a numeral adjective indicating 'one less than thirty', thus denoting twenty-nine.

sahāsamā.meaning_2: equal together; equally accompanied; simultaneously balanced
sahāsamā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sahāsamā appears to be a feminine adjective derived from the combination of saha 'with, together' and samā 'equal, like', suggesting a sense of equality in accompaniment or simultaneous balance. Without provided sentences, the exact contextual usage cannot be specified further, but it likely functions descriptively in compounds.

eḷakalomasamuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: origination based on goats' wool; arising from offense involving goats' fleece
eḷakalomasamuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound refers to the category of monastic offenses originating from or based on goats' wool or fleece, such as prohibitions on using it for robes or other items; the sentence indicates the completion of discussion on such topics.
eḷakalomasamuṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: Originations like the offense on wool are finished.

piṇḍabhojanaṃ.meaning_2: eating an almsmeal; eating alms food
piṇḍabhojanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, piṇḍabhojanaṃ refers to the act of eating food obtained through alms, a common monastic practice in Pāḷi texts. The English translation 'Detachable, eating an almsmeal' appears to include an unrelated word 'Detachable' which may be a mistranslation or error.

gaṇavikālasannidhi.meaning_2: storing a group at the wrong time; group store at improper time
gaṇavikālasannidhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound noun refers to the act or instance of storing or hoarding a group (e.g., monks) during the improper time (vikāla), which in monastic context means the period from noon until dawn when eating or storing food is prohibited. The English translation 'Group, at the wrong time, store' breaks down the components, indicating a violation involving group storage off-hours.
gaṇavikālasannidhi.translation_1: Group, at the wrong time, store,

uyyodhi.grammar: masc, from ud yā + ava dhā
uyyodhi.meaning_2: battle; fight; conflict; army (in battle context)
uyyodhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form uyyodhi appears as a compound noun derived from uyyodhana (act of fighting off) or directly from ud-yā (drive off) and odhi (boundary), metaphorically denoting a battle as a 'boundary of assault' or clash of mobilized forces. In the sentence, it parallels senaṃ (army) and conveys the sense of military engagement or warfare.

nhāyanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'surā orena nhāyanā', it refers to the act of bathing with alcohol, implying a lesser or inadequate form of bathing, possibly in a prohibitive or disciplinary sense in Vinaya texts.

desanikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'desanikā' refers to discourses or teachings, specifically two of them concerning acknowledgment or confession in the Vinaya context of stains (impurities or offenses).

lasuṇupatiṭṭhe.meaning_2: place for attending to garlic; location involving garlic
lasuṇupatiṭṭhe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'lasuṇupatiṭṭhe naccanā', the locative form indicates the context or place where dancing (naccanā) is prohibited, specifically in relation to attending to or handling garlic, likely in a monastic rule context where such activities are restricted.
lasuṇupatiṭṭhe.translation_1: Garlic, should she attend on, dancing.

nhānamattharaṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a neuter noun in the accusative singular, listing items in a monastic context: bathing (facilities or act), sheet (bedding), and sleeping place. The English translation reflects the compound's collective sense in the sentence.

abhikkhukāvāsena.meaning_2: by means of a monastery without monks; by a residence lacking monastics
abhikkhukāvāsena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The instrumental form abhikkhukāvāsena indicates the manner or means, referring to a monastic residence devoid of resident monks, as per the context of an empty monastery.
abhikkhukāvāsena.translation_1: And with a monastery without monks;

gandhavāsitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'alaṅkāraṃ gandhavāsitaṃ', the word describes jewelry that is scented or perfumed, indicating adornments imbued with fragrance.

asaṃkaccikā.meaning_2: without rubbish and flame; free from refuse and fire
asaṃkaccikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a bahuvrīhi compound formed with the negative prefix 'a-', indicating absence of both 'saṃka' (rubbish) and 'accikā' (flame). It may describe something pure or untainted by waste and fire, possibly in a metaphorical sense in Vinaya contexts.

vācācittena.meaning_2: by speech and mind; through speech and mind
vācācittena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the tatpuruṣa compound vācācitta, used in sentences to denote origin or means involving speech and mind, as in 'produced from speech and mind'.
vācācittena.translation_1: Are from body, not from speech or mind,
vācācittena.translation_2: Or they are produced from speech and mind,

eḷakalomikāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound eḷakalomi- refers to wool from goats or sheep, equated in context to ordinary wool (samā ... eḷakalomikāti), likely indicating a type of animal-derived wool used in textiles or monastic robes.

padasodhammasamuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: origination of offenses related to word-by-word recitation of the Teaching
padasodhammasamuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound used in the context of completing sections on disciplinary offenses in the Vinaya, specifically those arising from errors in memorizing or reciting the Dhamma word by word or line by line. The English translation 'Originations like the offense for memorizing the Teaching' indicates it refers to cases of misconduct originating in this manner.
padasodhammasamuṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: Originations like the offense for memorizing the Teaching are finished.

padaññatra.meaning_2: except for words; apart from phrases; line by line except
padaññatra.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form padaññatra appears to be a sandhi variant or compound blending 'padaṃ' (acc. sg. of pada, 'word' or 'line by line') with 'aññatra' (except, apart from), likely resolving to padaṃ + aññatra. In the context of 'padaññatra asammatā', it conveys 'not approved except for memorizing' or 'memorizing except, not appointed', indicating an exception related to recitation or word-based practice in Vinaya rules.

kāyacittato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form kāyacittato is an instrumental ablative singular of the tatpurusha compound 'kāyacitta' (body-mind), used in the sentence to indicate origin or source, contrasting with 'vācā' (from speech). In context, it specifies that certain actions or qualities arise from speech alone, not from physical or mental aspects.
kāyacittato.translation_1: Are from speech, not from body or mind;

kāyacittakā.meaning_2: with body and mind; bodily and mental
kāyacittakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form used in contexts referring to physical and mental aspects together, common in Buddhist texts for 'body and mind'.

padasodhammasadisā.meaning_2: similar to word-by-word recitation of the Teaching
padasodhammasadisā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is feminine nominative singular, fitting a feminine subject in the context of memorizing the Teaching, where 'padaso' indicates recitation line by line or word by word, 'dhamma' refers to the doctrine or teaching, and 'sadisa' means similar to.

addhānasamuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: origination based on time or journey; offenses originating from travel or temporal conditions
addhānasamuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound refers to a class of monastic offenses arising from or due to journeys or time periods, such as prohibitions on unnecessary travel; the sentence indicates the completion of discussing these origins.
addhānasamuṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: Originations like the offense for traveling are finished.

addhānanāvaṃ.meaning_2: boat for long journeys; traveling vessel
addhānanāvaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'addhānanāvaṃ paṇītaṃ', it refers to a fine or excellent boat used for long-distance travel, combining 'addhāna' (journey, long road) with 'nāvā' (boat). The accusative singular form indicates it as the object of the sentence.

pāṭidesanī.meaning_2: acknowledgment; confession of wrongdoing; to be acknowledged
pāṭidesanī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, pāṭidesanī refers to the eight specific offenses that require formal acknowledgment or confession by a monk, as indicated by 'aṭṭha ca pāṭidesanī' meaning 'and the eight to be acknowledged'.
pāṭidesanī.translation_1: And the eight to be acknowledged.

kāyavācāhi.meaning_2: by body and speech; by body, speech, and mind
kāyavācāhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in the sentences to indicate origin or production from body and speech, or body, speech, and mind, as per the contextual English translations. The compound functions adverbially in these phrases.
kāyavācāhi.translation_1: Or they are produced from body and speech,
kāyavācāhi.translation_2: Or from body, speech and mind—

theyyasatthasamuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: origination; arising; cause; offense originating from a party of traveling thieves
theyyasatthasamuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this term refers to the legal case or offense arising from involvement with a group of traveling thieves, as indicated by the sentence concluding the discussion of such originations.
theyyasatthasamuṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: Originations like the offense on a group of traveling thieves are finished.

sūpaviññāpanena.meaning_2: asking for bean curry; request for lentil soup
sūpaviññāpanena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound sūpaviññāpanena is the instrumental singular of sūpaviññāpana, meaning 'by asking for bean curry' or 'with a request for lentil soup', as used in the context of the sentence. It combines sūpa (soup or lentil curry) with viññāpana (act of informing or asking), indicating a request for that item.
sūpaviññāpanena.translation_1: And with asking for bean curry;

rattichannañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form 'rattichannañca' appears to be a sandhi compound where 'ratti' (night) combines with 'channa' (concealed, from √chad) and 'ca' (and). In the sentence 'rattichannañca okāsaṃ', it describes 'okāsaṃ' (space or place) as being both at night and concealed, or in open spaces that are hidden during the night. The 'ñ' likely results from sandhi resolution of 'channa + ca'.
rattichannañca.translation_1: Night, and concealed, out in the open,

theyyasatthasamuṭṭhānā.meaning_2: origination of a party of thieves; arising of a group of traveling thieves
theyyasatthasamuṭṭhānā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is an inflected instrumental singular of the compound noun 'theyyasatthasamuṭṭhāna', used in the context to denote the origin or arising of a thief caravan, as per the English translation. The compound combines 'theyyasattha' (party of thieves) with 'samuṭṭhāna' (origination), functioning adverbially to indicate the basis or cause.
theyyasatthasamuṭṭhānā.translation_1: As the origination of a group of traveling thieves,

dhammadesanāsamuṭṭhānaṃ.grammar: nt, comp, from dhammadesanā and samuṭṭhāna
dhammadesanāsamuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: origination; arising; cause (of offenses related to giving a Teaching); offenses originating from Dhamma teaching
dhammadesanāsamuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, this compound noun refers to the cases or origins of offenses arising from the act of teaching the Dhamma, as in Vinaya contexts where such matters are concluded or finished. The English translation 'Originations like the offenses on giving a Teaching' suggests a focus on legal or disciplinary origins tied to Dhamma discourse.
dhammadesanāsamuṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: Originations like the offenses on giving a Teaching are finished.

pādukupāhanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound pādukupāhanā is used in the context of the Vinaya to refer to footwear in general, and is listed alongside yānaṃ (vehicle) as one of the items permitted or regulated for monks, indicating a collective term for modes of conveyance or support for the feet.

seyyapallatthikāya.meaning_2: lying down and clasping the knees; posture of lying with knees clasped
seyyapallatthikāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the compound 'seyyapallatthikā', describing a specific posture where one lies down (seyyā) while clasping or embracing the knees (pallatthikā), as per the contextual translation.
seyyapallatthikāya.translation_1: Lying down, and clasping their knees;

veṭhitoguṇṭhito.meaning_2: wrapped and covered; with headdress and covered head
veṭhitoguṇṭhito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound veṭhitoguṇṭhito combines two past participles, veṭhita (wrapped) and guṇṭhita (covered), to describe a state of being both wrapped and covered, specifically referring to the head in the context of headdress or head covering in Vinaya monastic regulations.

ekādasamanūnakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term functions as an ordinal adjective in the context of the Vinaya, specifying the eleventh rule that is complete and not deficient in any way.

bhūtārocanasamuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: origination due to telling the truth; arising from truthful disclosure; in Vinaya context, the case or offense originating from speaking truly
bhūtārocanasamuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This term refers to the category of monastic offenses or rules that arise specifically from the act of truthfully reporting or disclosing facts, as in confessing faults or testifying honestly in Vinaya proceedings. The sentence indicates the completion of the exposition on such originations.
bhūtārocanasamuṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: Originations like the offense for telling truthfully are finished.

bhūtārocanakā.meaning_2: name of a rule; informing of what is true
bhūtārocanakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'bhūtārocanakā nāma', it functions as a feminine noun denoting the name of a specific rule or category in the Vinaya, literally 'the stating of what is true', referring to the act of truthfully declaring or informing about actual events or facts.
bhūtārocanakā.translation_1: So informing of what is true

corivuṭṭhāpanasamuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: origination concerning the rehabilitation of a female thief; case of admission of a female criminal
corivuṭṭhāpanasamuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound serving as the object of niṭṭhitaṃ ('finished') in the Vinaya context, referring to the completion of legal cases involving the rehabilitation or ordination process for a female thief or criminal. The English translation interprets corī as 'female criminal' in the monastic disciplinary sense.
corivuṭṭhāpanasamuṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: Originations like the offense for the admission of a female criminal are finished.

corivuṭṭhāpanaṃ.meaning_2: admitting a female criminal; rehabilitating a female thief; offense related to giving higher ordination to a female thief
corivuṭṭhāpanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound refers to a specific monastic offense involving the rehabilitation or higher ordination of a female thief (corī), often with implications of improper procedure or scandal. The English translation 'This offense for admitting a female criminal' highlights its use as a term for a punishable act in the monastic code.
corivuṭṭhāpanaṃ.translation_1: This offense for admitting a female criminal

ananuññātasamuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: origination due to lack of permission; arising from unapproved actions
ananuññātasamuṭṭhānaṃ.construction: na + anu + √ñā + ta + saṃ + ud + √ṭhā + ana
ananuññātasamuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound refers to offenses or violations originating from actions performed without proper permission, as concluded in the sentence where such cases are finalized or completed.
ananuññātasamuṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: Originations like the offense for lack of permission are finished.

catuṭhānikaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'akataṃ catuṭhānikaṃ', the word functions as a neuter nominative singular adjective modifying an implied or omitted noun, describing something 'not done' that possesses four bases or foundations, possibly referring to a quadrilateral structure or a fourfold doctrinal base in the Vinaya context.
catuṭhānikaṃ.translation_1: One that has four bases is not done.

samuṭṭhānañhi.meaning_2: indeed; certainly; truly; definitely; because; for
samuṭṭhānañhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This form is a sandhi combination of 'samuṭṭhāna' (nt, origination; arising) and 'hi' (emphatic particle, indeed; because). In the given sentence 'samuṭṭhānañhi saṅkhepaṃ', it functions as an adverbial phrase meaning 'for the contraction on originations', where 'hi' provides emphasis or causal nuance to 'samuṭṭhāna'.

asammohakaraṃ.meaning_2: cause for non-delusion; that which produces mental clarity
asammohakaraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, asammohakaraṃ refers to a condition or factor that generates non-delusion, aligning with the English translation 'A cause for non-delusion'. The form is accusative singular neuter, likely functioning as the object of an implied verb.

nettidhammānulomikaṃ.meaning_2: in accordance with the Teaching that guides; conformable to the guideline of the doctrine
nettidhammānulomikaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound nettidhammānulomikaṃ combines 'netti' (guideline or guide) with 'dhamma' (teaching or doctrine) and 'ānulomika' (conformable or in accordance with), indicating conformity to the guiding principles of the Buddha's teaching, as reflected in the English translation 'In accordance with the Teaching that guides'.
nettidhammānulomikaṃ.translation_1: In accordance with the Teaching that guides;

katipucchāvāro.meaning_2: section; sub-section on questions regarding quantity; instance of enquiry about how many
katipucchāvāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound denotes a specific section in the grammatical or exegetical text dealing with interrogative questions using 'kati' (how many?), marked as concluded in the given sentence. 'Vāra' here refers to a textual division or sub-section, common in Pāḷi commentaries.
katipucchāvāro.translation_1: The section on questioning “how many?” is finished.

pāṭidesanīyāpattikkhandho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound refers to the section grouping offenses that require formal acknowledgment or admission by the offender before the Community, as seen in the lists of offense classes where it follows pācittiya and precedes dukkaṭa.
pāṭidesanīyāpattikkhandho.translation_1: The class of offenses entailing expulsion, the class of offenses entailing suspension, the class of offenses entailing confession, the class of offenses entailing acknowledgment, the class of offenses of wrong conduct.
pāṭidesanīyāpattikkhandho.example_2: pārājikāpattikkhandho, saṅghādisesāpattikkhandho, thullaccayāpattikkhandho, pācittiyāpattikkhandho, pāṭidesanīyāpattikkhandho, dukkaṭāpattikkhandho, dubbhāsitāpattikkhandho—
pāṭidesanīyāpattikkhandho.translation_2: The class of offenses entailing expulsion, the class of offenses entailing suspension, the class of serious offenses, the class of offenses entailing confession, the class of offenses entailing acknowledgment, the class of offenses of wrong conduct, the class of offenses of wrong speech.

dukkaṭāpattikkhandho.meaning_2: the class of offenses of wrong conduct
dukkaṭāpattikkhandho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the provided sentences, this term denotes a specific category of Vinaya offenses involving wrongly done actions, positioned among other classes like expulsion and confession offenses.
dukkaṭāpattikkhandho.translation_1: The class of offenses entailing expulsion, the class of offenses entailing suspension, the class of offenses entailing confession, the class of offenses entailing acknowledgment, the class of offenses of wrong conduct.
dukkaṭāpattikkhandho.example_2: pārājikāpattikkhandho, saṅghādisesāpattikkhandho, thullaccayāpattikkhandho, pācittiyāpattikkhandho, pāṭidesanīyāpattikkhandho, dukkaṭāpattikkhandho, dubbhāsitāpattikkhandho—
dukkaṭāpattikkhandho.translation_2: The class of offenses entailing expulsion, the class of offenses entailing suspension, the class of serious offenses, the class of offenses entailing confession, the class of offenses entailing acknowledgment, the class of offenses of wrong conduct, the class of offenses of wrong speech.

velāanatikkamo.meaning_2: non-transgressing the boundary; not going beyond the limit
velāanatikkamo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound velāanatikkamo is used in the context of Vinaya texts to describe the non-transgression or non-exceeding of the prescribed boundaries or limits related to offenses, forming part of a series of terms denoting restraint and abstention.
velāanatikkamo.example_1: pañcahi āpattikkhandhehi ārati virati paṭivirati veramaṇī akiriyā akaraṇaṃ anajjhāpatti velāanatikkamo setughāto—
velāanatikkamo.translation_1: The refraining from, the keeping away from, the desisting from, the abstaining from, the non-doing of, the non-performing of, the non-committing of, the non-transgressing the boundary of, the incapability with respect to the five classes of offenses.
velāanatikkamo.example_2: sattahi āpattikkhandhehi ārati virati paṭivirati veramaṇī akiriyā akaraṇaṃ anajjhāpatti velāanatikkamo setughāto—
velāanatikkamo.translation_2: The refraining from, the keeping away from, the desisting from, the abstaining from, the non-doing of, the non-performing of, the non-committing of, the non-transgressing the boundary of, the incapability with respect to the seven classes of offenses.

thullaccayāpattikkhandho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound denotes the third of the seven classes of monastic offenses, specifically the serious moral transgressions that require formal meeting of the Saṅgha for resolution, entailing neither expulsion nor suspension but significant penance.
thullaccayāpattikkhandho.example_1: pārājikāpattikkhandho, saṅghādisesāpattikkhandho, thullaccayāpattikkhandho, pācittiyāpattikkhandho, pāṭidesanīyāpattikkhandho, dukkaṭāpattikkhandho, dubbhāsitāpattikkhandho—
thullaccayāpattikkhandho.translation_1: The class of offenses entailing expulsion, the class of offenses entailing suspension, the class of serious offenses, the class of offenses entailing confession, the class of offenses entailing acknowledgment, the class of offenses of wrong conduct, the class of offenses of wrong speech.

dubbhāsitāpattikkhandho.meaning_2: class of offenses of wrong speech
dubbhāsitāpattikkhandho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound noun refers to the category of minor verbal offenses in the Vinaya Piṭaka, specifically those involving incorrect or wrong speech, as opposed to other classes like those entailing expulsion or confession. It is the last in the list of seven pāṭikkhandhas.
dubbhāsitāpattikkhandho.example_1: pārājikāpattikkhandho, saṅghādisesāpattikkhandho, thullaccayāpattikkhandho, pācittiyāpattikkhandho, pāṭidesanīyāpattikkhandho, dukkaṭāpattikkhandho, dubbhāsitāpattikkhandho—
dubbhāsitāpattikkhandho.translation_1: The class of offenses entailing expulsion, the class of offenses entailing suspension, the class of serious offenses, the class of offenses entailing confession, the class of offenses entailing acknowledgment, the class of offenses of wrong conduct, the class of offenses of wrong speech.

viññupasatthāni.meaning_2: praised by the wise; commended by the discerning
viññupasatthāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, this compound adjective describes moral conduct (sīlāni) that is praised by the wise (viññū), emphasizing its approval among discerning individuals, as part of a list of qualities leading to samādhi.
viññupasatthāni.example_1: puna caparaṃ bhikkhu yāni tāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni akammāsāni bhujissāni viññupasatthāni aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhisaṃvattanikāni, tathārūpesu sīlesu sīlasāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca.
viññupasatthāni.translation_1: (5) Furthermore, a monk lives with his fellow monastics, both in public and in private, with moral conduct that is unbroken, consistent, spotless, pure, liberating, praised by the wise, ungrasped, and leading to stillness.

vinītāgāravā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'Training, and disrespect', the compound vinītāgāravā combines vinīta (trained, as in disciplined in Vinaya) with agārava (disrespectful, privative of gārava), linked by 'ca' (and) to contrast positive training with its negative counterpart of irreverence.

vivādanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'samuṭṭhānā vivādanā', vivādanā is the instrumental plural form meaning 'by disputes' or 'through disputes', paired with 'originations' to indicate sources or causes of disputes in doctrinal or monastic contexts.

bhedādhikaraṇena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in Vinaya context to denote legal proceedings related to schism, aligning with the sentence's reference to schism and legal issues.

chaāpattisamuṭṭhānavāro.meaning_2: section on the six kinds of originations of offenses
chaāpattisamuṭṭhānavāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound noun functions as the title of a section in the Vinaya text, indicating a division focused on the six categories of how offenses arise or originate, as concluded in the sentence.
chaāpattisamuṭṭhānavāro.translation_1: The first section on the six kinds of originations of offenses is finished.

dubbhāsitāpattikkhandhena.meaning_2: class of offenses of wrong speech
dubbhāsitāpattikkhandhena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term refers to the aggregate or group of offenses involving wrong or bad speech in the Vinaya classification, as indicated by the contextual sentence listing various classes of offenses.
dubbhāsitāpattikkhandhena.example_1: siyā pārājikāpattikkhandhena, siyā saṅghādisesāpattikkhandhena, siyā thullaccayāpattikkhandhena, siyā pācittiyāpattikkhandhena, siyā dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena, siyā dubbhāsitāpattikkhandhena.
dubbhāsitāpattikkhandhena.translation_1: they may be in the class of offenses entailing expulsion; they may be in the class of offenses entailing suspension; they may be in the class of serious offenses; they may be in the class of offenses entailing confession; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong conduct; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong speech.

āpattisamuṭṭhānagāthā.meaning_2: verses on the kinds of originations of offenses
āpattisamuṭṭhānagāthā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound noun refers to a specific section in the Vinaya text consisting of verses that discuss the various causes or origins of monastic offenses (āpatti), as indicated by the contextual sentences where it marks the title and conclusion of the third section.
āpattisamuṭṭhānagāthā.translation_1: 3. The verses on the kinds of originations of offenses
āpattisamuṭṭhānagāthā.translation_2: The third section on the verses on the kinds of originations of offenses is finished.

vipattipaccayavāro.grammar: masc, comp, from vipatti + paccaya + vāra
vipattipaccayavāro.meaning_2: section on 'as a result of failure'
vipattipaccayavāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a title for the fourth section in a textual division, where vipatti denotes failure or misfortune, paccaya indicates the causal condition 'as a result of', and vāra specifies the section or chapter.
vipattipaccayavāro.translation_1: The fourth section on “as a result of failure” is finished.

sīlavipattipaccayā.meaning_2: dependent on failure in morality; due to failure in morality; as a result of failure in morality
sīlavipattipaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, this instrumental adverbial form indicates the causal condition ('as a result of failure in morality') under which offenses are committed, linking the ethical lapse to the arising of four types of āpattiyo (offenses).
sīlavipattipaccayā.translation_1: How many kinds of offenses does one commit as a result of failure in morality?

ācāravipattipaccayā.grammar: ind, adv, in comps, abl sg of paccaya
ācāravipattipaccayā.meaning_2: dependent on failure in conduct; due to failure in moral conduct; as a result of lapse in conduct
ācāravipattipaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, this adverbial phrase specifies the causal condition for committing an offense, linking failure in moral conduct (ācāravipatti) as the supporting factor (paccayā) leading to one type of offense (āpatti).
ācāravipattipaccayā.translation_1: How many kinds of offenses does one commit as a result of failure in conduct?

diṭṭhivipattipaccayā.grammar: ind, adv, in comps, abl sg of diṭṭhivipattipaccaya
diṭṭhivipattipaccayā.meaning_2: dependent on failure in view; due to wrong view; as a result of failure in view
diṭṭhivipattipaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, it functions adverbially to indicate the causal condition ('as a result of') leading to committing two offenses due to wrong view or failure in view.
diṭṭhivipattipaccayā.translation_1: How many kinds of offenses does one commit as a result of failure in view?

ājīvavipattipaccayā.grammar: ind, adv, in comps, abl sg of ājīvavipattipaccaya
ājīvavipattipaccayā.meaning_2: dependent on failure in livelihood; due to failure in livelihood; caused by failure in livelihood
ājīvavipattipaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, ājīvavipattipaccayā specifies the condition under which six offenses are committed, functioning adverbially to indicate the causal basis of 'failure in livelihood' in Vinaya discussions on monastic misconduct.
ājīvavipattipaccayā.translation_1: How many kinds of offenses does one commit as a result of failure in livelihood?

ājīvakāraṇā.grammar: ind, adv, abl sg of kāraṇa
ājīvakāraṇā.meaning_2: because of livelihood; for the sake of livelihood; on account of livelihood
ājīvakāraṇā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya sentences, 'ājīvakāraṇā' functions adverbially to specify that the prohibited actions (claiming false attainments, match-making, recommending monks, requesting food for oneself) are motivated by the need to earn a living, distinguishing these cases from non-ājīva motivated offenses which may carry different penalties.
ājīvakāraṇā.example_1: ājīvahetu ājīvakāraṇā pāpiccho icchāpakato asantaṃ abhūtaṃ uttarimanussadhammaṃ ullapati, āpatti pārājikassa;
ājīvakāraṇā.translation_1: (1) when, to make a living, having bad desires, overcome by desire, one claims a non-existent superhuman quality, one commits an offense entailing expulsion;
ājīvakāraṇā.example_2: ājīvahetu ājīvakāraṇā sañcarittaṃ samāpajjati, āpatti saṅghādisesassa;
ājīvakāraṇā.translation_2: (2) when, to make a living, one acts as a matchmaker, one commits an offense entailing suspension;

adhikaraṇapaccayavāro.grammar: masc, comp, from adhikaraṇa paccaya vāra
adhikaraṇapaccayavāro.meaning_2: section on legal issues as conditions
adhikaraṇapaccayavāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound noun refers to a specific chapter or subsection in a Pāḷi grammatical or doctrinal text, likely dealing with conditional relationships arising from legal or disciplinary matters in the Vinaya context, as indicated by the sentence marking its completion as the fifth section.
adhikaraṇapaccayavāro.translation_1: The fifth section on “as a result of legal issues” is finished.

vivādādhikaraṇapaccayā.meaning_2: dependent on a legal issue arising from a dispute; due to a case involving disagreement; as a result of a legal issue from disputes
vivādādhikaraṇapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This adverbial form functions as an instrumental of condition in the texts, indicating the causal basis for offenses or legal issues stemming from disputes, as seen in phrases like 'vivādādhikaraṇapaccayā dve āpattiyo āpajjati' meaning 'one commits two offenses due to a legal issue from a dispute'.
vivādādhikaraṇapaccayā.translation_1: “How many kinds of offenses does one commit as a result of legal issues arising from disputes?

anuvādādhikaraṇapaccayā.meaning_2: dependent on a legal issue arising from an accusation; due to a case involving condemnation
anuvādādhikaraṇapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This instrumental adverbial form is used throughout the text to indicate the causal basis for committing offenses or generating other legal issues in the Vinaya context, as seen in questions like 'anuvādādhikaraṇapaccayā kati āpattiyo āpajjati?' meaning 'How many offenses due to a legal issue from accusation?' It denotes dependency on the condition of an accusation-based dispute.
anuvādādhikaraṇapaccayā.translation_1: How many kinds of offenses does one commit as a result of legal issues arising from accusations?
