dhuvaṭṭhānikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes foot stands (pādukā) that are fixed and cannot be moved, contrasting with mobile types. 'Dhuva' conveys permanence or stability, 'aṭṭhānika' indicates a fixed position or location.
dhuvaṭṭhānikā.translation_1: There are three kinds of foot stands that are fixed in place and immobile:

asaṅkamanīyā.meaning_2: not to be crossed; immobile; immovable
asaṅkamanīyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'asaṅkamanīyā' describes the foot stands as fixed and not to be crossed or moved, emphasizing their stationary nature in contrast to portable ones.
asaṅkamanīyā.translation_1: There are three kinds of foot stands that are fixed in place and immobile:

pādaghaṃsaniyo.meaning_2: foot scrubber; instrument for rubbing the feet
pādaghaṃsaniyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term refers to an instrument or device used for scrubbing or rubbing the feet, as indicated by the context of three kinds of such scrubbers. The compound breaks down to 'pāda' (foot), 'ghaṃsa' (rubbing), and 'nīya' (instrumental suffix indicating a tool for the action).
pādaghaṃsaniyo.translation_1: There are three kinds of foot scrubbers:

samuddapheṇakoti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, it refers to a type of light, porous stone resembling sea foam, translated as 'pumice' alongside stones and pebbles.

senāsanagilāyanā.meaning_2: sick in dwelling; unwell due to lodging
senāsanagilāyanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where senāsana (lodging) is the upapada to gilāyana (being sick), indicating sickness related to or in one's dwelling place. The English translation 'Dwelling, sick' reflects the compound's dual aspects, likely describing a monk who is ill due to his living conditions.

pabbājapaṭisāraṇī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound used in Vinaya contexts, particularly in abbreviated verse forms (doggerel). 'Pabbājā' refers to banishing or expulsion from the monastic community, while 'paṭisāraṇī' is an abbreviated form of 'paṭisāraṇīya', denoting matters requiring reconciliation or confession. The compound thus signifies procedures or texts related to banishing followed by reconciliation in monastic discipline.

āgāḷhakammādhisīle.meaning_2: in the harsh legal procedure regarding higher morality
āgāḷhakammādhisīle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of the tatpuruṣa compound āgāḷhakammādhisīla, used adverbially to indicate the context of a strict or harsh formal legal procedure in the domain of higher ethical conduct, as per the Vinaya context.
āgāḷhakammādhisīle.translation_1: Strong, legal procedure, in the higher morality,

davānācāra.meaning_2: playful conduct; sporting behavior; frivolous action
davānācāra.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'dava' (fun, play, sport) with 'ācāra' (conduct, behavior), likely denoting conduct involving playful or sporting activities, possibly with a connotation of frivolity or improper behavior depending on context.

ājīvāpannā.meaning_2: one who has committed (an offence) in regard to livelihood; one fallen into livelihood-related misconduct; similar (such) person committing livelihood faults
ājīvāpannā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ājīvāpannā is the nominative singular masculine of the compound ājīva-āpanna, where ājīva means 'livelihood' and āpanna is the past participle of āpajjati meaning 'having fallen into' or 'committed' (especially an offence). In the Vinaya context, this likely refers to a monk who has committed a fault related to improper livelihood, aligning with the sentence's focus on 'livelihood, committing, similar'—indicating such a person who has similarly transgressed in this area.

avaṇṇuposathena.meaning_2: observance-day ceremony of dispraise; disparaging observance-day rite
avaṇṇuposathena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in context to denote the ceremony or rite involving disparagement or dispraise, as per the English translation 'Disparages, and with observance-day ceremony.' This compound likely refers to a faulty or blameworthy observance, contrasting with proper uposatha practices.

vohārapaccekena.meaning_2: with conventional authority; by authoritative speech
vohārapaccekena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'Speak, and with authority', the compound indicates speaking with the authority derived from conventional or verbal usage, combining 'vohāra' (verbal expression or mode of communication) with 'pacceka' (individual or separate), suggesting a distinct or personal authoritative manner in speech.

pucchitabbakā.grammar: masc, fut pp agent of pucchati
pucchitabbakā.meaning_2: those who should not be asked
pucchitabbakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pucchitabbakā is the nominative plural of the masculine agent noun derived from the future passive participle pucchitabba (to be asked), indicating persons who are to be questioned or interrogated. In the sentence 'na pucchitabbakā duve', it refers to two categories of individuals who should not be approached for questioning, likely in a Vinaya context concerning monastic discipline.
pucchitabbakā.translation_1: Two on those who should not be asked;

nissayasāmaṇerā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the compound nissayasāmaṇera, used in Vinaya context to denote the formal dependence or support involving a novice monk, as indicated by the English translation.

uposathatikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound uposathatikā refers to a triad or set of three uposatha ceremonies, as indicated by the sentence 'uposathatikā tīṇi' meaning 'three [sets of] observance-day ceremonies'. Here, 'tīṇi' specifies three such groups.

pavāraṇatikā.meaning_2: group of three invitation ceremonies; triad of pavāraṇā
pavāraṇatikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, pavāraṇā refers to the invitation ceremony at the end of the vassa retreat. Here, pavāraṇatikā denotes a set or triad of three such ceremonies, as indicated by the sentence 'Three on three invitation ceremonies'.

tikabhojanasaddhamme.meaning_2: eating in groups of no more than three, in bad qualities; eating in groups of no more than three, in false doctrine
tikabhojanasaddhamme.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form tikabhojanasaddhamme is a sandhi compound in locative singular, combining tikabhojana (nt, 'eating in a group of no more than three') with asaddhamma (masc, 'bad qualities' or 'false doctrine'), but written without the initial 'a-' due to contextual or scribal variation. In the given English translation 'in bad qualities', it reflects asaddhamma meaning 1 or 2, indicating unvirtuous practices or untrue teachings in the context of restricted communal eating.
tikabhojanasaddhamme.translation_1: Eating in groups of no more than three, in bad qualities,

pādaghaṃsanikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term pādaghaṃsanikā refers to a tool or person for scrubbing or rubbing the feet, as indicated by the context of the English translation 'And foot scrubbers'. It is a compound where 'pāda' means foot and 'ghaṃsanikā' derives from the action of rubbing (ghaṃsati), with 'nikā' likely indicating an agent or instrument, feminized to match possible grammatical requirements in the sentence.

catukkavāro.meaning_2: quaternion; group of four occasions; fourfold instance
catukkavāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'catukka' (group of four) with 'vāra' (occasion or instance), likely referring to a set of four occasions or cases, possibly in a technical or enumerative context such as Vinaya sections.

sakavācāya.grammar: ind, adv, instr sg of sakavācā
sakavācāya.meaning_2: through one's own speech; by one's own words
sakavācāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of Vinaya offenses (āpatti), sakavācāya refers to committing or clearing an offense verbally through one's own speech, contrasting with paravācāya (through another's speech). Sentences 4 appears fragmentary and may be part of a larger expression like 'sakavācāya kāyena' meaning 'through one's own speech, by body'.
sakavācāya.translation_1: (1) There are offenses that one commits through one’s own speech, but clears through someone else’s speech.
sakavācāya.translation_2: (2) There are offenses that one commits through someone else’s speech, but clears through one’s own speech.

paravācāya.grammar: ind, adv, instr sg of vācā
paravācāya.meaning_1: verbally; out loud; lit. by speaking
paravācāya.meaning_2: by (one's own) speech; by someone else's speech
paravācāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, paravācāya denotes commitment or clearance of offenses 'through someone else's speech' (e.g., via another's confession or pronouncement), contrasting with sakavācāya 'through one's own speech'. This instrumental form highlights the means of verbal action in Vinaya procedural contexts.
paravācāya.translation_1: (1) There are offenses that one commits through one’s own speech, but clears through someone else’s speech.
paravācāya.translation_2: (2) There are offenses that one commits through someone else’s speech, but clears through one’s own speech.

pasutto.meaning_2: sleeping; in a state of sleep
pasutto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'pasutto' refers to the state of being asleep, used to describe offenses committed or cleared during sleep, as in the categories of atthāpatti (offenses). It contrasts with 'paṭibuddho' (awake). Sentence 4 specifies 'pasutto ca acittako', meaning unintentionally while sleeping.
pasutto.translation_1: (1) There are offenses that one commits while sleeping, but clears while awake.
pasutto.translation_2: (2) There are offenses that one commits while awake, but clears while sleeping.

mamāyitabbo.meaning_1: should be taken as a personal possession
mamāyitabbo.meaning_2: should be appropriated; should be regarded as one's own
mamāyitabbo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, mamāyitabbo refers to treating requisites (parikkhāro) as personal possessions, contrasting with non-attachment in monastic practice. It appears in varying combinations across the four cases, indicating degrees of possession and use.
mamāyitabbo.example_1: atthi parikkhāro rakkhitabbo gopetabbo mamāyitabbo paribhuñjitabbo;
mamāyitabbo.translation_1: (1) There are requisites that should be guarded, taken as a personal possession, and made use of.
mamāyitabbo.example_2: atthi parikkhāro rakkhitabbo gopetabbo mamāyitabbo, na paribhuñjitabbo;
mamāyitabbo.translation_2: (2) There are requisites that should be guarded and made use of, but not taken as a personal possession.

liṅgapātubhāvena.meaning_2: appearance of sexual characteristics; manifestation of gender features
liṅgapātubhāvena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, this compound noun denotes the visible manifestation of sexual or gender characteristics, likely referring to physical signs in monastic or legal contexts where such appearances could lead to disqualification or scrutiny.
liṅgapātubhāvena.translation_1: in the midst of the Sangha, in the midst of a group, in the presence of an individual, through the appearance of sexual characteristics. —
liṅgapātubhāvena.translation_2: in the midst of the Sangha, in the midst of a group, in the presence of an individual, through the appearance of sexual characteristics. —

sāmukkaṃsā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound sāmukkaṃsā combines 'sāma' (self-, own) with 'ukkaṃsa' (excellence, elevation) to denote unique or self-excelling qualities. In the context, 'cattāro sāmukkaṃsā' refers to four such unique things, likely the four unique qualities of the Buddha or similar doctrinal elements, as 'paṭiggahi' indicates they have been received or accepted.

paṭiggahitaparibhogā.meaning_2: things requiring reception; items for received use; requisites to be obtained for consumption
paṭiggahitaparibhogā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound functions as a bahuvrīhi describing the four items that must be formally received (paṭiggahita) for permissible use (paribhoga) in monastic life, such as robes or alms, aligning with the Vinaya context of requisites.
paṭiggahitaparibhogā.translation_1: There are four things that need to be received:

parisasobhaṇā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound formed from 'parisā' (assembly) and 'sobhaṇā' (beautiful), likely in nominative singular feminine, describing a radiant or splendid gathering in a context emphasizing beauty or excellence.

vatthunānattatā.meaning_2: variety in the action that is the basis for the offense; diversity in the basis or object of the rule
vatthunānattatā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound refers to the diversity or multiplicity in the 'vatthu' (basis, object, or action) of monastic rules, contrasting with uniformity in the type of offense (āpatti). It is used to classify rules based on whether their foundational actions vary while the resulting offenses do not, or vice versa, as outlined in the fourfold schema.
vatthunānattatā.example_1: atthi vatthunānattatā no āpattinānattatā, atthi āpattinānattatā no vatthunānattatā, atthi vatthunānattatā ceva āpattinānattatā ca, atthi neva vatthunānattatā no āpattinānattatā.
vatthunānattatā.translation_1: (1) There are rules that have variety in the action that is the basis for the offense, but not in the offense. (2) There are rules that have variety in the offense, but not in the action that is the basis for the offense. (3) There are rules that have variety both in the action that is the basis for the offense and in the offense. (4) There are rules that have variety neither in the action that is the basis for the offense nor in the offense.
vatthunānattatā.example_2: atthi vatthunānattatā no āpattinānattatā, atthi āpattinānattatā no vatthunānattatā, atthi vatthunānattatā ceva āpattinānattatā ca, atthi neva vatthunānattatā no āpattinānattatā.
vatthunānattatā.translation_2: (1) There are rules that have variety in the action that is the basis for the offense, but not in the offense. (2) There are rules that have variety in the offense, but not in the action that is the basis for the offense. (3) There are rules that have variety both in the action that is the basis for the offense and in the offense. (4) There are rules that have variety neither in the action that is the basis for the offense nor in the offense.

āpattinānattatā.meaning_2: variety in the offense; diversity of offenses
āpattinānattatā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound refers to the diversity or multiplicity in the types or classifications of offenses (āpatti), as opposed to uniformity, contrasting with vatthunānattatā (variety in the basis of the offense). It highlights rules where offenses vary while the basis remains constant, or vice versa, illustrating the nuanced structure of monastic regulations.
āpattinānattatā.example_1: atthi vatthunānattatā no āpattinānattatā, atthi āpattinānattatā no vatthunānattatā, atthi vatthunānattatā ceva āpattinānattatā ca, atthi neva vatthunānattatā no āpattinānattatā.
āpattinānattatā.translation_1: (1) There are rules that have variety in the action that is the basis for the offense, but not in the offense. (2) There are rules that have variety in the offense, but not in the action that is the basis for the offense. (3) There are rules that have variety both in the action that is the basis for the offense and in the offense. (4) There are rules that have variety neither in the action that is the basis for the offense nor in the offense.
āpattinānattatā.example_2: atthi vatthunānattatā no āpattinānattatā, atthi āpattinānattatā no vatthunānattatā, atthi vatthunānattatā ceva āpattinānattatā ca, atthi neva vatthunānattatā no āpattinānattatā.
āpattinānattatā.translation_2: (1) There are rules that have variety in the action that is the basis for the offense, but not in the offense. (2) There are rules that have variety in the offense, but not in the action that is the basis for the offense. (3) There are rules that have variety both in the action that is the basis for the offense and in the offense. (4) There are rules that have variety neither in the action that is the basis for the offense nor in the offense.

vatthusabhāgatā.meaning_2: sharing of the basis (of an offense); commonality of the foundational act
vatthusabhāgatā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'vatthu' refers to the objective basis or foundational act of a monastic rule, and 'sabhāgatā' indicates its shared nature across rules. The term categorizes rules by whether this basis is shared (e.g., same act applies to multiple offenses) or not, as enumerated in the four cases: shared basis but not offense; shared offense but not basis; both shared; neither shared.
vatthusabhāgatā.example_1: atthi vatthusabhāgatā no āpattisabhāgatā, atthi āpattisabhāgatā no vatthusabhāgatā, atthi vatthusabhāgatā ceva āpattisabhāgatā ca atthi neva vatthusabhāgatā no āpattisabhāgatā.
vatthusabhāgatā.translation_1: (1) There are rules where the action that is the basis for the offense is shared, but not the offense. (2) There are rules where the offense is shared, but not the action that is the basis for the offense. (3) There are rules where both the action that is the basis for the offense and the offense are shared. (4) There are rules where neither the action that is the basis for the offense nor the offense is shared.
vatthusabhāgatā.example_2: atthi vatthusabhāgatā no āpattisabhāgatā, atthi āpattisabhāgatā no vatthusabhāgatā, atthi vatthusabhāgatā ceva āpattisabhāgatā ca atthi neva vatthusabhāgatā no āpattisabhāgatā.
vatthusabhāgatā.translation_2: (1) There are rules where the action that is the basis for the offense is shared, but not the offense. (2) There are rules where the offense is shared, but not the action that is the basis for the offense. (3) There are rules where both the action that is the basis for the offense and the offense are shared. (4) There are rules where neither the action that is the basis for the offense nor the offense is shared.

āpattisabhāgatā.meaning_2: sharing of an offense; commonality in the offense (in Vinaya rules)
āpattisabhāgatā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, āpattisabhāgatā refers to cases where the offense itself is shared among multiple rules, contrasting with vatthusabhāgatā (sharing of the basis or action). This compound is used to classify rules into four categories based on whether the basis (vatthu) and the offense (āpatti) are shared or not.
āpattisabhāgatā.example_1: atthi vatthusabhāgatā no āpattisabhāgatā, atthi āpattisabhāgatā no vatthusabhāgatā, atthi vatthusabhāgatā ceva āpattisabhāgatā ca atthi neva vatthusabhāgatā no āpattisabhāgatā.
āpattisabhāgatā.translation_1: (1) There are rules where the action that is the basis for the offense is shared, but not the offense. (2) There are rules where the offense is shared, but not the action that is the basis for the offense. (3) There are rules where both the action that is the basis for the offense and the offense are shared. (4) There are rules where neither the action that is the basis for the offense nor the offense is shared.
āpattisabhāgatā.example_2: atthi vatthusabhāgatā no āpattisabhāgatā, atthi āpattisabhāgatā no vatthusabhāgatā, atthi vatthusabhāgatā ceva āpattisabhāgatā ca atthi neva vatthusabhāgatā no āpattisabhāgatā.
āpattisabhāgatā.translation_2: (1) There are rules where the action that is the basis for the offense is shared, but not the offense. (2) There are rules where the offense is shared, but not the action that is the basis for the offense. (3) There are rules where both the action that is the basis for the offense and the offense are shared. (4) There are rules where neither the action that is the basis for the offense nor the offense is shared.

bhinditukāmā.meaning_2: wanting to split; desiring to cause a schism
bhinditukāmā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'bhinditukāmā honti' refers to those desiring to cause a schism in the Saṅgha, paralleling the English 'there are some who want to cause a schism in the Sangha'.
bhinditukāmā.example_1: saṅgho vā bhinno hoti, saṅghaṃ vā bhinditukāmā honti, jīvitantarāyo vā hoti, brahmacariyantarāyo vā hoti.
bhinditukāmā.translation_1: there is a schism in the Sangha; there are some who want to cause a schism in the Sangha; there is a threat to life; there is a threat to the monastic life. —

abhivādanāraho.meaning_2: worthy of being bowed down to; deserving of paying respect; entitled to being honored
abhivādanāraho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the contextual sentences, 'abhivādanāraho' describes individuals who merit the act of bowing down or paying respect, as distinguished from those deserving standing up for (paccuṭṭhānāraho) or a seat (āsanāraho). It highlights gradations of respect in social or monastic etiquette.
abhivādanāraho.translation_1: (1) There are people who deserve being bowed down to, but not being stood up for.
abhivādanāraho.translation_2: (2) There are people who deserve being stood up for, but not to being bowed down to.

paccuṭṭhānāraho.meaning_2: deserving of standing up for (in respect); worthy of rising to one's feet
paccuṭṭhānāraho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentences, 'paccuṭṭhānāraho' denotes worthiness of the act of rising from one's seat as a gesture of respect, contrasting with 'abhivādanāraho' (bowing). It applies to persons meriting such honor in varying degrees, as per the four cases.
paccuṭṭhānāraho.translation_1: (1) There are people who deserve being bowed down to, but not being stood up for.
paccuṭṭhānāraho.translation_2: (2) There are people who deserve being stood up for, but not to being bowed down to.

vatthusandassanā.meaning_2: pointing out the action that is the basis for an offense
vatthusandassanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound refers to the procedural step of identifying or pointing out the specific action or matter (vatthu) that serves as the foundation for a monastic offense, as part of formal admonition processes.
vatthusandassanā.translation_1: pointing out the action that is the basis for an offense, pointing out the offense, refusing to live together, refusing to act respectfully. —

āpattisandassanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun used in Vinaya context to denote the act of identifying or pointing out an offense, parallel to vatthusandassanā as pointing out the basis for the offense.
āpattisandassanā.translation_1: pointing out the action that is the basis for an offense, pointing out the offense, refusing to live together, refusing to act respectfully. —

saṃvāsapaṭikkhepo.meaning_2: refusing to live together; refusal of cohabitation
saṃvāsapaṭikkhepo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'saṃvāsa' (cohabitation) is qualified by 'paṭikkhepa' (rejection). In the Vinaya context, it refers to a formal disciplinary action where a monk refuses to continue living together with another monk due to misconduct, as part of the listed procedures for addressing offenses.
saṃvāsapaṭikkhepo.translation_1: pointing out the action that is the basis for an offense, pointing out the offense, refusing to live together, refusing to act respectfully. —

sāmīcipaṭikkhepo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound denotes a formal disciplinary measure involving the refusal to show proper respect or courtesy, parallel to saṃvāsapaṭikkhepo which is refusal to live together. The first member sāmīci likely draws from the sense of 'proper procedure' or 'friendly treatment', combined with paṭikkhepa 'prohibition'.
sāmīcipaṭikkhepo.translation_1: pointing out the action that is the basis for an offense, pointing out the offense, refusing to live together, refusing to act respectfully. —

anaññapācittiyāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form 'anaññapācittiyāni' is the neuter nominative/accusative plural of the compound 'anaññapācittiya', used in the Vinaya to denote one of the four specific classes of confession offenses distinguished by the phrase 'no other' (anañña), indicating exclusivity in the rule's application, as seen in the contextual sentences enumerating these offenses.
anaññapācittiyāni.translation_1: There are four offenses entailing confession concerning “no other”. —
anaññapācittiyāni.translation_2: How many on ‘no other, he commits an offense entailing confession’?

ajānakāye.meaning_2: by the body unknowingly; by the physical act without awareness
ajānakāye.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'ajānakāye majjhe ca', ajānakāye is the instrumental singular of the compound ajānakāya, meaning 'by the body unknowingly'. It refers to an unintentional physical action or deed performed without awareness, often in discussions of karma or moral conduct in Pāḷi texts.
ajānakāye.translation_1: Unknowingly, by body, and in the midst of,

mahāvikaṭakammāni.meaning_2: incredibly disgusting things; foul edibles; legal procedures
mahāvikaṭakammāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given context, the compound mahāvikaṭakammāni appears to be neuter plural, translated as 'foul edibles, legal procedures', suggesting a specialized Vinaya usage where 'kammāni' refers to formal legal acts or procedures that are metaphorically or literally described as incredibly disgusting or foul.

sobhanāgantukena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound is an instrumental singular form used in the context to describe a shining or beautiful new arrival, as per the English translation.
sobhanāgantukena.translation_1: Shining, and by a new arrival.

vatthunānattā.meaning_2: variety in the action; diversity of the basis
vatthunānattā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in the context of a departing action (gamiko), indicating diversity or variety in the basis or object of the action, likely referring to the multiplicity of possible objects or grounds for departure.
vatthunānattā.translation_1: One departing, variety in the action,

sabhāgupajjhāyena.meaning_2: with the shared preceptor; with the preceptor in common
sabhāgupajjhāyena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is the instrumental singular of a tatpuruṣa compound sabhāgupajjhāya, where sabhāga ('shared, common') modifies upajjhāya ('preceptor'). In the monastic context, it refers to the preceptor shared among several novices, as indicated by the English translation 'Shared, and with preceptor'.

nāgati.meaning_2: not wrong acting; correct course; right behaviour
nāgati.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'agati nāgati ceva', nāgati contrasts with agati (wrong acting) to denote proper or right acting, forming a pair that covers both negative and positive modes of behaviour or destination.
nāgati.translation_1: Wrong acting, and not wrong acting,

vissajjeyyā.meaning_2: should reply; should send forth; should release
vissajjeyyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'vissajjeyyā tathā duve', meaning 'And another two one should reply', the word functions as an optative form indicating obligation or advice to respond or reply, likely in a dialogic or instructional setting such as in Vinaya procedures. The provided dictionary entries for 'vissa' and 'jeyya' appear unrelated and likely erroneous for this form.
vissajjeyyā.translation_1: And another two on should reply;

pañcakavāro.meaning_2: group of five occasions; pentadic repetition; set of five instances
pañcakavāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound likely refers to a structured set of five occasions or repetitions, common in textual divisions or ritual contexts in Pāḷi literature.

nappaṭikkosati.meaning_2: does not object; does not reject; does not refuse to accept
nappaṭikkosati.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of Vinaya legal procedures, nappaṭikkosati specifically means not raising any objection or protest during the ongoing process, indicating tacit approval or non-resistance to the proceedings.
nappaṭikkosati.example_1: sayaṃ vā kammaṃ karoti, paraṃ vā ajjhesati, chandaṃ vā pārisuddhiṃ vā deti, kayiramāne kamme nappaṭikkosati, kate vā pana kamme dhammadiṭṭhi hoti.
nappaṭikkosati.translation_1: (1) one does the legal procedure oneself; (2) one requests someone else; (3) one gives one’s consent or declares one’s purity; (4) one does not object while the legal procedure is being carried out; or (5) one has the view that the completed legal procedure is legitimate.

avikappanā.meaning_2: non-assignment to another; not assigning ownership; not transferring ownership
avikappanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context of meal formalities, 'avikappanā' refers to the prohibition or absence of assigning or transferring ownership of the meal to another person, ensuring the meal is not shared or designated beyond the invited recipient.
avikappanā.translation_1: (1) visiting families before or after a meal invitation, (2) eating in a group, (3) eating a meal before another, (4) non-determination, (5) non-assignment to another.

thullakumārigocaro.meaning_2: association with single women; resort of unmarried grown-up women
thullakumārigocaro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, thullakumārigocaro indicates habitual association or resort with thullakumārīs, interpreted as single or unmarried grown-up women, listed among improper associations for a monk.
thullakumārigocaro.example_1: pāpabhikkhupi akuppadhammopi vesiyāgocaro vā hoti, vidhavāgocaro vā hoti, thullakumārigocaro vā hoti, paṇḍakagocaro vā hoti, bhikkhunigocaro vā hoti.
thullakumārigocaro.translation_1: he regularly associates with sex workers, widows, single women, paṇḍakas, or nuns. —

eraṇḍakatelaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given context, eraṇḍakatelaṃ refers to castor oil, derived from the seeds of the castor oil plant (eraṇḍa), listed among various oils in a Pāḷi enumeration.
eraṇḍakatelaṃ.translation_1: sesame oil, mustard oil, honey-tree oil, castor oil, and oil from fat. —

arogasampadā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'aroga' (health, freedom from disease) with 'sampadā' (success, attainment), denoting one of the five worldly successes in the list, specifically referring to success or attainment in health.
arogasampadā.translation_1: success in relatives, success in property, success in health, success in morality, and success in view.

undūrakkhāyikaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound undūrakkhāyikaṃ describes food or items damaged or consumed by rats (undūra), fitting the context of impure or unfit substances in the Vinaya list. The base akkhāyikā, meaning 'narrative' or 'story', here likely denotes 'recitation' or 'telling', extended to imply consumption or devouring in a metaphorical sense, though the primary sense is 'eaten by rats' as per the translation.
undūrakkhāyikaṃ.translation_1: (1) those from a charnel ground, (2) those from a shop, (3) those eaten by rats, (4) those eaten by termites, (5) those burned by fire.

upacikakkhāyikaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound upacikakkhāyikaṃ describes food or items that have been eaten or damaged by termites (upacikā), paralleling the English translation 'those eaten by termites' in the list of impure or contaminated things.
upacikakkhāyikaṃ.translation_1: (1) those from a charnel ground, (2) those from a shop, (3) those eaten by rats, (4) those eaten by termites, (5) those burned by fire.

gokhāyikaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, gokhāyikaṃ refers to robes or cloth that has been chewed by cattle, listed among types of defective or impure cloth unsuitable for use, as per the provided sentence.
gokhāyikaṃ.translation_1: (1) those chewed by cattle, (2) those chewed by goats, (3) those left at a stupa, (4) those discarded from a king’s consecration, (5) those taken to and then brought back from a charnel ground.

ajakkhāyikaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, ajakkhāyikaṃ refers to robes or cloth that has been chewed or damaged by goats, as part of the categories of unfit robes listed. The term is a descriptive compound combining 'aja' (goat) with a form derived from 'ākkhyāti' (to narrate or tell), adapted here to mean 'chewed by' in the sense of the action performed on the cloth.
ajakkhāyikaṃ.translation_1: (1) those chewed by cattle, (2) those chewed by goats, (3) those left at a stupa, (4) those discarded from a king’s consecration, (5) those taken to and then brought back from a charnel ground.

gatapaṭiyāgataṃ.meaning_2: those taken to and then brought back from a charnel ground
gatapaṭiyāgataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This term describes robes that were carried (gata) to a charnel ground and then returned (paṭiyāgata), fitting the Vinaya context of acceptable robe origins despite prior use.
gatapaṭiyāgataṃ.translation_1: (1) those chewed by cattle, (2) those chewed by goats, (3) those left at a stupa, (4) those discarded from a king’s consecration, (5) those taken to and then brought back from a charnel ground.

bhatapaṭiyābhataṃ.meaning_2: brought back to the army; returned to military service
bhatapaṭiyābhataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound likely from a Vinaya or military context, resolving to bhatapaṭi-ābhataṃ, with double sandhi across three morphemes: bhata (army) + paṭi (back) + ā (to) + bhata (army). The form is accusative neuter singular, possibly functioning adverbially or as a nominal phrase.

theyyāvahāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'theyyā' (instrumental of 'theyya' meaning theft) qualifies 'āvahāro' (a form of avahāra meaning removal), specifying the manner of removal as by theft, in the context of Vinaya offenses involving different modes of illicit removal.
theyyāvahāro.translation_1: removing by theft, removing by force, removing dependent on conditions, removing by concealing, removing by drawing lots. —

pasayhāvahāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound denotes a specific type of theft or removal accomplished through forceful means, as opposed to theft or other methods like concealing or drawing lots.
pasayhāvahāro.translation_1: removing by theft, removing by force, removing dependent on conditions, removing by concealing, removing by drawing lots. —

parikappāvahāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where parikappa (intention; plan; dependent on conditions) qualifies avahāro (removal), specifically denoting a type of removal in the context of monastic discipline that relies on contrived plans or conditional arrangements, as opposed to direct theft or force.
parikappāvahāro.translation_1: removing by theft, removing by force, removing dependent on conditions, removing by concealing, removing by drawing lots. —

paṭicchannāvahāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound denotes a specific method of removal or appropriation that involves concealment or hiding, as opposed to overt theft or force.
paṭicchannāvahāro.translation_1: removing by theft, removing by force, removing dependent on conditions, removing by concealing, removing by drawing lots. —

avissajjaniyāni.meaning_2: things not to be given away; things not to be released
avissajjaniyāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is neuter plural nominative/accusative, referring to the five categories of items (e.g., in monastic rules) that should not be relinquished or given away, as per the Vinaya context.
avissajjaniyāni.translation_1: There are five things not to be given away. —

pañcāpattiyo.meaning_2: group of five offenses; five kinds of offenses
pañcāpattiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given Vinaya contexts, pañcāpattiyo refers to specific sets of five offenses classified by their origination (from body only, from body and speech, or as confessable offenses), functioning as a collective noun in the nominative plural.
pañcāpattiyo.example_1: pañcāpattiyo kāyato samuṭṭhanti, na vācato na cittato.
pañcāpattiyo.translation_1: There are five kinds of offenses that originate from body, not from speech and mind. —
pañcāpattiyo.example_2: pañcāpattiyo kāyato ca vācato ca samuṭṭhanti, na cittato.
pañcāpattiyo.translation_2: There are five kinds of offenses that originate from body and speech, not from mind. —

pañcānisaṃsā.meaning_2: five benefits; five advantages; five good results
pañcānisaṃsā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term pañcānisaṃsā is a compound functioning as a nominative plural, denoting 'five benefits' in the contexts of various monastic practices and qualities, such as robe-making, sweeping, being inspiring, and expertise in the Vinaya.
pañcānisaṃsā.translation_1: There are five benefits of performing the robe-making ceremony. —
pañcānisaṃsā.translation_2: There are five benefits of sweeping:

kathinatthāre.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'kathinatthāre' is the locative singular of the compound 'kathinatthāra', referring to the act of performing or conducting the robe-making ceremony (kaṭhinatthāra), which is a monastic event in the Vinaya where robes are formally offered and received. The five benefits are associated with this ceremony.
kathinatthāre.translation_1: There are five benefits of performing the robe-making ceremony. —

akatātirittañca.meaning_2: not made left over; not prepared as leftovers; not set aside as remaining
akatātirittañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya sentence, this compound describes something that has not been intentionally prepared or set aside as leftovers, emphasizing its unsuitability for consumption due to lack of proper designation as remaining food.
akatātirittañca.example_1: adinnañca hoti, aviditañca hoti, akappiyañca hoti, appaṭiggahitañca hoti, akatātirittañca hoti.
akatātirittañca.translation_1: what has not been given, what is not known about, what is not allowable, what has not been received, what has not been made left over. —

katātirittañca.meaning_2: what has been made left over; prepared leftovers
katātirittañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'katātiritta' describes food or offerings that have been intentionally made or set aside as leftovers, fitting the Vinaya criteria for proper alms consumption. The compound combines the past participle 'kata' (done, made) with 'atiritta' (left over), implying deliberate preparation of remainders.
katātirittañca.example_1: dinnañca hoti, viditañca hoti, kappiyañca hoti, paṭiggahitañca hoti, katātirittañca hoti.
katātirittañca.translation_1: what has been given, what is known about, what is allowable, what has been received, what has been made left over. —

majjadānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, majjadānaṃ refers to the gift or offering of alcohol, listed alongside other types of gifts like entertainment and a woman, likely in a Vinaya context discussing inappropriate or specific forms of giving.
majjadānaṃ.translation_1: alcohol, entertainment, a woman, a bull, and a picture. —

samajjadānaṃ.meaning_2: entertainment; theatrical display; festival; fair; fete
samajjadānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the contextual list of unwholesome gifts, samajjadānaṃ refers to the offering of entertainment or a theatrical display, highlighting donations that lead to indulgence rather than merit.
samajjadānaṃ.translation_1: alcohol, entertainment, a woman, a bull, and a picture. —

itthidānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'itthidānaṃ' is listed as one of the five bad gifts (alongside alcohol, entertainment, a bull, and a picture), referring to the offering or gift of a woman, likely in a prohibitive sense in Vinaya literature.
itthidānaṃ.translation_1: alcohol, entertainment, a woman, a bull, and a picture. —

usabhadānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'usabhadānaṃ' refers to the offering or gift of a bull, listed among inappropriate or worldly gifts alongside alcohol, entertainment, a woman, and a picture.
usabhadānaṃ.translation_1: alcohol, entertainment, a woman, a bull, and a picture. —

cittakammadānaṃ.meaning_2: gift of a picture; gift of decorating
cittakammadānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the contextual list of gifts, 'cittakammadānaṃ' is translated as 'a picture', indicating a gift involving painting or decorative art, akin to offering visual or artistic items.
cittakammadānaṃ.translation_1: alcohol, entertainment, a woman, a bull, and a picture. —

vinodiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely instrumental singular of feminine noun vinodī, used to indicate means or manner in context, such as 'by bending' or 'through deflection'.

gamiyacittaṃ.meaning_2: thought of departing; intention to go
gamiyacittaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'uppannaṃ gamiyacittaṃ' refers to an arisen mental state of wanting to depart or go away, parallel to other difficult-to-remove mental phenomena like desire and ill will. The compound combines the potential participle 'gamiya' (fit to go) with 'citta' (thought/mind), indicating a directed intention.
gamiyacittaṃ.example_1: uppanno rāgo duppaṭivinodayo, uppanno doso duppaṭivinodayo, uppanno moho duppaṭivinodayo, uppannaṃ paṭibhānaṃ duppaṭivinodayaṃ, uppannaṃ gamiyacittaṃ duppaṭivinodayaṃ.
gamiyacittaṃ.translation_1: desire, ill will, confusion, feeling inspired to speak, and the thought of departing.

sakacittaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentences, sakacittaṃ refers to 'one’s own mind' which becomes serene (pasīdati) as a result of wholesome actions, contrasting with paracittaṃ 'the minds of others'.
sakacittaṃ.example_1: sakacittaṃ pasīdati, paracittaṃ pasīdati, devatā attamanā honti, pāsādikasaṃvattanikakammaṃ upacinati, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
sakacittaṃ.translation_1: (1) one’s own mind becomes serene, (2) the minds of others become serene, (3) the gods are pleased, (4) one accumulates actions that lead to being inspiring, (5) at the break-up of the body after death one is reborn in heaven.
sakacittaṃ.example_2: sakacittaṃ pasīdati, paracittaṃ pasīdati, devatā attamanā honti, satthusāsanaṃ kataṃ hoti, pacchimā janatā diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjati.
sakacittaṃ.translation_2: (1) one’s own mind becomes serene, (2) the minds of others become serene, (3) the gods are pleased, (4) one carries out the Teacher’s instruction, (5) later generations follow one’s example.

pāsādikasaṃvattanikakammaṃ.meaning_2: action that leads to being inspiring; action conducive to being charming
pāsādikasaṃvattanikakammaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, this compound refers to meritorious actions that contribute to serenity in oneself and others, pleasing the gods, and leading to rebirth in heaven.
pāsādikasaṃvattanikakammaṃ.example_1: sakacittaṃ pasīdati, paracittaṃ pasīdati, devatā attamanā honti, pāsādikasaṃvattanikakammaṃ upacinati, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
pāsādikasaṃvattanikakammaṃ.translation_1: (1) one’s own mind becomes serene, (2) the minds of others become serene, (3) the gods are pleased, (4) one accumulates actions that lead to being inspiring, (5) at the break-up of the body after death one is reborn in heaven.

upacinati.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'pāsādikasaṃvattanikakammaṃ upacinati' means one accumulates meritorious actions that lead to a serene and inspiring state, contributing to rebirth in a good destination.
upacinati.example_1: sakacittaṃ pasīdati, paracittaṃ pasīdati, devatā attamanā honti, pāsādikasaṃvattanikakammaṃ upacinati, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
upacinati.translation_1: (1) one’s own mind becomes serene, (2) the minds of others become serene, (3) the gods are pleased, (4) one accumulates actions that lead to being inspiring, (5) at the break-up of the body after death one is reborn in heaven.

bhāsapariyantaṃ.meaning_2: limit of speech; what is proper to say; boundary of language
bhāsapariyantaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, bhāsapariyantaṃ refers to the appropriate limits or bounds of speech in monastic procedures, such as what one may legitimately say in formal acts (e.g., confessions or ordinations). The accusative form indicates the object of 'grasping' or 'not grasping' (uggaṇhāti/na uggaṇhāti), emphasizing discernment of propriety for oneself (attano) or others (parassa) to avoid illegitimate actions (adhammena kāreti).
bhāsapariyantaṃ.example_1: attano bhāsapariyantaṃ na uggaṇhāti, parassa bhāsapariyantaṃ na uggaṇhāti, attano bhāsapariyantaṃ na uggahetvā parassa bhāsapariyantaṃ na uggahetvā adhammena kāreti appaṭiññāya.
bhāsapariyantaṃ.translation_1: (1) he does not grasp what is proper for himself to say; (2) he does not grasp what is proper for others to say; (3-5) not grasping either, he makes them act illegitimately, without their admission.
bhāsapariyantaṃ.example_2: attano bhāsapariyantaṃ na uggaṇhāti, parassa bhāsapariyantaṃ na uggaṇhāti, attano bhāsapariyantaṃ na uggahetvā parassa bhāsapariyantaṃ na uggahetvā adhammena kāreti appaṭiññāya.
bhāsapariyantaṃ.translation_2: (1) he does not grasp what is proper for himself to say; (2) he does not grasp what is proper for others to say; (3-5) not grasping either, he makes them act illegitimately, without their admission.

āpattisamudayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of Vinaya texts, āpattisamudaya refers to the causal arising or origin of offenses, paralleling the Four Noble Truths structure where it denotes the 'origination' of dukkha, here applied to transgressions. It appears in enumerations of knowledge required for proper adjudication.
āpattisamudayaṃ.example_1: āpattiṃ na jānāti, āpattiyā mūlaṃ na jānāti, āpattisamudayaṃ na jānāti, āpattinirodhaṃ na jānāti, āpattinirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ na jānāti.
āpattisamudayaṃ.translation_1: (1) he does not know the offenses; (2) he does not know the roots of the offenses; (3) he does not know the origins of the offenses; (4) he does not know the ending of the offenses; (5) he does not know the path leading to the ending of the offenses.
āpattisamudayaṃ.example_2: āpattiṃ jānāti, āpattiyā mūlaṃ jānāti, āpattisamudayaṃ jānāti, āpattinirodhaṃ jānāti, āpattinirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ jānāti.
āpattisamudayaṃ.translation_2: (1) he knows the offenses; (2) he knows the roots of the offenses; (3) he knows the origins of the offenses; (4) he knows the ending of the offenses; (5) he knows the path leading to the ending of the offenses.

āpattinirodhaṃ.meaning_2: ending of the offense; cessation of wrongdoing; termination of transgression
āpattinirodhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, āpattinirodhaṃ refers to the knowledge of how offenses cease or are terminated, paralleling the Four Noble Truths structure applied to vinaya offenses: understanding the offense, its cause, its cessation, and the path to that cessation.
āpattinirodhaṃ.example_1: āpattiṃ na jānāti, āpattiyā mūlaṃ na jānāti, āpattisamudayaṃ na jānāti, āpattinirodhaṃ na jānāti, āpattinirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ na jānāti.
āpattinirodhaṃ.translation_1: (1) he does not know the offenses; (2) he does not know the roots of the offenses; (3) he does not know the origins of the offenses; (4) he does not know the ending of the offenses; (5) he does not know the path leading to the ending of the offenses.
āpattinirodhaṃ.example_2: āpattiṃ jānāti, āpattiyā mūlaṃ jānāti, āpattisamudayaṃ jānāti, āpattinirodhaṃ jānāti, āpattinirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ jānāti.
āpattinirodhaṃ.translation_2: (1) he knows the offenses; (2) he knows the roots of the offenses; (3) he knows the origins of the offenses; (4) he knows the ending of the offenses; (5) he knows the path leading to the ending of the offenses.

āpattinirodhagāminiṃ.meaning_2: path leading to the ending of offenses; practice going to the cessation of transgressions
āpattinirodhagāminiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound noun appears in accusative singular feminine, modifying 'paṭipadaṃ' (path/practice). In the context of the sentences, it describes the noble eightfold path or ethical practice that leads to the complete cessation of offenses (āpatti), paralleling the Four Noble Truths structure applied to wrongdoing in Vinaya contexts.
āpattinirodhagāminiṃ.example_1: āpattiṃ na jānāti, āpattiyā mūlaṃ na jānāti, āpattisamudayaṃ na jānāti, āpattinirodhaṃ na jānāti, āpattinirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ na jānāti.
āpattinirodhagāminiṃ.translation_1: (1) he does not know the offenses; (2) he does not know the roots of the offenses; (3) he does not know the origins of the offenses; (4) he does not know the ending of the offenses; (5) he does not know the path leading to the ending of the offenses.
āpattinirodhagāminiṃ.example_2: āpattiṃ jānāti, āpattiyā mūlaṃ jānāti, āpattisamudayaṃ jānāti, āpattinirodhaṃ jānāti, āpattinirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ jānāti.
āpattinirodhagāminiṃ.translation_2: (1) he knows the offenses; (2) he knows the roots of the offenses; (3) he knows the origins of the offenses; (4) he knows the ending of the offenses; (5) he knows the path leading to the ending of the offenses.

anusandhivacanapathaṃ.meaning_2: sequence of statements; connected path of expressions
anusandhivacanapathaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound refers to the orderly sequence or logical flow of statements within the monastic code, essential for proper recitation and interpretation of the rules. It combines 'anusandhi' (connection or sequence) with 'vacanapatha' (path of speech), emphasizing the linked arrangement of textual elements.
anusandhivacanapathaṃ.example_1: vatthuṃ na jānāti, nidānaṃ na jānāti, paññattiṃ na jānāti, anupaññattiṃ na jānāti, anusandhivacanapathaṃ na jānāti.
anusandhivacanapathaṃ.translation_1: (1) he does not know the actions that are the bases for offenses; (2) he does not know the origin stories; (3) he does not know the rules; (4) he does not know the additions to the rules; (5) he does not know the sequence of statements.
anusandhivacanapathaṃ.example_2: vatthuṃ jānāti, nidānaṃ jānāti, paññattiṃ jānāti, anupaññattiṃ jānāti, anusandhivacanapathaṃ jānāti.
anusandhivacanapathaṃ.translation_2: (1) he knows the actions that are the bases for offenses; (2) he knows the origin stories; (3) he knows the rules; (4) he knows the additions to the rules; (5) he knows the sequence of statements.

pubbakusalo.meaning_2: skilled in what comes first; skilled in preliminaries
pubbakusalo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'pubbakusalo' refers to expertise in the preliminary aspects of monastic procedures, such as knowing the proper sequence before a formal motion (ñatti), contrasting with 'aparakusalo' for subsequent steps. The compound combines 'pubba' (previous, earlier) with 'kusala' (skilled in), emphasizing procedural foresight.
pubbakusalo.example_1: ñattiṃ na jānāti, ñattiyā karaṇaṃ na jānāti, na pubbakusalo hoti, na aparakusalo hoti, akālaññū ca hoti.
pubbakusalo.translation_1: (1) he does not know the motion; (2) he does not know how the motion is done; (3) he is not skilled in what comes first; (4) he is not skilled in what comes afterwards; (5) he does not know the right time.
pubbakusalo.example_2: ñattiṃ jānāti, ñattiyā karaṇaṃ jānāti, pubbakusalo hoti, aparakusalo hoti, kālaññū ca hoti.
pubbakusalo.translation_2: (1) he knows the motion; (2) he knows how the motion is done; (3) he is skilled in what comes first; (4) he is skilled in what comes afterwards; (5) he knows the right time.

aparakusalo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of Vinaya, aparakusalo describes a monk who is competent or expert in the subsequent aspects of monastic procedures, contrasting with pubbakusalo (skilled in what precedes). The compound combines 'apara' (later, subsequent) with 'kusala' (skilled in), emphasizing procedural knowledge in formal acts like the Pātimokkha recitation.
aparakusalo.example_1: ñattiṃ na jānāti, ñattiyā karaṇaṃ na jānāti, na pubbakusalo hoti, na aparakusalo hoti, akālaññū ca hoti.
aparakusalo.translation_1: (1) he does not know the motion; (2) he does not know how the motion is done; (3) he is not skilled in what comes first; (4) he is not skilled in what comes afterwards; (5) he does not know the right time.
aparakusalo.example_2: ñattiṃ jānāti, ñattiyā karaṇaṃ jānāti, pubbakusalo hoti, aparakusalo hoti, kālaññū ca hoti.
aparakusalo.translation_2: (1) he knows the motion; (2) he knows how the motion is done; (3) he is skilled in what comes first; (4) he is skilled in what comes afterwards; (5) he knows the right time.

āpattānāpattiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where āpatti (offense) and anāpatti (non-offense) are coordinated to denote the distinction between rule violations and non-violations in the Vinaya context, as seen throughout the provided sentences where it consistently refers to knowledge of what constitutes an offense versus what does not.
āpattānāpattiṃ.example_1: āpattānāpattiṃ na jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, ācariyaparamparā kho panassa na suggahitā hoti na sumanasikatā na sūpadhāritā.
āpattānāpattiṃ.translation_1: (1) he does not know the offenses and non-offenses; (2) he does not know the light and heavy offenses; (3) he does not know the curable and incurable offenses; (4) he does not know the grave and minor offenses; (5) he has not well-learned and well-remembered his teachers’ tradition.
āpattānāpattiṃ.example_2: āpattānāpattiṃ jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ jānati, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, ācariyaparamparā kho panassa suggahitā hoti sumanasikatā sūpadhāritā.
āpattānāpattiṃ.translation_2: (1) he knows the offenses and non-offenses; (2) he knows the light and heavy offenses; (3) he knows the curable and incurable offenses; (4) he knows the grave and minor offenses; (5) he has well-learned and well-remembered his teachers’ tradition.

lahukagarukaṃ.meaning_2: light and heavy; minor and serious offenses
lahukagarukaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound specifically refers to the classification of offenses as light (lahuka: minor, less serious) versus heavy (garuka: grave, more serious), essential for understanding disciplinary procedures and the monk's or nun's knowledge of the monastic code.
lahukagarukaṃ.example_1: āpattānāpattiṃ na jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, ācariyaparamparā kho panassa na suggahitā hoti na sumanasikatā na sūpadhāritā.
lahukagarukaṃ.translation_1: (1) he does not know the offenses and non-offenses; (2) he does not know the light and heavy offenses; (3) he does not know the curable and incurable offenses; (4) he does not know the grave and minor offenses; (5) he has not well-learned and well-remembered his teachers’ tradition.
lahukagarukaṃ.example_2: āpattānāpattiṃ jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ jānati, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, ācariyaparamparā kho panassa suggahitā hoti sumanasikatā sūpadhāritā.
lahukagarukaṃ.translation_2: (1) he knows the offenses and non-offenses; (2) he knows the light and heavy offenses; (3) he knows the curable and incurable offenses; (4) he knows the grave and minor offenses; (5) he has well-learned and well-remembered his teachers’ tradition.

sāvasesānavasesaṃ.meaning_2: (of offenses) curable and incurable; remediable and irremediable
sāvasesānavasesaṃ.construction: sa + ava + √sis > ses + *a + na + ava + √sis > ses + *a + aṃ
sāvasesānavasesaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound adjective describes the distinction between offenses that can be remedied (sāvasesa, lit. 'with remainder') and those that cannot (anavasesa, lit. 'without remainder'). In the Vinaya context, it refers to offenses that can be cleared through confession or amends versus those that are permanent or irreparable, such as expulsion. The accusative singular form agrees with āpattiṃ in the sentence.
sāvasesānavasesaṃ.example_1: āpattānāpattiṃ na jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, ācariyaparamparā kho panassa na suggahitā hoti na sumanasikatā na sūpadhāritā.
sāvasesānavasesaṃ.translation_1: (1) he does not know the offenses and non-offenses; (2) he does not know the light and heavy offenses; (3) he does not know the curable and incurable offenses; (4) he does not know the grave and minor offenses; (5) he has not well-learned and well-remembered his teachers’ tradition.
sāvasesānavasesaṃ.example_2: āpattānāpattiṃ jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ jānati, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, ācariyaparamparā kho panassa suggahitā hoti sumanasikatā sūpadhāritā.
sāvasesānavasesaṃ.translation_2: (1) he knows the offenses and non-offenses; (2) he knows the light and heavy offenses; (3) he knows the curable and incurable offenses; (4) he knows the grave and minor offenses; (5) he has well-learned and well-remembered his teachers’ tradition.

paṇḍitotveva.meaning_2: as learned; indeed as a learned one
paṇḍitotveva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial compound formed from 'paṇḍita' (learned) + 'utu' (abstract suffix indicating state or condition, here 'as a learned one') + 'eva' (indeed). In the context, it specifies that the monk possessing the five qualities is regarded precisely as learned, emphasizing the certainty or exclusivity of this attribution.
paṇḍitotveva.example_1: pañcahupāli, aṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu paṇḍitotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
paṇḍitotveva.translation_1: But a monk who has five qualities is considered learned:
paṇḍitotveva.example_2: imehi kho, upāli, pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu paṇḍitotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.

vinicchayakusalo.meaning_2: skilled in deciding; competent in adjudication; expert in passing judgement
vinicchayakusalo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound vinicchayakusalo refers to expertise in making decisions or verdicts, particularly in monastic legal matters (adhikaraṇa). In the context of the sentences, it contrasts with akusala (unskilled), describing a monk's proficiency in resolving disputes and offenses according to the Pātimokkha rules.
vinicchayakusalo.example_1: āpattānāpattiṃ na jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, adhikaraṇe ca na vinicchayakusalo hoti.
vinicchayakusalo.translation_1: (1) he does not know the offenses and non-offenses; (2) he does not know the light and heavy offenses; (3) he does not know the curable and incurable offenses; (4) he does not know the grave and minor offenses; (5) he is not skilled in deciding legal issues.
vinicchayakusalo.example_2: āpattānāpattiṃ jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, adhikaraṇe ca vinicchayakusalo hoti.
vinicchayakusalo.translation_2: (1) he knows the offenses and non-offenses; (2) he knows the light and heavy offenses; (3) he knows the curable and incurable offenses; (4) he knows the grave and minor offenses; (5) he is skilled in deciding legal issues.

nānissitena.meaning_2: without formal support; without reliance (in the context of a monk's living situation, indicating unsupported or independent living which is advised against under certain qualities)
nānissitena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'nānissitena' describes a state of living without the formal support or reliance typically required for monks possessing certain qualities; the prefix 'nā-' (before vowel) intensifies the negation of 'nissita' (reliant), emphasizing unsupported living that is prohibited for life in these cases.
nānissitena.translation_1: When a monk has five qualities, he should not live without formal support:
nānissitena.example_2: aparehipi pañcahaṅgehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā nānissitena vatthabbaṃ—
nānissitena.translation_2: When a monk has five other qualities, he should not live without formal support:

nānissitāya.meaning_2: without formal support; unsupported (by the community)
nānissitāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'nānissitāya' refers to a nun living without formal ecclesiastical support or dependence on the community, which is prohibited when she possesses the specified qualities. The form is an emphatic variant of 'anissitāya' using 'nā' for 'na', common in certain compounds to avoid vowel sandhi issues.
nānissitāya.translation_1: When a nun has five qualities, she should not live without formal support:
nānissitāya.example_2: aparehipi pañcahaṅgehi samannāgatāya bhikkhuniyā nānissitāya vatthabbaṃ—
nānissitāya.translation_2: When a nun has five other qualities, she should not live without formal support:

aggiparijitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, aggiparijitaṃ refers to a seed that has been damaged or scorched by fire, as the first in a list of five types of unusable or invalid seeds in a Vinaya rule.
aggiparijitaṃ.example_1: aggiparijitaṃ, satthaparijitaṃ, nakhaparijitaṃ, abījaṃ, nibbattabījaññeva pañcamaṃ.
aggiparijitaṃ.translation_1: (1) it has been damaged by fire, (2) it has been damaged by a knife, (3) it has been damaged by a fingernail, (4) it’s seedless, (5) the seeds have been removed.

satthaparijitaṃ.meaning_2: damaged by a knife; cut by a weapon
satthaparijitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, satthaparijitaṃ describes a seed that has been damaged or cut by a knife or weapon (sattha), as one of the conditions for invalidating a seed in Vinaya rules.
satthaparijitaṃ.example_1: aggiparijitaṃ, satthaparijitaṃ, nakhaparijitaṃ, abījaṃ, nibbattabījaññeva pañcamaṃ.
satthaparijitaṃ.translation_1: (1) it has been damaged by fire, (2) it has been damaged by a knife, (3) it has been damaged by a fingernail, (4) it’s seedless, (5) the seeds have been removed.

nakhaparijitaṃ.meaning_2: damaged by a fingernail; scratched by nails
nakhaparijitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, nakhaparijitaṃ refers to something damaged or scratched by a fingernail, listed alongside other forms of damage in a legal or classificatory enumeration, likely from Vinaya texts on invalidating conditions.
nakhaparijitaṃ.example_1: aggiparijitaṃ, satthaparijitaṃ, nakhaparijitaṃ, abījaṃ, nibbattabījaññeva pañcamaṃ.
nakhaparijitaṃ.translation_1: (1) it has been damaged by fire, (2) it has been damaged by a knife, (3) it has been damaged by a fingernail, (4) it’s seedless, (5) the seeds have been removed.

nibbaṭabījaññeva.meaning_2: knowledge of the seed of rebirth
nibbaṭabījaññeva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Refers to the understanding or knowledge concerning the 'seed' or cause of rebirth (nibbatabīja), likely in a doctrinal context of Buddhist soteriology where such knowledge aids in liberation.

nippaṭṭabījaññeva.meaning_2: non-arising of the seed; absence of the seed of becoming
nippaṭṭabījaññeva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'the non-knowledge/ignorance of the arisen seed,' referring to the absence of the latent seed of rebirth or becoming in the context of enlightenment or liberation.

suttuddeso.meaning_2: observance-day ceremony which consists of reciting the Monastic Code; recitation of the suttas
suttuddeso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'suttuddeso' refers to the first type of uposatha ceremony involving the recitation or chanting of the suttas (likely the Pātimokkha rules in the Monastic Code). The compound combines 'sutta' (possibly from uddesa sense of 'recitation' or 'rules') with 'uddesa' (recitation, chanting, or Pātimokkha rules).
suttuddeso.example_1: suttuddeso, pārisuddhiuposatho, adhiṭṭhānuposatho, pavāraṇā, sāmaggīuposathoyeva pañcamo.
suttuddeso.translation_1: (1) the observance-day ceremony which consists of reciting the Monastic Code, (2) the observance-day ceremony which consists of declaring purity, (3) the observance-day ceremony which consists of a determination, (4) the invitation ceremony, (5) the observance-day ceremony for the sake of unity as the fifth.

sāmaggīuposathoyeva.meaning_2: observance-day ceremony for the sake of unity
sāmaggīuposathoyeva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound noun refers to the fifth type of uposatha ceremony in the Vinaya context, specifically aimed at promoting harmony and reconciliation among the monastic community, as indicated by the English translation 'the observance-day ceremony for the sake of unity'.
sāmaggīuposathoyeva.example_1: suttuddeso, pārisuddhiuposatho, adhiṭṭhānuposatho, pavāraṇā, sāmaggīuposathoyeva pañcamo.
sāmaggīuposathoyeva.translation_1: (1) the observance-day ceremony which consists of reciting the Monastic Code, (2) the observance-day ceremony which consists of declaring purity, (3) the observance-day ceremony which consists of a determination, (4) the invitation ceremony, (5) the observance-day ceremony for the sake of unity as the fifth.

vinītānantarena.grammar: ind, adv, instr sg of vinītānantara
vinītānantarena.meaning_2: by training and the next life; by means of the intermediate state of discipline and rebirth
vinītānantarena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is an adverbial instrumental singular of the compound vinītānantara, where vinīta ('trained, disciplined') modifies antara ('interval, intermediate'). In context, it likely refers to the disciplinary training in this life and the intermediate state leading to the next life, aligning with the English translation.
vinītānantarena.translation_1: Training, and with the next life;

kappantusaṅkitelañca.construction: kapp + an + tu + saṅkit + e + lana + ca
kappantusaṅkitelañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound or sequence representing 'kappantu saṅkite lana ca', where 'kappantu' is an optative form of kappati (may it be allowable), 'saṅkite' is locative singular of saṅkita (in the suspected), 'lana' is a form related to ela (offence or possibly a variant), and 'ca' (and). The English translation suggests a list: allowable, suspected, and oil, possibly interpreting 'ela' or 'lana' as related to 'tela' (oil) in a Vinaya context of allowable items. However, based on entries, 'tela' fits the oil meaning better, indicating potential scribal or interpretive variation in 'elañca' for 'telañca'.

avissajji.meaning_2: not to be given away; not to be shared out; not to be distributed
avissajji.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'avissajji' describes property or items that cannot be given away or distributed, as in the case of communal exclusion where such items are not to be shared.
avissajji.translation_1: Not to be given away, not to be shared out,
avissajji.translation_2: “Excluded from the community, not to be given away,

avebhaṅgi.meaning_2: not to be divided; not to be broken up; not to be shared out
avebhaṅgi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'avissajji avebhaṅgi', it parallels 'avissajji' meaning 'not to be given away', indicating a prohibition on dividing or distributing, likely referring to monastic property or precepts that must remain undivided.
avebhaṅgi.translation_1: Not to be given away, not to be shared out,

kāyavācato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the compound 'kāyavāca', used in the ablative sense 'from body and speech' in the context of the sentence, indicating origin or source involving physical actions and verbal expressions.
kāyavācato.translation_1: From body, from body and speech.

paccantikathinena.meaning_2: outer robe-making ceremony; ceremony for making robes outside the monastery
paccantikathinena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound adjective used substantively, referring to the kathina ceremony performed outside the monastery, as indicated by the context 'Outside, and with the robe-making ceremony'. This contrasts with the standard kathina held within the monastery boundaries.
paccantikathinena.translation_1: Outside, and with the robe-making ceremony;

pārājithulladukkaṭaṃ.meaning_2: an offense entailing expulsion, a serious offense, an offense of wrong conduct
pārājithulladukkaṭaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound in the Vinaya context, combining elements for types of monastic offenses: 'pārājika' (entailing expulsion), 'thulla' (serious), and 'dukkaṭa' (wrong-doing). The neuter accusative singular form matches the sentence structure, likely as the object of an implied verb.
pārājithulladukkaṭaṃ.translation_1: An offense entailing expulsion, a serious offense, an offense of wrong conduct.

apuññaduvinodayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound functions as an indeclinable adjective or adverbial phrase describing something (likely dukkha or a similar concept) that lacks merit and is difficult to dispel, based on the English translation.

lahukaṭṭhamakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'lahukaṭṭhamakā ete' translated as 'These are light and strong,' the compound describes objects (likely masculine plural nominative) that are both lightweight (lahuka) and robust or firm (aṭṭhamaka, from aṭṭha 'strong'). The adjective aṭṭhamaka, derived from aṭṭha 'strength' or 'eight,' here conveys solidity or endurance, complementing the lightness.

paṃsurukkhasusānikā.meaning_2: rag-robe; tree; people who live in charnel grounds
paṃsurukkhasusānikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a dvanda compound listing three types of dwellings or possessions for ascetics: rag-robes (paṃsu, lit. 'dust', referring to robes made from discarded cloth), trees (rukkha), and charnel grounds (susānikā, lit. 'good cemetery-dwellers'). The English translation interprets it as 'rag-robe, tree, people who live in charnel grounds', suggesting the last part refers to the ascetics themselves rather than the location.
paṃsurukkhasusānikā.translation_1: Rag-robe, tree, people who live in charnel grounds;

nisajjiko.meaning_2: one who sits; one who never lies down
nisajjiko.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of sapadāno nisajjiko, nisajjiko describes someone who remains continuously in a sitting position, never reclining, emphasizing disciplined posture in monastic life.
nisajjiko.translation_1: Continuous, one who never lies down.

āpattānāpattipi.meaning_2: offenses and non-offenses; transgression and non-transgression
āpattānāpattipi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound linking 'āpatti' (offense, neuter) and 'anāpatti' (non-offense, feminine) with 'api' (and also). In the Vinaya context of the sentence, it enumerates both categories of actions—those that constitute offenses and those that do not—for legal or disciplinary discussion.

kaṇhasukkapadā.meaning_2: verses on dark and bright; verses on black and white
kaṇhasukkapadā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'kaṇhasukkapadā' refers to verses or stanzas (pada) dealing with the themes of dark (kaṇha, negative or unwholesome actions) and bright (sukka, positive or wholesome actions), likely alluding to the Dhammapada or similar poetic sections contrasting moral paths.
kaṇhasukkapadā.translation_1: These verses on dark and bright,

apāsādikapāsādi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a dvanda compound (coordination) where 'apāsādika' means 'uninspiring, not pleasing' and 'pāsādi' is a bahuvrīhi compound meaning 'having inspiration' or 'characterized by inspiration,' derived from 'pāsada' (inspiration, confidence). The 'ādi' indicates 'and so on,' extending the list of qualities related to lack of or presence of inspiration in a contextual sense of emotional or motivational states.

samaṇakappi.meaning_2: allowable for ascetics; suitable for monastics
samaṇakappi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound samaṇakappi modifies bījaṃ ('seed' or 'propagation') in the context of the Vinaya, indicating that propagation is permitted or allowable for samaṇas (monks or ascetics).

vinayādhammikena.meaning_2: according to the monastic law; legitimate in terms of vinaya; not against the disciplinary code
vinayādhammikena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental singular form of a sandhi compound 'vinayādhammika', where 'vinayā' (genitive or possessive of 'vinaya') modifies 'dhammika', meaning 'conforming to the monastic law'. In the context, it contrasts with 'adhammikena' ('illegitimate'), indicating actions or matters that align with the disciplinary rules of the monastic order.

suddhipañcakāti.meaning_2: the pentad of purity; basic section on fives
suddhipañcakāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound suddhipañcaka refers to a group of five related to purity or purification, marking the completion of a textual section on such pentads in the Pāḷi canon. The iti particle quotatively closes the statement, indicating 'this is the end of the suddhipañcaka.'
suddhipañcakāti.translation_1: The basic section on fives is finished.”

chakkavāro.meaning_2: sixfold repetition; group of six occasions
chakkavāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'chakka' (group of six) with 'vāra' (occasion or turn), likely denoting a sequence or cycle of six instances, common in Pāli texts for enumerating repetitive events or disciplinary cases.

chacchedanakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form chacchedanakā is the nominative plural of a neuter compound noun, agreeing with āpattiyo in the sentence. It refers to six specific types of offenses in the Vinaya that involve acts of cutting or severing, such as cutting plants or robes.
chacchedanakā.translation_1: There are six offenses involving cutting. —

chānisaṃsā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'chānisaṃsā vinayadhare', this is the nominative plural form of a compound meaning 'six benefits', referring to the six advantages or profits of being an expert on the Monastic Law (Vinaya), as translated in the English sentence.
chānisaṃsā.translation_1: There are six benefits of being an expert on the Monastic Law. —

paññakkhandhena.meaning_2: aggregate of wisdom; collection of understanding; group of insight
paññakkhandhena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, paññakkhandhena refers to the complete aggregate or collection of wisdom belonging to an asekha (one beyond training), as part of the fivefold endowment of an arahant, emphasizing perfected insight into the Dhamma.
paññakkhandhena.example_1: asekkhena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato hoti, asekkhena samādhikkhandhena samannāgato hoti, asekkhena paññakkhandhena samannāgato hoti, asekkhena vimuttikkhandhena samannāgato hoti, asekkhena vimuttiñāṇadassanakkhandhena samannāgato hoti, dasavasso vā hoti atirekadasavasso vā.
paññakkhandhena.translation_1: he has (1) the virtue, (2) stillness, (3) wisdom, (4) freedom, and (5) the knowledge and vision of freedom of one who is fully trained, and (6) he has ten or more years of seniority.
paññakkhandhena.example_2: attanā asekkhena paññakkhandhena samannāgato hoti, paraṃ asekkhe paññakkhandhe samādapetā;
paññakkhandhena.translation_2: (3) he has the wisdom of one who is fully trained himself and encourages others in it;

paññakkhandhe.meaning_2: aggregate of wisdom; collection of wisdom; mass of knowledge
paññakkhandhe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given context, 'paññakkhandha' refers to the comprehensive aggregate or totality of wisdom attained by an arahant (one who is fully trained, asekkha), emphasizing the complete development of insight and understanding in the path to enlightenment. The term parallels the five aggregates (khandhā) in Buddhist doctrine, here specifically denoting wisdom as a foundational element.
paññakkhandhe.example_1: attanā asekkhena paññakkhandhena samannāgato hoti, paraṃ asekkhe paññakkhandhe samādapetā;
paññakkhandhe.translation_1: (3) he has the wisdom of one who is fully trained himself and encourages others in it;

ādibrahmacāriyakāya.meaning_2: basics of the spiritual life; fundamentals of the holy life; initial training in celibacy
ādibrahmacāriyakāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'ādibrahmacāriyakāya sikkhāya' refers to the foundational training in the holy life (brahmacariya), paralleling 'abhisamācārikāya sikkhāya' (good conduct) as the initial stages of monastic instruction, distinct from higher trainings like adhisīla, adhicitta, adhipaññā.
ādibrahmacāriyakāya.example_1: paṭibalo hoti antevāsiṃ vā saddhivihāriṃ vā ābhisamācārikāya sikkhāya sikkhāpetuṃ, ādibrahmacāriyakāya sikkhāya vinetuṃ, abhidhamme vinetuṃ, abhivinaye vinetuṃ, uppannaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ dhammato vivecetuṃ, dasavasso vā hoti atirekadasavasso vā.
