ādibrahmacāriyakāya.translation_1: he is capable of five things in regard to a student: (1) to train him in good conduct; (2) to train him in the basics of the spiritual life; (3) to train him in the Teaching; (4) to train him in the Monastic Law; and (5) to use the Teaching to make him give up wrong views. And (6) he has ten or more years of seniority.
ādibrahmacāriyakāya.example_2: na paṭibalo hoti antevāsiṃ vā saddhivihāriṃ vā abhisamācārikāya sikkhāya sikkhāpetuṃ, ādibrahmacāriyakāya sikkhāya vinetuṃ, adhisīle vinetuṃ, adhicitte vinetuṃ, adhipaññāya vinetuṃ—
ādibrahmacāriyakāya.translation_2: He’s incapable of five things in regard to a student: (1) of training him in good conduct; (2) of training him in the basics of the spiritual life; (3) of training him in the higher morality; (4) of training him in the higher mind; (5) of training him in the higher wisdom.

ākārānisaṃsena.meaning_2: with ways and benefits; by manner and advantage
ākārānisaṃsena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the tatpuruṣa compound ākārānisaṃsa, used in the context to denote accompanying aspects or manners along with their benefits or advantages.

kāyavācācittato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Ablative form of the compound kāyavācācitta, denoting origin or source in the context of ethical actions or karma arising from physical, verbal, and mental faculties.
kāyavācācittato.translation_1: And from body, speech and mind,

kammavivādameva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'kammavivādameva ca' refers to legal procedures and disputes in the Vinaya sense, where 'kamma' denotes formal legal acts and 'vivāda' indicates contention or argument, combined to signify matters of legal contention.

gilānābhisamācārī.meaning_2: one of good conduct despite sickness; behaving well while ill
gilānābhisamācārī.construction: gilāna + abhi + sam + ā + cār + ī
gilānābhisamācārī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound gilānābhisamācārī describes a person who maintains good conduct (abhisamācārī) even when sick (gilāna), as reflected in the English gloss 'Sick, good conduct'. Here, abhisamācārī likely functions as a tatpuruṣa compound with abhi- (towards, perfecting) + samācārī (good conduct), emphasizing proper behavior in the context of illness.

āpattādhammadhammikāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound enumerating categories in a legal or doctrinal context, likely from Vinaya texts, where āpattā refers to offenses, adhamma to what is contrary to dhamma (illegitimate), and dhammika to what accords with dhamma (legitimate), with iti marking the end of the list or explanation.

sattakavāro.meaning_2: section on the septet; chapter concerning the group of seven
sattakavāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound likely refers to a specific section or chapter in a Pāḷi text dealing with the concept of a 'septet' or group of seven, common in Buddhist enumerations such as the seven factors of enlightenment.

sattāpattiyo.meaning_2: kinds of offenses; types of wrongdoing
sattāpattiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form used in the sentence to indicate 'seven kinds of offenses' in a Vinaya context, where āpatti specifically denotes monastic transgressions.

sattāpattikkhandhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term refers to the sevenfold classification of offenses (āpatti) in the Vinaya Piṭaka, serving as the foundational categories for legal issues arising from transgressions within the monastic community.
sattāpattikkhandhā.translation_1: There are seven classes of offenses. —
sattāpattikkhandhā.example_2: vivādādhikaraṇassa aṭṭhārasabhedakaravatthūni samuṭṭhānā, anuvādādhikaraṇassa catasso vipattiyo samuṭṭhānā, āpattādhikaraṇassa sattāpattikkhandhā samuṭṭhānā, kiccādhikaraṇassa cattāri kammāni samuṭṭhānā—
sattāpattikkhandhā.translation_2: Legal issues arising from disputes originate from the eighteen grounds for schism; legal issues arising from accusations originate from the four kinds of failure; legal issues arising from offenses originate from the seven classes of offenses; legal issues arising from business originate from the four kinds of legal procedures.

aruṇasamathena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the compound aruṇasamatha, used in context to indicate 'with the settling of dawn', combining the reddish dawn light with the concept of calming or settling, likely poetic reference to the tranquil onset of daybreak.

catubhikkhū.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound 'catubhikkhū' is in the nominative plural form, referring to four shining monks in the context of the sentence 'And four about monks who shine,' where 'sobhane' indicates their resplendent or virtuous quality.
catubhikkhū.translation_1: And four about monks who shine;

aṭṭhakavāro.meaning_2: chapter on the octad; section on the group of eight
aṭṭhakavāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound aṭṭhakavāro likely refers to a specific chapter or section titled 'The Octad' in a Pāḷi text, such as the Aṭṭhakavagga in the Sutta Nipāta, where aṭṭhaka denotes a group or poem of eight stanzas, and vāra indicates a section or chapter. Without the sentence context, this is the most fitting interpretation based on common usage in Buddhist literature.

dūteyyaṅgāni.meaning_2: quality of a qualified messenger; factor of a messenger
dūteyyaṅgāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term refers to the eight specific qualities or factors that define a qualified messenger (dūta) in the context of Buddhist texts, particularly in diplomatic or instructional scenarios where messengers convey the Buddha's teachings accurately and respectfully.
dūteyyaṅgāni.translation_1: There are eight qualities of a qualified messenger. —
dūteyyaṅgāni.translation_2: How many qualities does a qualified messenger have?

titthiyavattāni.meaning_2: proper conduct; customary practice of monastics of other religions
titthiyavattāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'aṭṭha titthiyavattāni', the term refers to the eight specific disciplinary or behavioral practices observed by ascetics or monastics from non-Buddhist sects, highlighting a Vinaya discussion on contrasting religious observances.
titthiyavattāni.translation_1: There are eight proper conducts of monastics of other religions. —

yāvatatiyadūsanā.meaning_2: corrupting as far as the third time; third-time corruption
yāvatatiyadūsanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'yāvatatiya' (as far as the third time) modifies 'dūsanā' (corrupting). In the Vinaya context, it refers to the act of corrupting or violating up to the third offense, often in monastic disciplinary rules.

kathinubbhārā.meaning_2: the end of the kathina (robe) season; withdrawal of kathina privileges
kathinubbhārā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'kathinubbhārā' refers to the termination of the kathina period, during which monks enjoy special allowances for robe-making after the rains retreat. The instrumental case indicates 'by the ending of the kathina season' or 'with the kathina coming to an end'.
kathinubbhārā.translation_1: Key phrases, the robe season coming to an end,

dūtaṅgā.meaning_2: quality of a qualified messenger; factor of an envoy
dūtaṅgā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'dūtaṅgā' refers to the essential qualities or attributes that make a messenger suitable for their role, paralleling 'uposathā' as observance days.
dūtaṅgā.translation_1: And observance days, qualities of a qualified messenger,

pārājikaṭṭhamaṃ.meaning_2: offense entailing expulsion, parts; case of the eighth part on expulsion offenses
pārājikaṭṭhamaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form used as an adverbial phrase indicating the topic 'parts of offenses entailing expulsion' in the Vinaya context, specifically referring to the eighth section or part related to pārājika rules.

adesitūpasampadā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term refers to a case in the Vinaya where full ordination (upasampadā) is given without proper confession or appointment (adesita), likely indicating an invalid or irregular ordination procedure.

paccuṭṭhānāsanañceva.meaning_2: and also the act of standing up and seating (as a gesture of respect)
paccuṭṭhānāsanañceva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound where 'paccuṭṭhāna' (rising/standing up in respect) and 'āsana' (seating) are coordinated by 'ca eva' (and indeed/just so), indicating obligatory actions of respect in the Vinaya context, as per the translation 'One should stand up for, and seat'.
paccuṭṭhānāsanañceva.translation_1: One should stand up for, and seat,

aṭṭhadhammesu.meaning_2: in eight dhammas; in eight principles; in eight respects
aṭṭhadhammesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form aṭṭhadhammesu is the locative plural of the tatpuruṣa compound aṭṭhadhammo, meaning 'eight dhammas' or 'eight principles/respects'. In the context of 'behaving in eight respects', it refers to conduct or behavior in accordance with eight specific dhammas, likely moral or doctrinal principles.

navakavāro.meaning_2: novice's turn; case concerning a new monk
navakavāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In Vinaya context, this compound likely refers to a procedural case or section involving a novice monk (navaka), where vāra denotes a turn, instance, or subsection of monastic rules.

navamaṃsehi.meaning_2: one of nine kinds of meat; (lit.) ninth part (of meat)
navamaṃsehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'navamaṃsehi' is the instrumental plural of 'navamaṃsa', referring to nine specific types of forbidden meat (e.g., human, elephant, etc.), where 'nava' indicates the number nine and 'aṃsa' means 'portion' or 'kind' of meat. The offense (dukkaṭaṃ) arises from consuming these.
navamaṃsehi.translation_1: There is an offense of wrong conduct for eating nine kinds of meat. —

vidhamānā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'nava vidhamānā', the present participle vidhamānā modifies vidhā (implied from context as 'kinds' or 'sorts'), literally indicating 'nine kinds being (there)' or 'nine kinds present', which idiomatically translates to 'there are nine kinds' in English, emphasizing existence or availability of the nine types of conceit (māna).
vidhamānā.translation_1: There are nine kinds of conceit. —

āghātavatthuvinayā.meaning_2: grounds for resentment; getting rid of grounds for resentment; dispelling causes of animosity
āghātavatthuvinayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form āghātavatthuvinayā is the instrumental singular of the compound noun, used in context to denote the 'dispelling of grounds for resentment' as per the English translation. The compound combines 'āghāta-vatthu' (cause of resentment) with 'vinaya' (removal), fitting the Vinaya Piṭaka's theme of resolving monastic disputes.

maṃsuddesaparamāni.meaning_2: related to meat, recitation, and the utmost
maṃsuddesaparamāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a neuter nominative/accusative plural form of a tatpuruṣa compound 'maṃsuddesaparamāni', glossed in the contextual sentence as 'Meat, reciting, and ‘at the most’', likely enumerating three separate concepts or topics in a list, with 'ca' indicating connection.

adhammadhammasaññatti.meaning_2: illegitimate ways of winning over; legitimate ways of winning over
adhammadhammasaññatti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where adhamma and dhamma modify saññatti, indicating both unrighteous and righteous methods of persuasion or instruction. In the Vinaya context, it refers to improper and proper means to gain support or adherence among the saṅgha.
adhammadhammasaññatti.translation_1: Illegitimate ways of winning over, and legitimate ways of winning over,

adhammadhammikāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a dvandva compound juxtaposing 'adhammika' (illegitimate, unrighteous) and 'dhammika' (legitimate, righteous) in the neuter plural accusative form, used substantively in the context to refer to both categories of actions or matters as explained in the sentence.

dasakavāro.meaning_2: group of ten occasions; decade of turns; tenfold repetition
dasakavāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound dasakavāro combines dasaka (group of ten) with vāra (occasion or turn), likely referring to a set of ten verses, stanzas, or sections in Pāḷi texts, such as a decade in poetic or canonical divisions.

dasavatthukā.meaning_1: having ten bases; with ten topics
dasavatthukā.meaning_2: ten subject matters; ten topics (of wrong view or right view)
dasavatthukā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'dasavatthukā' describes the ten foundational topics or bases (vatthūni) for micchādiṭṭhi (wrong view) and sammādiṭṭhi (right view), as outlined in Pāḷi Abhidhamma texts. The feminine ending -ā agrees with diṭṭhi (feminine noun meaning 'view').
dasavatthukā.translation_1: There are ten subject matters of wrong view. —
dasavatthukā.translation_2: There are ten subject matters of right view. —

anuggahetvā.meaning_2: having followed; having grasped; having taken up
anuggahetvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'anuggahetvā' conveys 'not having grasped' or 'without grasping' the proper limits of speech for oneself and others, leading to illegitimate actions; it parallels 'uggahetvā' but with the prefix 'anu-' indicating following or conforming to the limits.
anuggahetvā.example_1: attano bhāsapariyantaṃ na uggaṇhāti, parassa bhāsapariyantaṃ na uggaṇhāti, attano bhāsapariyantaṃ anuggahetvā parassa bhāsapariyantaṃ anuggahetvā adhammena kāreti, appaṭiññāya āpattiṃ na jānāti, āpattiyā mūlaṃ na jānāti, āpattisamudayaṃ na jānāti, āpattinirodhaṃ na jānāti, āpattinirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ na jānāti.
anuggahetvā.translation_1: (1) he does not grasp what is proper for himself to say; (2) he does not grasp what is proper for others to say; (3-5) not grasping either, he makes them act illegitimately, without their admission; (6) he does not know the offenses; (7) he does not know the roots of the offenses; (8) he does not know the origin of the offenses; (9) he does not know the ending of the offenses; (10) he does not know the path leading to the ending of the offenses.
anuggahetvā.example_2: attano bhāsapariyantaṃ na uggaṇhāti, parassa bhāsapariyantaṃ na uggaṇhāti, attano bhāsapariyantaṃ anuggahetvā parassa bhāsapariyantaṃ anuggahetvā adhammena kāreti, appaṭiññāya āpattiṃ na jānāti, āpattiyā mūlaṃ na jānāti, āpattisamudayaṃ na jānāti, āpattinirodhaṃ na jānāti, āpattinirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ na jānāti.
anuggahetvā.translation_2: (1) he does not grasp what is proper for himself to say; (2) he does not grasp what is proper for others to say; (3-5) not grasping either, he makes them act illegitimately, without their admission; (6) he does not know the offenses; (7) he does not know the roots of the offenses; (8) he does not know the origin of the offenses; (9) he does not know the ending of the offenses; (10) he does not know the path leading to the ending of the offenses.

bhāsādhikaraṇañceva.meaning_2: language issue only; merely the matter of speech
bhāsādhikaraṇañceva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound in the context of Vinaya, referring exclusively to the disciplinary issue concerning speech or language, as indicated by the English translation 'To say, and legal issue'. The form is accusative neuter for the purpose of, combined with the emphatic conjunction 'ca eva'.

ñattilahukameva.meaning_2: just a light motion; motion, and light
ñattilahukameva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial sandhi compound in the Vinaya context, where ñatti refers to a formal motion or proposal, lahukam to something light or quick (as an adverb), and eva emphasizes 'just' or 'only'. The English translation 'Motion, and light' likely interprets lahukam as 'light' in a literal sense, possibly alluding to a light or swift quality of the motion, though 'quickly' fits the adverbial form better in Pāḷi usage.

paṃsukūladhāraṇā.meaning_2: wearing (robes) from a rubbish heap; practice of using discarded rags as robes
paṃsukūladhāraṇā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the contextual sentence 'paṃsukūladhāraṇā ca', it refers to the ascetic practice of monks wearing robes made from discarded cloth found on rubbish heaps, emphasizing humility and non-attachment to material possessions. The English translation 'Rag, and wearing' appears to be an incomplete or literal rendering, likely intending 'wearing rag-robes'.

dasāhasukkaitthiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound or list form enumerating three distinct concepts in the context of the sentence: a period of ten days, semen (as a substance), and women (likely in a monastic disciplinary context such as prohibitions or observances).

avandiyakkosena.meaning_2: with what is not to be honoured and abuse
avandiyakkosena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the compound avandiyakkosa, meaning 'with disrespect and abuse'. In the context, it describes the manner of not paying respect, combining something not worthy of honour with verbal insults.
avandiyakkosena.translation_1: Should not pay respect to, and with abuse;

pesuññañceva.meaning_2: and malicious talebearing; and divisive speech
pesuññañceva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'pesuññañceva' functions as an adverbial phrase emphasizing the inclusion of malicious talebearing among prohibited or listed items, contrasting with the erroneous English translation mentioning furniture, which likely stems from a misinterpretation of subsequent terms like 'senā' (army, possibly linked to material contexts).
pesuññañceva.translation_1: And malicious talebearing, kinds of furniture,

yāgumaṃsā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'dhammikā yāgumaṃsā ca', the compound refers to legitimate offerings of congee and meat, likely in a monastic or ritual setting where such provisions are deemed appropriate.

ekādasakavāro.meaning_2: eleventh occasion; eleventh instance; eleventh turn
ekādasakavāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun formed from the adjective 'ekādasaka' (eleventh, related to eleven) and the masculine noun 'vāra' (occasion, turn, or instance), likely referring to the eleventh observance or repetition in a sequence, such as in ritual or calendrical contexts.

ekāda.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] ekāda is a cardinal numeral meaning 'eleven', used as an indeclinable in Pāḷi; it can function adjectivally or adverbially depending on context, but no specific sentence provided for further analysis.

vīthā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] vīthā is a feminine noun denoting a street or road, commonly used in Pāḷi texts to refer to thoroughfares or paths in urban or village settings. Without specific sentences provided, the general meaning applies.

sīmādosā.meaning_2: flaw in a monastery zone; defect in a boundary area
sīmādosā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'sīmā' refers to the defined boundary for performing legal acts in a monastery, and 'dosa' here means fault or defect, as evidenced by the sentence describing eleven kinds of such flaws.
sīmādosā.translation_1: There are eleven kinds of flaws in monastery zones. —
sīmādosā.translation_2: And flaws in monastery zones, abuse,

ekādasādīnavā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, ekādasādīnavā refers to the eleven specific dangers expected for individuals who engage in abusive and reviling speech, as per the Vinaya or related texts.
ekādasādīnavā.translation_1: There are eleven dangers to be expected for people who abuse and revile.

adhiṭṭhānavikappanā.meaning_2: determination; assigning to another; transferring ownership
adhiṭṭhānavikappanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun combining adhiṭṭhāna (determination or basis) with vikappanā (assigning or transferring ownership, especially in Vinaya contexts). The English translation 'Determination, assigning to another' suggests it refers to the act of determining or resolving to assign something (e.g., ownership or responsibility) to another party, likely in a monastic or legal sense within the Vinaya.

nissayāvandiyā.meaning_2: formal support that should not be paid respect to; something relied upon that is not to be honoured
nissayāvandiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya, this compound refers to a formal dependency or support (nissaya) on a teacher that is not to be honoured (avandiya), indicating a prohibition against paying respect to such a support under certain conditions.
nissayāvandiyā.translation_1: Formal support, and should not pay respect to,

mettāyekādasā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form mettāyekādasā is a feminine nominative singular ordinal derived from the compound mettāyekādas ('eleven with loving-kindness'), referring to the eleventh in a series of mettā (loving-kindness) practices or topics. In context, 'mettāyekādasā katāti' means 'the elevens with mettā are done' or 'the eleventh on loving-kindness is completed,' likely concluding a section in a text like the Vinaya.

catupañcakā.meaning_2: fours and fives; groups of four and five
catupañcakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound noun in the nominative plural, referring to the numerical categories of fours (catu) and fives (pañcaka) in the context of enumerating groups or sets in Pāḷi texts, as indicated by the sentence structure 'tikā ca catupañcakā' meaning 'and the threes, fours, and fives'.
catupañcakā.translation_1: And the threes, fours, and fives;

chasattaṭṭhanavakā.meaning_2: the sixes, sevens, eights, and nines
chasattaṭṭhanavakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound listing numerical groups from six to nine, used in the context of enumerating categories or sets in the text. The form -kā indicates neuter plural, agreeing with the subject of the sentence.
chasattaṭṭhanavakā.translation_1: And the sixes, sevens, eights, and nines,

ñātadhammena.meaning_2: knowing the Teaching; knowing the Doctrine
ñātadhammena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound ñātadhammena is the instrumental singular form used to describe the Buddha as 'the One who knows the Teaching,' emphasizing his perfect understanding of the Doctrine in this context.
ñātadhammena.translation_1: By the Unwavering One who knows the Teaching;

uposathādipucchāvissajjanā.meaning_2: questioning and answering regarding the observance day etc.; aspects of the legal procedures
uposathādipucchāvissajjanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound noun refers to the section in the Vinaya dealing with procedures for inquiring about and resolving matters related to the uposatha ceremony and similar observances, concluding the discussion as per the sentence.
uposathādipucchāvissajjanā.translation_2: The aspects of the legal procedures are finished.

ādimajjhantapucchanaṃ.meaning_2: questioning from beginning to end; comprehensive questioning
ādimajjhantapucchanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a neuter noun, describing a thorough questioning that covers the entire range from start (ādi) through middle (majjha) to end (anta). The form is accusative singular, likely the object of a verb in an unprovided sentence.

rūpiyachaḍḍakasammutiyā.meaning_2: appointment of a money discarder; consent for cash remover
rūpiyachaḍḍakasammutiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in the context of inquiring about the structure (beginning, middle, end) of the procedure for appointing a money discarder, likely in a Vinaya legal context involving consensus or permission.
rūpiyachaḍḍakasammutiyā.example_1: rūpiyachaḍḍakasammutiyā ko ādi, kiṃ majjhe, kiṃ pariyosānaṃ?
rūpiyachaḍḍakasammutiyā.translation_1: What is the beginning, the middle, and the end of appointing a money discarder?

sāṭiyaggāhāpakasammutiyo.meaning_2: appointment of a distributor of rainy-season bathing cloths
sāṭiyaggāhāpakasammutiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is the nominative plural form of a compound noun referring to the 'appointments' or 'designations' of distributors who collect or manage sāṭiya (rainy-season bathing cloths) in the Vinaya context. The sentence analyzes its structural components (beginning, middle, end), indicating a breakdown of the compound.
sāṭiyaggāhāpakasammutiyo.example_1: sāṭiyaggāhāpakasammutiyo ko ādi, kiṃ majjhe, kiṃ pariyosānaṃ?
sāṭiyaggāhāpakasammutiyo.translation_1: What is the beginning, the middle, and the end of appointing a distributor of rainy-season bathing cloths?

pattaggāhāpakasammutiyā.meaning_2: appointment of a distributor of almsbowls
pattaggāhāpakasammutiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This instrumental singular form refers to the act or process of appointing a distributor of almsbowls in the Vinaya context, as indicated by the sentence analyzing its beginning, middle, and end.
pattaggāhāpakasammutiyā.example_1: pattaggāhāpakasammutiyā ko ādi, kiṃ majjhe, kiṃ pariyosānaṃ?
pattaggāhāpakasammutiyā.translation_1: What is the beginning, the middle, and the end of appointing a distributor of almsbowls?
pattaggāhāpakasammutiyā.translation_2: of appointing a distributor of almsbowls? …

daṇḍasammutiyā.meaning_2: permission to carry/use a staff; consent for staff usage
daṇḍasammutiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound refers to the formal permission or agreement allowing a monk to carry a staff for support during travel or illness, as analyzed in the beginning (ādi), middle (majjhe), and end (pariyosānaṃ) of the rule.
daṇḍasammutiyā.example_1: daṇḍasammutiyā ko ādi, kiṃ majjhe, kiṃ pariyosānaṃ?
daṇḍasammutiyā.translation_1: What is the beginning, the middle, and the end of the permission to use a staff?
daṇḍasammutiyā.translation_2: of the permission to use a staff? …

sikkāsammutiyā.meaning_2: permission to use a carrying net
sikkāsammutiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in Vinaya context to denote formal consent or agreement for using a sikkā (basket or net on a carrying pole). The sentence analyzes its structural elements, typical in Vinaya formalities.
sikkāsammutiyā.example_1: sikkāsammutiyā ko ādi, kiṃ majjhe, kiṃ pariyosānaṃ?
sikkāsammutiyā.translation_1: What is the beginning, the middle, and the end of the permission to use a carrying net?
sikkāsammutiyā.translation_2: of the permission to use a carrying net? …

daṇḍasikkāsammutiyā.meaning_2: permission to use a staff and a carrying net
daṇḍasikkāsammutiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound denotes the formal permission or consensus granted to monks for carrying items using a staff and a net, structured as a legal procedure with beginning (topic and person), middle (motion), and end (announcement).
daṇḍasikkāsammutiyā.example_1: daṇḍasikkāsammutiyā ko ādi, kiṃ majjhe, kiṃ pariyosānaṃ?
daṇḍasikkāsammutiyā.translation_1: What is the beginning, the middle, and the end of the permission to use a staff and a carrying net?
daṇḍasikkāsammutiyā.example_2: daṇḍasikkāsammutiyā ko ādi, kiṃ majjhe, kiṃ pariyosānanti?
daṇḍasikkāsammutiyā.translation_2: of the permission to use a staff and a carrying net?

ādimajjhantavissajjanā.grammar: fem, comp, abstr, act, from vissajjeti
ādimajjhantavissajjanā.meaning_2: replies on the beginning, the middle, and the end; answering regarding the start, middle, and conclusion
ādimajjhantavissajjanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where vissajjanā 'answering' is qualified by the tripartite ādi-majjha-anta 'beginning-middle-end', referring to replies or responses structured around the initial, middle, and final parts, as per the contextual English translation.
ādimajjhantavissajjanā.translation_1: 2. Replies on the beginning, the middle, and the end

sāṭiyaggāhāpakasammutiyā.meaning_2: appointment of a distributor of rainy-season bathing cloths; permission for appointing a rainsuit collector
sāṭiyaggāhāpakasammutiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is the feminine instrumental singular of the compound noun sāṭiyaggāhāpakasammuti, used in a Vinaya context to denote the formal agreement or appointment procedure for a role involving the collection or distribution of sāṭiya (rainy-season bathing cloths). The English translation interprets it as 'of appointing a distributor,' highlighting the sammuti aspect of consent in monastic administration.
sāṭiyaggāhāpakasammutiyā.translation_1: of appointing a distributor of rainy-season bathing cloths? …

atthavasapakaraṇaṃ.meaning_2: book; literary work; section on the ten reasons for the training rules
atthavasapakaraṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In this context, the compound refers to the specific treatise or section detailing the ten purposes or reasons (atthavasa) for the vinaya training rules, concluded here as 'finished'.
atthavasapakaraṇaṃ.translation_1: The ten reasons for the training rules are finished.
atthavasapakaraṇaṃ.translation_2: The ten reasons for the training rules are finished.

saṅghasuṭṭhu.meaning_2: for the well-being of the Sangha; for the good of the community
saṅghasuṭṭhu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentences, 'saṅghasuṭṭhu' functions as an adverbial phrase meaning 'for the well-being of the Sangha', often paired with 'yaṃ ... taṃ' constructions to explain purposes or equivalences, such as equating it to the Sangha's comfort or its role in restraining misconduct and supporting the Dhamma.
saṅghasuṭṭhu.translation_1: The well-being of the Sangha is the comfort of the Sangha.
saṅghasuṭṭhu.translation_2: The well-being of the Sangha is the comfort of the Sangha.

saṅghaphāsu.meaning_2: comfort of the Sangha; well-being of the Sangha
saṅghaphāsu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term saṅghaphāsu is used in the Saṅghabhedaka Sutta (AN 10.12) to describe the well-being and comfort of the monastic community (Saṅgha), which supports the restraint of bad individuals, ease for good monks, confidence in the faithless, longevity of the Dhamma, and upholding of the Vinaya.
saṅghaphāsu.translation_1: The well-being of the Sangha is the comfort of the Sangha.
saṅghaphāsu.example_2: yaṃ saṅghaphāsu taṃ dummaṅkūnaṃ puggalānaṃ niggahāya.
saṅghaphāsu.translation_2: The comfort of the Sangha is for the restraint of bad people.

atthasataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'atthasataṃ' refers to 'a hundred purposes,' paralleling 'dhammasataṃ' as 'a hundred teachings.' The form is accusative singular neuter of the compound, likely in a poetic or exclamatory structure emphasizing abundance.

dhammasataṃ.meaning_2: a hundred teachings; a hundred doctrines
dhammasataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, dhammasataṃ refers to a hundred teachings or doctrines, paralleling atthasataṃ as a hundred purposes or goals, likely in a hyperbolic or enumerative sense emphasizing abundance.

niruttisatāni.meaning_2: expressions; ways of speaking; two hundred expressions
niruttisatāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'dve ca niruttisatāni' meaning 'and two hundred expressions', the compound niruttisatāni refers to two hundred instances of nirutti (expressions or ways of speaking), functioning as a neuter plural noun agreeing with 'dve'.

ñāṇasatāni.meaning_2: hundred knowledges; set of one hundred insights
ñāṇasatāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'cattāri ñāṇasatāni' translated as 'four hundred knowledges', ñāṇasata refers to a unit of one hundred knowledges or insights, likely from Buddhist technical terminology such as the 400 knowledges in the Abhidhamma or similar enumerations.

aṭṭhapucchāyaṃ.meaning_2: eight questions; set of eight inquiries
aṭṭhapucchāyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'paṭhamaṃ aṭṭhapucchāyaṃ', the locative form aṭṭhapucchāyaṃ refers to 'in the first (section) on eight questions', indicating a topic or division focused on eight specific inquiries, likely in a doctrinal or scriptural discussion.

punaṭṭha.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'punaṭṭha ca paccayesu' indicates an additional set of eight items related to 'paccaya' (conditions or results), as translated 'And then eight on ‘a result of’'. The form is a sandhi combination where final -a of puna merges with initial a- of aṭṭha.
punaṭṭha.translation_1: And then eight on ‘a result of’;

peyyālaantarā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term peyyālaantarā refers to the internal (antarā) elided repetition (peyyāla) within a text, as used in the context of textual subdivision or structural repetition in Pāḷi literature.

pavāraṇatthavasikā.meaning_2: sensible about the reasons for the invitation ceremony
pavāraṇatthavasikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound adjective modifies a feminine noun implied in the context, referring to being rational or intent on the purposes/benefits associated with the pavāraṇā ceremony at the end of the vassa retreat, as indicated by the English translation 'Invitation ceremony, about reasons'.

gāthāsaṅgaṇikaṃ.meaning_2: verses on the training rules; verses on how to accuse properly
gāthāsaṅgaṇikaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term gāthāsaṅgaṇikaṃ appears as a neuter accusative singular in the Vinaya context, referring to a collection or section of verses (gāthā) related to training rules (sikkhāpada) or procedures for formal accusation (saṅgaṇhāti, lit. 'taking up' or 'accusing'). In sentences 0 and 2, it marks the completion of verses on training rules; in sentence 3, on accusation procedures. The base saṅgaṇika likely derives from saṃ + √gaṇ (to take up, assemble), indicating 'pertaining to assembly or formal procedure'.
gāthāsaṅgaṇikaṃ.translation_1: The verses on the training rules  are finished.
gāthāsaṅgaṇikaṃ.translation_2: There are these verses on the training rules.”

sattanagaresu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sattanagaresu is the locative plural of the compound sattanagara, meaning 'seven towns'. In the context of the sentence, it refers to rules or precepts 'laid down in seven towns', likely alluding to the seven towns where the Buddha permitted certain monastic practices or origins of vinaya rules.

paññattasikkhāpadaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun referring to a training precept or rule that has been formally declared or prescribed, commonly used in the Vinaya context for monastic regulations.

paggaṇhitvāna.meaning_2: having taken; having raised; having lifted up
paggaṇhitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, paggaṇhitvāna describes the action of raising the joined palms (añjaliṃ) in a gesture of respect or supplication.

āsīsamānarūpova.meaning_2: as if only hoping; just like one desiring
āsīsamānarūpova.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adverbial expression functioning as an indeclinable. In the context of the sentence 'What are you hoping for?', it modifies the verb, conveying 'as if only hoping' or 'just like one desiring', emphasizing the manner of hoping or desiring.

āsiṃsamānarūpova.meaning_2: I was just as if of similar form
āsiṃsamānarūpova.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound formed by the aorist 1st singular 'āsiṃ' (I was), the adjective 'samānarūp' (of similar form), and the indeclinable 'ova' (just like/as if, with eva for emphasis). It likely describes a state of appearing or being just like something of similar form, possibly in a simile or comparison in the text.

ahamakkhissaṃ.meaning_2: I would tell; I might tell; I should tell
ahamakkhissaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ahamakkhissaṃ is the first person singular optative of akkhāti 'to tell', with ahaṃ 'I' as an explicit subject for emphasis, matching the English translation 'And so I will tell you' where the optative conveys a sense of intention or future narrative.
ahamakkhissaṃ.translation_1: And so I will tell you,

yathāsi.meaning_2: as you are; according to your ability; according to your skill
yathāsi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'yathāsi kusalo tathā' translated as 'According to your skill', yathāsi functions adverbially to mean 'according to how you are' or 'as per your capacity', combining yathā ('as, according to') with asi ('you are'), indicating manner or condition.

aḍḍhuḍḍhasatāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound aḍḍhuḍḍhasatāni functions as a numeral adjective in the neuter plural form, agreeing with the subject 'te' (they, referring to items or entities), and denotes the quantity 350 as per the English translation. The first member aḍḍhuḍḍha means 'three and a half', and sata means 'hundred', yielding 3.5 × 100 = 350.
aḍḍhuḍḍhasatāni.translation_1: They are three hundred and fifty,

nisāmayitvā.meaning_2: having listened; having attended carefully; having heard
nisāmayitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, nisāmayitvā indicates the action of carefully listening or attending to the explanation before proceeding, functioning as an absolutive to express a prior action.
nisāmayitvā.translation_1: And after attending carefully to your explanation,

chaūna.meaning_2: six less than; two hundred ninety-four
chaūna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'chaūna tīṇisatāni' denotes 294, calculated as 300 (tīṇi satāni) minus 6 (chaūna), where ūna indicates deficiency. This compound functions as a cardinal numeral.

tīṇisatāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form tīṇisatāni is the neuter nominative and accusative plural of the cardinal number 'tīṇi sata' (three hundred), used here in a specific counting context to denote 294, likely as part of a larger numerical expression involving 'chaūna' (less six).

methunaviggahuttari.meaning_2: superior to sexual intercourse; beyond sexual activity
methunaviggahuttari.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes something superior or beyond sexual intercourse, likely referring to a person or state transcending physical sexual activity, aligning with the English gloss 'Sexual intercourse, person, super' in a monastic or doctrinal context.

paramparabhattaṃ.meaning_2: a meal before another; successive meal
paramparabhattaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'bhūtaṃ paramparabhattaṃ', the term refers to a meal that is true or actual in the sense of being prepared or served one after another, likely indicating a sequential or repeated provision of food in a monastic or ritual setting.

pācitapiṇḍaṃ.meaning_2: almsfood prepared; food obtained through requesting or preparation
pācitapiṇḍaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'ujjhāpanena ca pācitapiṇḍaṃ', the term refers to almsfood that is specially prepared or procured, often in response to complaints or requests, as indicated by the English translation 'having almsfood prepared'.
pācitapiṇḍaṃ.translation_1: And with complaining, having almsfood prepared;

giraggacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'giraggacariyā tattheva' (Hilltop wandering, right there), the compound describes the act of roaming or wandering specifically on a mountain peak or hilltop, emphasizing the location of the activity.

chapaññāsasatañceva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound formed by eliding the final ā of chapaññāsā before the initial s of sata, resulting in chapaññāsasata. The entire form chapaññāsasatañceva combines the numeral '156' with the conjunctive particle 'and indeed'. In the context, it enumerates a specific quantity, likely in a list of numbers.

kuṭikosiyaseyyā.meaning_2: hut, silk, and sleeping place; compound denoting items related to monastic possessions or prohibitions
kuṭikosiyaseyyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in the feminine instrumental singular form, used in Vinaya contexts to list three categories of lay offerings prohibited for monks: kuṭi (simple dwelling), kosiya (silk cloth), and seyyā (bed or sleeping arrangement). The English translation reflects the compound's components as separate items connected by 'and'.

catuvipattiṃ.meaning_2: misfortune in four ways; fourfold adversity; fourfold failure
catuvipattiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form catuvipattiṃ is the accusative singular of the tatpuruṣa compound catuvipatti, denoting four instances or kinds of vipatti (misfortune, failure, or adversity). Without contextual sentences, the precise usage cannot be determined, but it likely refers to a specific doctrinal concept of fourfold misfortune in Pāli literature.

lahukañcāpi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'garuka lahukañcāpi sāvasesaṃ', lahukañcāpi functions as an adverbial phrase meaning 'even light' or 'light ones too', contrasting with 'garuka' (serious). It modifies the implied subject of curability, indicating that even light offenses are curable when remaining.

aṭṭhettha.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'aṭṭhettha anavasesā', 'aṭṭhettha' is the locative singular form of 'aṭṭha' (eight), combined with 'ettha' (here), functioning as an adverbial phrase 'in eight here' or 'eight here', referring to eight cases or items in this context that are incurable (anavasesā). The numeral 'aṭṭha' is distinct from the homonyms meaning 'bone' or 'purpose'.

ācāravipattisammatā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound ācāravipattisammatā functions as a predicate adjective in feminine nominative singular, agreeing with 'sā' (this, fem.), indicating that the subject is regarded as an instance of failure in moral conduct, as per the sentence context.
ācāravipattisammatā.translation_1: This is considered failure in conduct.

viparītadiṭṭhiṃ.meaning_1: distorted view; wrong belief; perverse opinion
viparītadiṭṭhiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, viparītadiṭṭhiṃ refers to holding onto distorted or wrong views, which in Buddhist terminology often denotes false beliefs about reality, such as impermanence or non-self, leading to suffering.

diṭṭhivipattisammatā.meaning_2: considered as failure in view; deemed to be wrong view
diṭṭhivipattisammatā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence, the feminine form agrees with 'sā' (this), indicating something considered a failure or error in right view, often in doctrinal or ethical contexts.
diṭṭhivipattisammatā.translation_1: This is considered failure in view.

chedanakādi.meaning_2: to be cut down, etc.; beginning with cutting down
chedanakādi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound where chedanaka (derived from √chid, meaning 'involving cutting up') is combined with ādi ('etc., beginning with') to indicate 'to be cut down, etc.', as per the contextual translation.

bhedanakāni.meaning_2: matter to be destroyed; thing to be broken or split
bhedanakāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'bhedanakāni' refers to cases or matters involving the destruction or breaking (e.g., of monastic property or unity), as indicated by the interrogative 'kati bhedanakāni?' meaning 'How many (cases) on 'to be destroyed'?'

sodasa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'sodasa jānanti paññattā', 'sodasa' functions as a numeral adjective modifying an implied feminine noun like 'paññā' or 'dhammā', meaning 'sixteen (kinds of) knowing are set forth' or 'there are sixteen (modes of) knowing'.

asādhāraṇādi.meaning_2: not in common, etc.; uncommon and so forth
asādhāraṇādi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound used in a list or enumeration, indicating 'not in common' as the starting point followed by similar or related items, matching the English translation 'Not in common, etc.' in the context of Pāḷi grammatical or doctrinal categorization.

chacceva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'chacceva' modifies 'sattati' (seventy), specifying 'only six' to complete the total of 176. It appears to be a sandhi form where 'cha eva' combines, with 'a' from 'cha' eliding before 'e' of 'eva'.
chacceva.translation_1: So one hundred and seventy-six in total,

chaccevime.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'chaccevime' refers to 'these six' as the concluding or emphatic reference to a group of six items, forming part of the total enumeration of 176. The emphatic 'eva' underscores that these are precisely the six in question.
chaccevime.translation_1: These are the hundred and seventy-six,

samasattati.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In this Vinaya context, 'samasattati' is a compound numeral referring to a total of seventy minor offenses (khuddakā), where 'sama' indicates totality or equality, and 'sattati' is the feminine singular form of 'seventy' agreeing with the implied feminine plural noun 'khuddakā'.

tālavatthusamūpamā.meaning_2: similar to the palm stump; like the stump of a palm tree
tālavatthusamūpamā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given context, this compound adjective describes a person who, like a palm tree stump, has no further growth or potential left, often used in Buddhist texts to illustrate someone beyond further spiritual development.
tālavatthusamūpamā.translation_1: That person is like the simile of the palm stump,

aviruḷhī.meaning_2: not growing; without growth; incapable of growth
aviruḷhī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form aviruḷhī is the feminine nominative singular adjective, agreeing with an implied feminine plural subject in the sentence 'aviruḷhī bhavanti te,' translated as 'They are incapable of growth.' The prefix 'a-' negates the base viruḷhī derived from viruḷhi, emphasizing absence of development or sprouting in context.

aṭṭhāsītisataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form aṭṭhāsītisataṃ is the neuter singular accusative of the compound numeral, used here as the object of implied 'are' in the context of counting pācittiya offenses in the Vinaya.
aṭṭhāsītisataṃ.translation_1: One hundred and eighty-eight offenses entailing confession;
aṭṭhāsītisataṃ.translation_2: One hundred and eighty-eight offenses entailing confession

pārājikādiāpatti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'pārājikādi' functions as an upapada modifying 'āpatti', specifically referring to Vinaya categories starting with the gravest offenses (pārājika) and including subsequent ones like saṅghādisesa, etc., as indicated by the English translation 'The offenses entailing expulsion, etc.'

paraddho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, paraddho describes a state of having committed an offence or transgression, often in a moral or disciplinary sense, paralleling the ideas of falling away (cuto) and being defeated or fallen (bhaṭṭho).
paraddho.translation_1: When one has fallen away, offended, and fallen down,

tenetaṃ.meaning_2: thereby; because of that; on that account
tenetaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The expression 'tenetaṃ' functions as an adverbial phrase explaining the reason for the naming, equivalent to 'for this reason' or 'hence' in the context of the repeated sentence 'This is why it is called that.' It combines the instrumental 'tena' (by that) with the accusative 'etaṃ' (this), though as an indeclinable, it doesn't inflect.
tenetaṃ.translation_1: This is why it is called that.
tenetaṃ.translation_2: This is why it is called that.

tiṇṇamaññataraṃ.meaning_2: one of three; one of the three
tiṇṇamaññataraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form tiṇṇamaññataraṃ is the neuter accusative singular of the compound tiṇṇamaññatara, used here as a substantival adjective meaning 'one of the three (cases)'. It functions as the direct object of an implied verb like hoti ('is'). The first member tiṇṇa is the past participle of tarati ('to cross over'), but in this compound it idiomatically denotes 'the three' (referring to a set of three items that have been distinguished or categorized), with aññatara adding the sense of 'one of'. In the context, it refers to one of three legal or doctrinal cases in the Vinaya or similar Pāḷi text.
tiṇṇamaññataraṃ.translation_1: It is one of three cases—

nissajjitvāna.meaning_2: having relinquished; having given up; having let go
nissajjitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'nissajjitvāna deseti', the absolutive form indicates the action of relinquishing completed prior to the main action of confessing (deseti), conveying sequence in the Vinaya context of monastic discipline.

cittasaṃmohanaṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: place for the delusion of the mind; cause of mental confusion
cittasaṃmohanaṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'saṃmohana' (delusion or confusion) modifies 'aṭṭhāna' (place or cause), with 'citta' (mind) specifying the type of delusion. It likely refers to a locus or condition leading to mental obfuscation in a doctrinal context.

nimantanāsu.meaning_2: invitation; formal invitation to a meal
nimantanāsu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the locative plural form nimantanāsu, it indicates the context of 'at invitations' or 'upon invitations,' specifically referring to situations where monks eat at formal invitations from lay supporters, as per the Vinaya rules on accepting invitations.

anivāretvā.meaning_2: without inviting; without stopping; without calling
anivāretvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'anivāretvā tahiṃ bhuñje', the absolutive form indicates the action of eating occurs without the prior action of inviting or stopping her, implying a breach of propriety in a monastic context.
anivāretvā.translation_1: If they eat there without having stopped her,

saddhācittaṃ.meaning_2: mind with faith; faithful heart; family with faith
saddhācittaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'saddhācittaṃ kulaṃ' refers to a family characterized by faith, where 'saddhācittaṃ' functions as a descriptive compound modifying 'kulaṃ'. The accusative form indicates the object of 'gantvā' (going to).
saddhācittaṃ.translation_1: Going to a family that has faith,

anāḷiyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'appabhogaṃ anāḷiyaṃ', anāḷiyaṃ functions as a predicative adjective agreeing with a neuter implied subject, describing a state of poverty or scarcity of resources, akin to lacking an 'embankment' or barrier of wealth.
anāḷiyaṃ.translation_1: But is poor with little wealth;

sabhayānake.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'sāsaṅke sabhayānake', it functions as a neuter adjective agreeing with an implied neuter noun, describing something as fraught with fear or danger, hence 'risky and dangerous'.

gārayhapattā.meaning_2: blameworthy act; culpable deed; contemptible offense
gārayhapattā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, gārayhapattā refers to a feminine noun indicating an act or deed that is blameworthy within the teachings of the Sugata (Accomplished One), implying a violation or fault deserving of blame.
gārayhapattā.translation_1: She has committed a blameworthy act in the instruction of the Accomplished One.

saññamasaṃvaro.meaning_2: restraint of perception; control over speech through mindful perception
saññamasaṃvaro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound saññamasaṃvaro in the phrase 'mukhaṃ saññamasaṃvaro' refers to guarding the mouth through restrained perception, emphasizing self-control in speech to prevent harmful words, aligning with the English translation of a controlled and restrained mouth.
saññamasaṃvaro.translation_1: With a controlled and restrained mouth—

adhikaraṇabhedo.meaning_2: division of issues; distinction of cases; splitting of matters
adhikaraṇabhedo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where adhikaraṇa (issue, case) is qualified by bheda (division, distinction). In Vinaya contexts, it likely refers to the classification or differentiation of disciplinary cases or legal matters.

ukkoṭanabhedādi.meaning_2: subdivision on reopening, etc.; section dealing with bribery, schism, etc.
ukkoṭanabhedādi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun used in a Vinaya context to refer to a subsection or chapter covering topics starting with 'ukkoṭana' (reopening of legal cases or bribery) and 'bheda' (schism or division), extending to related matters indicated by 'ādi' (etc.). The English translation 'The subdivision on reopening, etc.' highlights the procedural reopening aspect in monastic law.

katihaṅgehi.meaning_2: with how many factors; with how many attributes; with how many qualities
katihaṅgehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form used interrogatively in Vinaya contexts to inquire about the number of qualifying factors or attributes for specific actions, such as legal procedures, eligibility for ceremonies, or fulfilling conditions for raising issues. The base compound katihaṅga is a tatpuruṣa interrogative combining 'kati' (how many) with 'aṅga' (factor, limb, quality).
katihaṅgehi.translation_1: How many attributes do people who reopen legal issues have?
katihaṅgehi.example_2: katihaṅgehi samannāgato puggalo abhabbo kathinaṃ attharituṃ?
katihaṅgehi.translation_2: What sort of person is unable to perform the robe-making ceremony?

ukkoṭentā.meaning_2: reopen (a legal issue); bring up again; revive
ukkoṭentā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'ukkoṭentā' is the present active participle nominative plural masculine, agreeing with 'puggalā' (people), indicating those who perform the action of reopening a settled legal matter (adhikaraṇaṃ), which constitutes an offense (āpatti). The term implies disturbing a resolved dispute.
ukkoṭentā.example_1: kati puggalā adhikaraṇaṃ ukkoṭentā āpattiṃ āpajjanti?
ukkoṭentā.translation_1: How many kinds of people commit an offense when they reopen a legal issue?
ukkoṭentā.example_2: cattāro puggalā adhikaraṇaṃ ukkoṭentā āpattiṃ āpajjanti?
ukkoṭentā.translation_2: There are four kinds of people who commit an offense when they reopen legal issues.

duvinicchitaṃ.meaning_2: badly decided; badly judged; badly settled
duvinicchitaṃ.construction: du + vi + nī + √ci > chi + ta + aṃ
duvinicchitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, duvinicchitaṃ describes a legal matter that has been decided or settled in a faulty or improper manner, requiring re-decision (puna vinicchitabbaṃ).
duvinicchitaṃ.example_1: akataṃ kammaṃ, dukkaṭaṃ kammaṃ, puna kātabbaṃ kammaṃ, anihataṃ, dunnihataṃ, puna nihanitabbaṃ, avinicchitaṃ, duvinicchitaṃ, puna vinicchitabbaṃ, avūpasantaṃ, duvūpasantaṃ, puna vūpasametabbanti—
duvinicchitaṃ.translation_1: “The legal procedure hasn’t been done”; “it’s been done badly”; “it should be done again”; “it’s not been settled”; “it’s been badly settled”; “it should be settled again”; “it’s not been decided”; “it’s been badly decided”; “it should be decided again”; “it’s not been disposed of”; “it’s been badly disposed of”; “it should be disposed of again”.

vinicchitabbaṃ.meaning_2: to be decided; to be investigated; to be examined; to be settled
vinicchitabbaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'puna vinicchitabbaṃ' refers to a legal matter that should be decided or investigated again, often after a prior inadequate decision (duvinicchitaṃ). The form is a potential passive participle indicating obligation, parallel to the English 'it should be decided again'.
vinicchitabbaṃ.example_1: akataṃ kammaṃ, dukkaṭaṃ kammaṃ, puna kātabbaṃ kammaṃ, anihataṃ, dunnihataṃ, puna nihanitabbaṃ, avinicchitaṃ, duvinicchitaṃ, puna vinicchitabbaṃ, avūpasantaṃ, duvūpasantaṃ, puna vūpasametabbanti—
vinicchitabbaṃ.translation_1: “The legal procedure hasn’t been done”; “it’s been done badly”; “it should be done again”; “it’s not been settled”; “it’s been badly settled”; “it should be settled again”; “it’s not been decided”; “it’s been badly decided”; “it should be decided again”; “it’s not been disposed of”; “it’s been badly disposed of”; “it should be disposed of again”.

adhikaraṇanidānādi.meaning_2: sources of legal issues, etc.; origins of disputes and so forth
adhikaraṇanidānādi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound refers to the foundational elements such as legal disputes (adhikaraṇa), their origins or causes (nidāna), and similar categories, as indicated by the English translation 'The sources of the legal issues, etc.'
adhikaraṇanidānādi.translation_1: 2. The sources of the legal issues, etc.

kiṃsambhāraṃ.meaning_2: what is the production; what is the constituent; what is the necessary requirement
kiṃsambhāraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'kiṃsambhāraṃ' interrogates the essential component or productive condition underlying various legal issues in the Vinaya, paralleling terms like source and origin.
kiṃsambhāraṃ.example_1: vivādādhikaraṇaṃ kiṃnidānaṃ, kiṃsamudayaṃ, kiṃjātikaṃ, kiṃpabhavaṃ, kiṃsambhāraṃ, kiṃsamuṭṭhānaṃ?
kiṃsambhāraṃ.translation_1: What is the source, the origin, the birth, the arising, the production, the origination of legal issues arising from disputes?
kiṃsambhāraṃ.example_2: anuvādādhikaraṇaṃ kiṃnidānaṃ, kiṃsamudayaṃ, kiṃjātikaṃ, kiṃpabhavaṃ, kiṃsambhāraṃ, kiṃsamuṭṭhānaṃ?
kiṃsambhāraṃ.translation_2: What is the source, the origin, the birth, the arising, the production, the origination of legal issues arising from accusations?

vivādanidānaṃ.grammar: ind, adv, in comps, acc sg of vivādanidāna
vivādanidānaṃ.meaning_2: due to dispute; because of quarrel; originating from argument
vivādanidānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, vivādanidānaṃ functions adverbially to indicate the source or cause of disputes in legal issues, paralleling other terms like vivādasamudayaṃ, emphasizing origination from disputes.
vivādanidānaṃ.example_1: vivādādhikaraṇaṃ vivādanidānaṃ vivādasamudayaṃ vivādajātikaṃ vivādapabhavaṃ vivādasambhāraṃ vivādasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
vivādanidānaṃ.translation_1: Legal issues arising from disputes have disputes as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

vivādasamudayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, vivādasamudayaṃ refers to the 'source' or 'origination' of disputes, paralleling terms like vivādanidānaṃ and vivādajātikaṃ, emphasizing the causal arising of legal issues from disputes.
vivādasamudayaṃ.example_1: vivādādhikaraṇaṃ vivādanidānaṃ vivādasamudayaṃ vivādajātikaṃ vivādapabhavaṃ vivādasambhāraṃ vivādasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
vivādasamudayaṃ.translation_1: Legal issues arising from disputes have disputes as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

vivādajātikaṃ.meaning_2: born from dispute; arisen from dispute; originating from dispute
vivādajātikaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'vivādajātikaṃ' describes legal issues as being 'born' or 'of the type' originating from disputes, paralleling terms like vivādanidānaṃ (source) and vivādapabhavaṃ (arising).
vivādajātikaṃ.example_1: vivādādhikaraṇaṃ vivādanidānaṃ vivādasamudayaṃ vivādajātikaṃ vivādapabhavaṃ vivādasambhāraṃ vivādasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
vivādajātikaṃ.translation_1: Legal issues arising from disputes have disputes as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

vivādapabhavaṃ.meaning_2: arising from dispute; production of dispute; origination of dispute
vivādapabhavaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, vivādapabhavaṃ denotes the production or origination aspect of disputes, paralleling terms like source, origin, and arising, emphasizing the causal emergence of legal issues from disputes.
vivādapabhavaṃ.example_1: vivādādhikaraṇaṃ vivādanidānaṃ vivādasamudayaṃ vivādajātikaṃ vivādapabhavaṃ vivādasambhāraṃ vivādasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
vivādapabhavaṃ.translation_1: Legal issues arising from disputes have disputes as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

vivādasambhāraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the list of terms for the source of disputes, vivādasambhāraṃ is the accusative singular of the compound vivādasambhāra, functioning as a bahuvrīhi or karmadhāraya compound where sambhāra denotes the 'production' or 'origination' aspect of vivāda, paralleling terms like vivādajātikaṃ (birth) and vivādapabhavaṃ (arising).
vivādasambhāraṃ.example_1: vivādādhikaraṇaṃ vivādanidānaṃ vivādasamudayaṃ vivādajātikaṃ vivādapabhavaṃ vivādasambhāraṃ vivādasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
vivādasambhāraṃ.translation_1: Legal issues arising from disputes have disputes as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

vivādasamuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: origination of dispute; arising from dispute
vivādasamuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, vivādasamuṭṭhānaṃ is used as a neuter accusative singular noun in a series describing legal issues or disputes, emphasizing their origination or arising from disputes themselves. It parallels terms like vivādanidānaṃ (source) and vivādajātikaṃ (birth), indicating causality in the context of Vinaya dispute resolution.
vivādasamuṭṭhānaṃ.example_1: vivādādhikaraṇaṃ vivādanidānaṃ vivādasamudayaṃ vivādajātikaṃ vivādapabhavaṃ vivādasambhāraṃ vivādasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
vivādasamuṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: Legal issues arising from disputes have disputes as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

anuvādanidānaṃ.meaning_2: source; origin (of legal issues arising from accusations)
anuvādanidānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative singular form of the tatpuruṣa compound anuvādanidāna, used adverbially in the text to mean 'due to accusation' or 'having accusation as source.' In the Vinaya context, it parallels other terms indicating the causal origin of legal matters related to blame or censure.
anuvādanidānaṃ.example_1: anuvādādhikaraṇaṃ anuvādanidānaṃ anuvādasamudayaṃ anuvādajātikaṃ anuvādapabhavaṃ anuvādasambhāraṃ anuvādasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
anuvādanidānaṃ.translation_1: Legal issues arising from accusations have accusations as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

anuvādasamudayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya sentence, 'anuvādasamudayaṃ' refers to the 'arising' or 'origination' of legal issues stemming from accusations, paralleling terms like nidāna (source) and pabhava (origin). Here, anuvāda is used in the sense of 'accusation' or 'blame' rather than 'translation'.
anuvādasamudayaṃ.example_1: anuvādādhikaraṇaṃ anuvādanidānaṃ anuvādasamudayaṃ anuvādajātikaṃ anuvādapabhavaṃ anuvādasambhāraṃ anuvādasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
anuvādasamudayaṃ.translation_1: Legal issues arising from accusations have accusations as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

anuvādajātikaṃ.meaning_2: arising from; originating from; born from; produced by
anuvādajātikaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, anuvāda means 'accusation' or 'blame'. The compound anuvādajātikaṃ functions as an adjective modifying the legal issue (adhikaraṇaṃ), indicating that it is 'arising from' or 'produced by' the accusation, paralleling terms like nidānaṃ (source/origin) and samudayaṃ (arising). The English translation captures this as 'have accusations as their ... birth'.
anuvādajātikaṃ.example_1: anuvādādhikaraṇaṃ anuvādanidānaṃ anuvādasamudayaṃ anuvādajātikaṃ anuvādapabhavaṃ anuvādasambhāraṃ anuvādasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
anuvādajātikaṃ.translation_1: Legal issues arising from accusations have accusations as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

anuvādapabhavaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In this Vinaya context, 'anuvāda' denotes accusations or legal charges, and 'pabhava' indicates their causal origin, paralleling terms like 'nidāna' (source) and 'samudaya' (arising). The accusative form fits the genitive construction describing the basis of legal issues.
anuvādapabhavaṃ.example_1: anuvādādhikaraṇaṃ anuvādanidānaṃ anuvādasamudayaṃ anuvādajātikaṃ anuvādapabhavaṃ anuvādasambhāraṃ anuvādasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
anuvādapabhavaṃ.translation_1: Legal issues arising from accusations have accusations as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

anuvādasambhāraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, anuvādasambhāraṃ refers to the 'production' or 'constituent' aspect of legal issues arising from accusations, paralleling terms like source, origin, and arising. Here, anuvāda is used in the sense of 'accusation' or 'blame' rather than 'translation'.
anuvādasambhāraṃ.example_1: anuvādādhikaraṇaṃ anuvādanidānaṃ anuvādasamudayaṃ anuvādajātikaṃ anuvādapabhavaṃ anuvādasambhāraṃ anuvādasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
anuvādasambhāraṃ.translation_1: Legal issues arising from accusations have accusations as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

anuvādasamuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'anuvādasamuṭṭhānaṃ' denotes the origination or arising of legal issues from accusations, paralleling terms like 'anuvādanidānaṃ' (source) and 'anuvādasamudayaṃ' (arising). The compound combines 'anuvāda' (accusation, blame) with 'samuṭṭhāna' (origination), emphasizing causal origin in Vinaya legal discourse.
anuvādasamuṭṭhānaṃ.example_1: anuvādādhikaraṇaṃ anuvādanidānaṃ anuvādasamudayaṃ anuvādajātikaṃ anuvādapabhavaṃ anuvādasambhāraṃ anuvādasamuṭṭhānaṃ.

āpattinidānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound serves as an adverbial accusative indicating the source or origin from which legal issues arising from offenses stem, paralleling terms like āpattisamudayaṃ and āpattijātikaṃ to emphasize causal origination.

āpattinidānaṃ.translation_1: Legal issues arising from offenses have offenses as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

The -jātika element indicates 'born from' or 'produced by', emphasizing origination from āpatti (offense).

āpattijātikaṃ.translation_1: Legal issues arising from offenses have offenses as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

āpattipabhavaṃ.meaning_2: production; arising; coming into being (of offenses)
āpattipabhavaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound denotes the 'production' or 'coming into being' of offenses, synonymous with other terms like origin and arising in the list of legal issue sources.
āpattipabhavaṃ.example_1: āpattādhikaraṇaṃ āpattinidānaṃ āpattisamudayaṃ āpattijātikaṃ āpattipabhavaṃ āpattisambhāraṃ āpattisamuṭṭhānaṃ.
āpattipabhavaṃ.translation_1: Legal issues arising from offenses have offenses as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

āpattisambhāraṃ.meaning_2: production; origination; accumulation of conditions for an offense
āpattisambhāraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, āpattisambhāraṃ refers to the 'production' or 'origination' of legal issues arising from offenses, paralleling terms like samudaya (arising) and pabhava (production), suggesting it denotes the accumulation or bringing together of factors that lead to an offense.
āpattisambhāraṃ.example_1: āpattādhikaraṇaṃ āpattinidānaṃ āpattisamudayaṃ āpattijātikaṃ āpattipabhavaṃ āpattisambhāraṃ āpattisamuṭṭhānaṃ.
āpattisambhāraṃ.translation_1: Legal issues arising from offenses have offenses as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

kiccayasamudayaṃ.meaning_2: arising; origination; coming into existence (of duties or functions)

The element 'yajātika' likely derives from √yaj (to arise, be born) + jāti (birth) + ka (suffix), though not directly attested; it conveys genesis tied to kicca.

hetunidānaṃ.translation_2: Legal issues arising from business have causes as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

hetusamudayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of legal issues arising from disputes or business, hetusamudayaṃ denotes the 'arising' or 'origin' of causes, parallel to terms like hetunidānaṃ (source) and hetujātikaṃ (birth), emphasizing the causal process in Vinaya adjudication.

hetusamudayaṃ.translation_2: Legal issues arising from business have causes as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

hetujātikaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of legal issues from disputes or business, hetujātikaṃ describes matters that are produced or born from causes, paralleling terms like hetunidānaṃ (source of causes) and hetupabhavaṃ (arising from causes), emphasizing causal origin in Vinaya disputes.

hetupabhavaṃ.translation_2: Legal issues arising from business have causes as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

hetusambhāraṃ.meaning_2: production; accumulation of causes; collection of conditions

The accusative form indicates it as the object of implied verbs like 'hoti' (is), paralleling the subsequent terms like paccayasamudayaṃ as synonymous elaborations.

paccayanidānaṃ.translation_2: Legal issues arising from business have conditions as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

paccayajātikaṃ.meaning_2: born (from conditions); produced (by conditions); arisen (from conditions)

paccayajātikaṃ.translation_2: Legal issues arising from business have conditions as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

paccayapabhavaṃ.meaning_2: arising (from conditions); origination (from conditions); production (from conditions)
paccayapabhavaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'paccayapabhavaṃ' is used as part of a series describing how legal issues (from disputes or business) have their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination in conditions (paccaya). It specifically denotes the 'arising' or 'coming into being' aspect dependent on supporting conditions, paralleling the English translation 'their arising'.

paccayapabhavaṃ.translation_2: Legal issues arising from business have conditions as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

paccayasambhāraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of legal issues arising from disputes or business, paccayasambhāraṃ refers to the production or coming together of conditions that give rise to the matter, parallel to terms like source, origin, birth, and arising.
paccayasambhāraṃ.example_1: vivādādhikaraṇaṃ paccayanidānaṃ, paccayasamudayaṃ, paccayajātikaṃ, paccayapabhavaṃ, paccayasambhāraṃ, paccayasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
paccayasambhāraṃ.translation_1: Legal issues arising from disputes have conditions as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

paccayasambhāraṃ.translation_2: Legal issues arising from business have conditions as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

paccayasamuṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: Legal issues arising from disputes have conditions as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

paccayasamuṭṭhānaṃ.translation_2: Legal issues arising from business have conditions as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising, their production, their origination.

adhikaraṇamūlādi.meaning_2: the roots of legal issues, etc.; the origins of disputes and so on
adhikaraṇamūlādi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound used in a Vinaya context, where adhikaraṇa refers to legal issues or disciplinary proceedings, mūla to their foundational beginnings, and ādi indicates 'etc.' or 'and the like,' encompassing related categories.
adhikaraṇamūlādi.translation_1: 3. The roots of legal issues, etc.

adhikaraṇapaccayāpatti.meaning_2: offense due to legal issue; transgression arising from disciplinary matter; violation because of legal proceedings
adhikaraṇapaccayāpatti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound refers to offenses that occur specifically because of involvement in legal or disciplinary issues (adhikaraṇa), where the legal matter serves as the supporting condition (paccaya) leading to the attainment or commission (patti) of the offense. The English translation 'Offenses because of legal issues' directly reflects this causal relationship in monastic rule violations.

āpattānāpattīti.meaning_2: offense or non-offense; offense or not an offense
āpattānāpattīti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a correlative phrase used in Vinaya contexts to question whether a particular legal issue constitutes an offense (āpatti) or a non-offense (anāpatti), as seen in the repeated structure across the sentences where it follows different types of adhikaraṇa (legal issues).
āpattānāpattīti.translation_1: “Is a legal issue arising from a dispute an offense or not an offense?”
āpattānāpattīti.translation_2: “Is a legal issue arising from an accusation an offense or not an offense?”

adhikaraṇādhippāyo.meaning_2: intention regarding the issue; purpose in relation to the legal matter; intended sense of the disciplinary proceeding
adhikaraṇādhippāyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where adhikaraṇa (issue, legal matter) serves as the upapada for adhippāya (intention, purpose), indicating purpose or intention concerning a legal or disciplinary issue. In Vinaya contexts, it likely refers to the intent behind a formal proceeding or case.

sattasamathanidānaṃ.meaning_2: origin of the settling of beings
sattasamathanidānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a neuter noun in accusative singular, likely referring to the foundational cause or narrative introduction concerning the calming or pacification of living beings, common in Buddhist texts for doctrinal origins or background stories.

kiṃsambhāro.meaning_2: what is the production?; what is the origination?
kiṃsambhāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya questions, 'kiṃsambhāro' functions as an interrogative compound asking for the causal condition or productive factor of various resolutions and acts, paralleling terms like nidāna (source) and samudaya (origin).
kiṃsambhāro.example_1: sammukhāvinayo kiṃnidāno, kiṃsamudayo, kiṃjātiko, kiṃpabhavo, kiṃsambhāro kiṃsamuṭṭhāno?

In the contextual sentences, it parallels other terms like nidānanidāno to describe the causal basis of disciplinary procedures such as face-to-face resolution or covering over with grass.

nidānajātiko.translation_2: Covering over as if with grass has sources as its source, its origin, its birth, its arising, its production, its origination.

nidānasambhāro.translation_2: Covering over as if with grass has sources as its source, its origin, its birth, its arising, its production, its origination.

nidānanidānaṃ.translation_1: Acting according to what has been admitted …

nidānasamudayaṃ.meaning_2: arising of the cause; origination from the source

nidānajātikaṃ.example_1: paṭiññātakaraṇaṃ nidānanidānaṃ, nidānasamudayaṃ, nidānajātikaṃ, nidānapabhavaṃ, nidānasambhāraṃ, nidānasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
nidānajātikaṃ.translation_1: Acting according to what has been admitted …
